column2: '13Oct'
column3: 1)	" Well
column4: first of all
column5: Bob
column6: thank you for moderating tonight. Thank you
column7: Arizona State
column8: for welcoming us.  And thank you to the Presidential Commission for undertaking this enormous task. We're proud to be here.  Mr. President
column9: I'm glad to be here with you again to share similarities and differences with the American people.  Will we ever be safe and secure again? Yes. We absolutely must be. That's the goal.  Now
column10: how do we achieve it is the most critical component of it.  I believe that this president
column11: regrettably
column12: rushed us into a war
column13: made decisions about foreign policy
column14: pushed alliances away. And
column15: as a result
column16: America is now bearing this extraordinary burden where we are not as safe as we ought to be.  The measurement is not: Are we safer? The measurement is: Are we as safe as we ought to be? And there are a host of options that this president had available to him
column17: like making sure that at all our ports in America containers are inspected. Only 95 percent of them -- 95 percent come in today uninspected. That's not good enough.  People who fly on airplanes today
column18: the cargo hold is not X-rayed
column19: but the baggage is. That's not good enough. Firehouses don't have enough firefighters in them. Police officers are being cut from the streets of America because the president decided to cut the COPS program.  So we can do a better job of homeland security. I can do a better job of waging a smarter
column20: more effective war on terror and guarantee that we will go after the terrorists.  I will hunt them down
column22: we'll capture them. We'll do whatever is necessary to be safe.  But I pledge this to you
column23: America: I will do it in the way that Franklin Roosevelt and Ronald Reagan and John Kennedy and others did
column24: where we build the strongest alliances
column25: where the world joins together
column26: where we have the best intelligence and where we are able
column27: ultimately
column28: to be more safe and secure.

column2: thank you very much. I want to thank Arizona State as well.  Yes
column3: we can be safe and secure
column4: if we stay on the offense against the terrorists and if we spread freedom and liberty around the world.  I have got a comprehensive strategy to not only chase down the Al Qaida
column5: wherever it exists -- and we're making progress; three-quarters of Al Qaida leaders have been brought to justice -- but to make sure that countries that harbor terrorists are held to account.  As a result of securing ourselves and ridding the Taliban out of Afghanistan
column6: the Afghan people had elections this weekend. And the first voter was a 19-year-old woman. Think about that. Freedom is on the march.  We held to account a terrorist regime in Saddam Hussein.  In other words
column7: in order to make sure we're secure
column8: there must be a comprehensive plan. My opponent just this weekend talked about how terrorism could be reduced to a nuisance
column9: comparing it to prostitution
column10: illegal gambling. I think that attitude and that point of view is dangerous. I don't think you can secure America for the long run if you don't have a comprehensive view as to how to defeat these people.  At home
column11: we'll do everything we can to protect the homeland. I signed the homeland security bill to better align our assets and resources. My opponent voted against it.  We're doing everything we can to protect our borders and ports.  But absolutely we can be secure in the long run. It just takes good
column12: strong leadership.

column1: Yes. When the president had an opportunity to capture or kill Osama bin Laden
column2: he took his focus off of them
column3: outsourced the job to Afghan warlords
column4: and Osama bin Laden escaped. Six months after he said Osama bin Laden must be caught dead or alive
column5: this president was asked
column6: ""Where is Osama bin Laden? "" He said
column7: ""I don't know. I don't really think about him very much. I'm not that concerned. ""  We need a president who stays deadly focused on the real war on terror.

column2: I just don't think I ever said I'm not worried about Osama bin Laden. It's kind of one of those exaggerations. Of course we're worried about Osama bin Laden. We're on the hunt after Osama bin Laden. We're using every asset at our disposal to get Osama bin Laden.  My opponent said this war is a matter of intelligence and law enforcement. No
column3: this war is a matter of using every asset at our disposal to keep the American people protected.

column11: regrettably
column12: rushed us into a war
column13: made decisions about foreign policy
column14: pushed alliances away. And
column15: as a result

column17: like making sure that at all our ports in America containers are inspected. Only 95 percent of them -- 95 percent come in today uninspected. That's not good enough.  People who fly on airplanes today

column19: but the baggage is. That's not good enough. Firehouses don't have enough firefighters in them. Police officers are being cut from the streets of America because the president decided to cut the COPS program.  So we can do a better job of homeland security. I can do a better job of waging a smarter
column20: more effective war on terror and guarantee that we will go after the terrorists.  I will hunt them down
column22: we'll capture them. We'll do whatever is necessary to be safe.  But I pledge this to you
column23: America: I will do it in the way that Franklin Roosevelt and Ronald Reagan and John Kennedy and others did
column24: where we build the strongest alliances
column25: where the world joins together
column26: where we have the best intelligence and where we are able
column27: ultimately
column28: to be more safe and secure.

column3: we can be safe and secure
column4: if we stay on the offense against the terrorists and if we spread freedom and liberty around the world.  I have got a comprehensive strategy to not only chase down the Al Qaida
column5: wherever it exists -- and we're making progress; three-quarters of Al Qaida leaders have been brought to justice -- but to make sure that countries that harbor terrorists are held to account.  As a result of securing ourselves and ridding the Taliban out of Afghanistan
column6: the Afghan people had elections this weekend. And the first voter was a 19-year-old woman. Think about that. Freedom is on the march.  We held to account a terrorist regime in Saddam Hussein.  In other words
column7: in order to make sure we're secure
column8: there must be a comprehensive plan. My opponent just this weekend talked about how terrorism could be reduced to a nuisance
column9: comparing it to prostitution
column10: illegal gambling. I think that attitude and that point of view is dangerous. I don't think you can secure America for the long run if you don't have a comprehensive view as to how to defeat these people.  At home
column11: we'll do everything we can to protect the homeland. I signed the homeland security bill to better align our assets and resources. My opponent voted against it.  We're doing everything we can to protect our borders and ports.  But absolutely we can be secure in the long run. It just takes good
column12: strong leadership.

column2: '13Oct'
column3: 1)	" Well
column4: first of all
column5: Bob
column6: thank you for moderating tonight. Thank you
column7: Arizona State
column8: for welcoming us.  And thank you to the Presidential Commission for undertaking this enormous task. We're proud to be here.  Mr. President
column9: I'm glad to be here with you again to share similarities and differences with the American people.  Will we ever be safe and secure again? Yes. We absolutely must be. That's the goal.  Now
column10: how do we achieve it is the most critical component of it.  I believe that this president
column11: regrettably
column12: rushed us into a war
column13: made decisions about foreign policy
column14: pushed alliances away. And
column15: as a result
column16: America is now bearing this extraordinary burden where we are not as safe as we ought to be.  The measurement is not: Are we safer? The measurement is: Are we as safe as we ought to be? And there are a host of options that this president had available to him
column17: like making sure that at all our ports in America containers are inspected. Only 95 percent of them -- 95 percent come in today uninspected. That's not good enough.  People who fly on airplanes today
column18: the cargo hold is not X-rayed
column19: but the baggage is. That's not good enough. Firehouses don't have enough firefighters in them. Police officers are being cut from the streets of America because the president decided to cut the COPS program.  So we can do a better job of homeland security. I can do a better job of waging a smarter
column20: more effective war on terror and guarantee that we will go after the terrorists.  I will hunt them down
column22: we'll capture them. We'll do whatever is necessary to be safe.  But I pledge this to you
column23: America: I will do it in the way that Franklin Roosevelt and Ronald Reagan and John Kennedy and others did
column24: where we build the strongest alliances
column25: where the world joins together
column26: where we have the best intelligence and where we are able
column27: ultimately
column28: to be more safe and secure.

column2: thank you very much. I want to thank Arizona State as well.  Yes
column3: we can be safe and secure
column4: if we stay on the offense against the terrorists and if we spread freedom and liberty around the world.  I have got a comprehensive strategy to not only chase down the Al Qaida
column5: wherever it exists -- and we're making progress; three-quarters of Al Qaida leaders have been brought to justice -- but to make sure that countries that harbor terrorists are held to account.  As a result of securing ourselves and ridding the Taliban out of Afghanistan
column6: the Afghan people had elections this weekend. And the first voter was a 19-year-old woman. Think about that. Freedom is on the march.  We held to account a terrorist regime in Saddam Hussein.  In other words
column7: in order to make sure we're secure
column8: there must be a comprehensive plan. My opponent just this weekend talked about how terrorism could be reduced to a nuisance
column9: comparing it to prostitution
column10: illegal gambling. I think that attitude and that point of view is dangerous. I don't think you can secure America for the long run if you don't have a comprehensive view as to how to defeat these people.  At home
column11: we'll do everything we can to protect the homeland. I signed the homeland security bill to better align our assets and resources. My opponent voted against it.  We're doing everything we can to protect our borders and ports.  But absolutely we can be secure in the long run. It just takes good
column12: strong leadership.

column1: Yes. When the president had an opportunity to capture or kill Osama bin Laden
column2: he took his focus off of them
column3: outsourced the job to Afghan warlords
column4: and Osama bin Laden escaped. Six months after he said Osama bin Laden must be caught dead or alive
column5: this president was asked
column6: ""Where is Osama bin Laden? "" He said
column7: ""I don't know. I don't really think about him very much. I'm not that concerned. ""  We need a president who stays deadly focused on the real war on terror.

column2: I just don't think I ever said I'm not worried about Osama bin Laden. It's kind of one of those exaggerations. Of course we're worried about Osama bin Laden. We're on the hunt after Osama bin Laden. We're using every asset at our disposal to get Osama bin Laden.  My opponent said this war is a matter of intelligence and law enforcement. No
column3: this war is a matter of using every asset at our disposal to keep the American people protected.

column2: '13Oct'
column3: 1)	" Well
column4: first of all
column5: Bob
column6: thank you for moderating tonight. Thank you
column7: Arizona State
column8: for welcoming us.  And thank you to the Presidential Commission for undertaking this enormous task. We're proud to be here.  Mr. President
column9: I'm glad to be here with you again to share similarities and differences with the American people.  Will we ever be safe and secure again? Yes. We absolutely must be. That's the goal.  Now
column10: how do we achieve it is the most critical component of it.  I believe that this president
column11: regrettably
column12: rushed us into a war
column13: made decisions about foreign policy
column14: pushed alliances away. And
column15: as a result
column16: America is now bearing this extraordinary burden where we are not as safe as we ought to be.  The measurement is not: Are we safer? The measurement is: Are we as safe as we ought to be? And there are a host of options that this president had available to him
column17: like making sure that at all our ports in America containers are inspected. Only 95 percent of them -- 95 percent come in today uninspected. That's not good enough.  People who fly on airplanes today
column18: the cargo hold is not X-rayed
column19: but the baggage is. That's not good enough. Firehouses don't have enough firefighters in them. Police officers are being cut from the streets of America because the president decided to cut the COPS program.  So we can do a better job of homeland security. I can do a better job of waging a smarter
column20: more effective war on terror and guarantee that we will go after the terrorists.  I will hunt them down
column22: we'll capture them. We'll do whatever is necessary to be safe.  But I pledge this to you
column23: America: I will do it in the way that Franklin Roosevelt and Ronald Reagan and John Kennedy and others did
column24: where we build the strongest alliances
column25: where the world joins together
column26: where we have the best intelligence and where we are able
column27: ultimately
column28: to be more safe and secure.

column2: thank you very much. I want to thank Arizona State as well.  Yes
column3: we can be safe and secure
column4: if we stay on the offense against the terrorists and if we spread freedom and liberty around the world.  I have got a comprehensive strategy to not only chase down the Al Qaida
column5: wherever it exists -- and we're making progress; three-quarters of Al Qaida leaders have been brought to justice -- but to make sure that countries that harbor terrorists are held to account.  As a result of securing ourselves and ridding the Taliban out of Afghanistan
column6: the Afghan people had elections this weekend. And the first voter was a 19-year-old woman. Think about that. Freedom is on the march.  We held to account a terrorist regime in Saddam Hussein.  In other words
column7: in order to make sure we're secure
column8: there must be a comprehensive plan. My opponent just this weekend talked about how terrorism could be reduced to a nuisance
column9: comparing it to prostitution
column10: illegal gambling. I think that attitude and that point of view is dangerous. I don't think you can secure America for the long run if you don't have a comprehensive view as to how to defeat these people.  At home
column11: we'll do everything we can to protect the homeland. I signed the homeland security bill to better align our assets and resources. My opponent voted against it.  We're doing everything we can to protect our borders and ports.  But absolutely we can be secure in the long run. It just takes good
column12: strong leadership.

column1: Yes. When the president had an opportunity to capture or kill Osama bin Laden
column2: he took his focus off of them
column3: outsourced the job to Afghan warlords
column4: and Osama bin Laden escaped. Six months after he said Osama bin Laden must be caught dead or alive
column5: this president was asked
column6: ""Where is Osama bin Laden? "" He said
column7: ""I don't know. I don't really think about him very much. I'm not that concerned. ""  We need a president who stays deadly focused on the real war on terror.

column2: I just don't think I ever said I'm not worried about Osama bin Laden. It's kind of one of those exaggerations. Of course we're worried about Osama bin Laden. We're on the hunt after Osama bin Laden. We're using every asset at our disposal to get Osama bin Laden.  My opponent said this war is a matter of intelligence and law enforcement. No
column3: this war is a matter of using every asset at our disposal to keep the American people protected.

column23: 'And
column24: as a result
column25: America is now bearing this extraordinary burden where we are not as safe as we ought to be.'
column26: 'The measurement is not: Are we safer?'
column27: 'The measurement is: Are we as safe as we ought to be?'
column28: 'And there are a host of options that this president had available to him
column29: like making sure that at all our ports in America containers are inspected.'
column30: 'Only 95 percent of them -- 95 percent come in today uninspected.'
column32: 'People who fly on airplanes today
column33: the cargo hold is not X-rayed
column34: but the baggage is.'
column35: ""That's not good enough.""
column36: ""Firehouses don't have enough firefighters in them.""
column37: 'Police officers are being cut from the streets of America because the president decided to cut the COPS program.'
column38: 'So we can do a better job of homeland security.'
column39: 'I can do a better job of waging a smarter
column40: more effective war on terror and guarantee that we will go after the terrorists.'
column41: ""I will hunt them down

column43: we'll capture them.""
column44: ""We'll do whatever is necessary to be safe.""
column45: 'But I pledge this to you
column46: America: I will do it in the way that Franklin Roosevelt and Ronald Reagan and John Kennedy and others did
column47: where we build the strongest alliances
column48: where the world joins together
column49: where we have the best intelligence and where we are able
column50: ultimately
column51: to be more safe and secure.'
column52: 'Bob
column53: thank you very much.'
column54: 'I want to thank Arizona State as well.'
column56: we can be safe and secure
column57: if we stay on the offense against the terrorists and if we spread freedom and liberty around the world.'
column58: ""I have got a comprehensive strategy to not only chase down the Al Qaida
column59: wherever it exists -- and we're making progress; three-quarters of Al Qaida leaders have been brought to justice -- but to make sure that countries that harbor terrorists are held to account.""
column60: 'As a result of securing ourselves and ridding the Taliban out of Afghanistan

column62: 'And the first voter was a 19-year-old woman.'
column64: 'Freedom is on the march.'
column65: 'We held to account a terrorist regime in Saddam Hussein.'

column68: there must be a comprehensive plan.""
column69: 'My opponent just this weekend talked about how terrorism could be reduced to a nuisance

column72: 'I think that attitude and that point of view is dangerous.'
column73: ""I don't think you can secure America for the long run if you don't have a comprehensive view as to how to defeat these people.""

column2: '13Oct'
column3: 10)	" Well
column4: I'm glad you raised that question. It's long overdue time to raise the minimum wage.  And
column5: America
column6: this is one of those issues that separates the president and myself.  We have fought to try to raise the minimum wage in the last years. But the Republican leadership of the House and Senate won't even let us have a vote on it. We're not allowed to vote on it. They don't want to raise the minimum wage. The minimum wage is the lowest minimum wage value it has been in our nation in 50 years.  If we raise the minimum wage
column7: which I will do over several years to $7 an hour
column8: 9. 2 million women who are trying to raise their families would earn another $3
column9: 800 a year.  The president has denied 9. 2 million women $3
column10: 800 a year
column11: but he doesn't hesitate to fight for $136
column12: 000 to a millionaire.  One percent of America got $89 billion last year in a tax cut
column13: but people working hard
column14: playing by the rules
column15: trying to take care of their kids
column16: family values
column17: that we're supposed to value so much in America -- I'm tired of politicians who talk about family values and don't value families.  What we need to do is raise the minimum wage. We also need to hold on to equal pay. Women work for 76 cents on the dollar for the same work that men do. That's not right in America.  And we had an initiative that we were working on to raise women's pay. They've cut it off. They've stopped it. They don't enforce these kinds of things.  Now
column18: I think that it's a matter of fundamental right that if we raise the minimum wage
column19: 15 million Americans would be positively affected. We'd put money into the hands of people who work hard
column20: who obey the rules
column21: who play for the American dream.  And if we did that
column22: we'd have more consumption ability in America
column23: which is what we need right now in order to kick our economy into gear. I will fight tooth and nail to pass the minimum wage.

column2: Mitch McConnell had a minimum-wage plan that I supported that would have increased the minimum wage. But let me talk about what's really important for the worker you're referring to. And that's to make sure the education system works. It's to make sure we raise standards.  Listen
column3: the No Child Left Behind Act is really a jobs act when you think about it. The No Child Left Behind Act says
column4: ""We'll raise standards. We'll increase federal spending. But in return for extra spending
column5: we now want people to measure -- states and local jurisdictions to measure to show us whether or not a child can read or write or add and subtract. ""  You cannot solve a problem unless you diagnose the problem. And we weren't diagnosing problems. And therefore just kids were being shuffled through the school.  And guess who would get shuffled through? Children whose parents wouldn't speak English as a first language just move through.  Many inner-city kids just move through. We've stopped that practice now by measuring early. And when we find a problem
column6: we spend extra money to correct it.  I remember a lady in Houston
column7: Texas
column8: told me
column9: ""Reading is the new civil right
column10: and she's right. In order to make sure people have jobs for the 21st century
column11: we've got to get it right in the education system
column12: and we're beginning to close a minority achievement gap now.  You see
column13: we'll never be able to compete in the 21st century unless we have an education system that doesn't quit on children
column14: an education system that raises standards
column15: an education that makes sure there's excellence in every classroom.

column2: will I have a litmus test for my judges? And the answer is
column3: no
column4: I will not have a litmus test. I will pick judges who will interpret the Constitution
column5: but I'll have no litmus test.

column1: Is that a new question or a 30-second question?

column2: again
column3: the president didn't answer the question.  I'll answer it straight to America. I'm not going to appoint a judge to the Court who's going to undo a constitutional right
column4: whether it's the First Amendment
column5: or the Fifth Amendment
column6: or some other right that's given under our courts today -- under the Constitution. And I believe that the right of choice is a constitutional right.  So I don't intend to see it undone.  Clearly
column7: the president wants to leave in ambivalence or intends to undo it.  But let me go a step further. We have a long distance yet to travel in terms of fairness in America. I don't know how you can govern in this country when you look at New York City and you see that 50 percent of the black males there are unemployed
column8: when you see 40 percent of Hispanic children -- of black children in some cities -- dropping out of high school.  And yet the president who talks about No Child Left Behind refused to fully fund -- by $28 billion -- that particular program so you can make a difference in the lives of those young people.  Now right here in Arizona
column9: that difference would have been $131 million to the state of Arizona to help its kids be able to have better education and to lift the property tax burden from its citizens. The president reneged on his promise to fund No Child Left Behind.  He'll tell you he's raised the money
column10: and he has. But he didn't put in what he promised
column11: and that makes a difference in the lives of our children.

column2: he clearly has a litmus test for his judges
column3: which I disagree with. And secondly
column4: only a liberal senator from Massachusetts would say that a 49 percent increase in funding for education was not enough.  We've increased funds. But more importantly
column5: we've reformed the system to make sure that we solve problems early
column6: before they're too late.  He talked about the unemployed. Absolutely we've got to make sure they get educated.  He talked about children whose parents don't speak English as a first language? Absolutely we've got to make sure they get educated.  And that's what the No Child Left Behind Act does.

column1: You don't measure it by a percentage increase. Mr. President
column2: you measure it by whether you're getting the job done. Five hundred thousand kids lost after-school programs because of your budget.  Now
column3: that's not in my gut. That's not in my value system
column4: and certainly not so that the wealthiest people in America can walk away with another tax cut.  $89 billion last year to the top 1 percent of Americans
column5: but kids lost their after-school programs. You be the judge.

column2: will I have a litmus test for my judges? And the answer is
column3: no
column4: I will not have a litmus test. I will pick judges who will interpret the Constitution
column5: but I'll have no litmus test.

column1: Is that a new question or a 30-second question?

column2: again
column3: the president didn't answer the question.  I'll answer it straight to America. I'm not going to appoint a judge to the Court who's going to undo a constitutional right
column4: whether it's the First Amendment
column5: or the Fifth Amendment
column6: or some other right that's given under our courts today -- under the Constitution. And I believe that the right of choice is a constitutional right.  So I don't intend to see it undone.  Clearly
column7: the president wants to leave in ambivalence or intends to undo it.  But let me go a step further. We have a long distance yet to travel in terms of fairness in America. I don't know how you can govern in this country when you look at New York City and you see that 50 percent of the black males there are unemployed
column8: when you see 40 percent of Hispanic children -- of black children in some cities -- dropping out of high school.  And yet the president who talks about No Child Left Behind refused to fully fund -- by $28 billion -- that particular program so you can make a difference in the lives of those young people.  Now right here in Arizona
column9: that difference would have been $131 million to the state of Arizona to help its kids be able to have better education and to lift the property tax burden from its citizens. The president reneged on his promise to fund No Child Left Behind.  He'll tell you he's raised the money
column10: and he has. But he didn't put in what he promised
column11: and that makes a difference in the lives of our children.

column2: he clearly has a litmus test for his judges
column3: which I disagree with. And secondly
column4: only a liberal senator from Massachusetts would say that a 49 percent increase in funding for education was not enough.  We've increased funds. But more importantly
column5: we've reformed the system to make sure that we solve problems early
column6: before they're too late.  He talked about the unemployed. Absolutely we've got to make sure they get educated.  He talked about children whose parents don't speak English as a first language? Absolutely we've got to make sure they get educated.  And that's what the No Child Left Behind Act does.

column1: You don't measure it by a percentage increase. Mr. President
column2: you measure it by whether you're getting the job done. Five hundred thousand kids lost after-school programs because of your budget.  Now
column3: that's not in my gut. That's not in my value system
column4: and certainly not so that the wealthiest people in America can walk away with another tax cut.  $89 billion last year to the top 1 percent of Americans
column5: but kids lost their after-school programs. You be the judge.

column4: I'm glad you raised that question. It's long overdue time to raise the minimum wage.  And
column5: America
column6: this is one of those issues that separates the president and myself.  We have fought to try to raise the minimum wage in the last years. But the Republican leadership of the House and Senate won't even let us have a vote on it. We're not allowed to vote on it. They don't want to raise the minimum wage. The minimum wage is the lowest minimum wage value it has been in our nation in 50 years.  If we raise the minimum wage
column7: which I will do over several years to $7 an hour
column8: 9. 2 million women who are trying to raise their families would earn another $3
column9: 800 a year.  The president has denied 9. 2 million women $3
column10: 800 a year
column11: but he doesn't hesitate to fight for $136
column12: 000 to a millionaire.  One percent of America got $89 billion last year in a tax cut
column13: but people working hard
column14: playing by the rules
column15: trying to take care of their kids
column16: family values
column17: that we're supposed to value so much in America -- I'm tired of politicians who talk about family values and don't value families.  What we need to do is raise the minimum wage. We also need to hold on to equal pay. Women work for 76 cents on the dollar for the same work that men do. That's not right in America.  And we had an initiative that we were working on to raise women's pay. They've cut it off. They've stopped it. They don't enforce these kinds of things.  Now
column18: I think that it's a matter of fundamental right that if we raise the minimum wage
column19: 15 million Americans would be positively affected. We'd put money into the hands of people who work hard
column20: who obey the rules
column21: who play for the American dream.  And if we did that
column22: we'd have more consumption ability in America
column23: which is what we need right now in order to kick our economy into gear. I will fight tooth and nail to pass the minimum wage.

column2: Mitch McConnell had a minimum-wage plan that I supported that would have increased the minimum wage. But let me talk about what's really important for the worker you're referring to. And that's to make sure the education system works. It's to make sure we raise standards.  Listen
column3: the No Child Left Behind Act is really a jobs act when you think about it. The No Child Left Behind Act says
column4: ""We'll raise standards. We'll increase federal spending. But in return for extra spending
column5: we now want people to measure -- states and local jurisdictions to measure to show us whether or not a child can read or write or add and subtract. ""  You cannot solve a problem unless you diagnose the problem. And we weren't diagnosing problems. And therefore just kids were being shuffled through the school.  And guess who would get shuffled through? Children whose parents wouldn't speak English as a first language just move through.  Many inner-city kids just move through. We've stopped that practice now by measuring early. And when we find a problem

column3: 10)	" Well
column4: I'm glad you raised that question. It's long overdue time to raise the minimum wage.  And
column5: America
column6: this is one of those issues that separates the president and myself.  We have fought to try to raise the minimum wage in the last years. But the Republican leadership of the House and Senate won't even let us have a vote on it. We're not allowed to vote on it. They don't want to raise the minimum wage. The minimum wage is the lowest minimum wage value it has been in our nation in 50 years.  If we raise the minimum wage
column7: which I will do over several years to $7 an hour
column8: 9. 2 million women who are trying to raise their families would earn another $3
column9: 800 a year.  The president has denied 9. 2 million women $3
column10: 800 a year
column11: but he doesn't hesitate to fight for $136
column12: 000 to a millionaire.  One percent of America got $89 billion last year in a tax cut
column13: but people working hard
column14: playing by the rules
column15: trying to take care of their kids
column16: family values
column17: that we're supposed to value so much in America -- I'm tired of politicians who talk about family values and don't value families.  What we need to do is raise the minimum wage. We also need to hold on to equal pay. Women work for 76 cents on the dollar for the same work that men do. That's not right in America.  And we had an initiative that we were working on to raise women's pay. They've cut it off. They've stopped it. They don't enforce these kinds of things.  Now
column18: I think that it's a matter of fundamental right that if we raise the minimum wage
column19: 15 million Americans would be positively affected. We'd put money into the hands of people who work hard
column20: who obey the rules
column21: who play for the American dream.  And if we did that
column22: we'd have more consumption ability in America
column23: which is what we need right now in order to kick our economy into gear. I will fight tooth and nail to pass the minimum wage.

column2: Mitch McConnell had a minimum-wage plan that I supported that would have increased the minimum wage. But let me talk about what's really important for the worker you're referring to. And that's to make sure the education system works. It's to make sure we raise standards.  Listen
column3: the No Child Left Behind Act is really a jobs act when you think about it. The No Child Left Behind Act says
column4: ""We'll raise standards. We'll increase federal spending. But in return for extra spending
column5: we now want people to measure -- states and local jurisdictions to measure to show us whether or not a child can read or write or add and subtract. ""  You cannot solve a problem unless you diagnose the problem. And we weren't diagnosing problems. And therefore just kids were being shuffled through the school.  And guess who would get shuffled through? Children whose parents wouldn't speak English as a first language just move through.  Many inner-city kids just move through. We've stopped that practice now by measuring early. And when we find a problem
column6: we spend extra money to correct it.  I remember a lady in Houston
column7: Texas
column8: told me
column9: ""Reading is the new civil right
column10: and she's right. In order to make sure people have jobs for the 21st century
column11: we've got to get it right in the education system
column12: and we're beginning to close a minority achievement gap now.  You see
column13: we'll never be able to compete in the 21st century unless we have an education system that doesn't quit on children
column14: an education system that raises standards
column15: an education that makes sure there's excellence in every classroom.

column2: will I have a litmus test for my judges? And the answer is
column3: no
column4: I will not have a litmus test. I will pick judges who will interpret the Constitution
column5: but I'll have no litmus test.

column1: Is that a new question or a 30-second question?

column2: again
column3: the president didn't answer the question.  I'll answer it straight to America. I'm not going to appoint a judge to the Court who's going to undo a constitutional right
column4: whether it's the First Amendment
column5: or the Fifth Amendment
column6: or some other right that's given under our courts today -- under the Constitution. And I believe that the right of choice is a constitutional right.  So I don't intend to see it undone.  Clearly
column7: the president wants to leave in ambivalence or intends to undo it.  But let me go a step further. We have a long distance yet to travel in terms of fairness in America. I don't know how you can govern in this country when you look at New York City and you see that 50 percent of the black males there are unemployed
column8: when you see 40 percent of Hispanic children -- of black children in some cities -- dropping out of high school.  And yet the president who talks about No Child Left Behind refused to fully fund -- by $28 billion -- that particular program so you can make a difference in the lives of those young people.  Now right here in Arizona
column9: that difference would have been $131 million to the state of Arizona to help its kids be able to have better education and to lift the property tax burden from its citizens. The president reneged on his promise to fund No Child Left Behind.  He'll tell you he's raised the money
column10: and he has. But he didn't put in what he promised
column11: and that makes a difference in the lives of our children.

column2: he clearly has a litmus test for his judges
column3: which I disagree with. And secondly
column4: only a liberal senator from Massachusetts would say that a 49 percent increase in funding for education was not enough.  We've increased funds. But more importantly
column5: we've reformed the system to make sure that we solve problems early
column6: before they're too late.  He talked about the unemployed. Absolutely we've got to make sure they get educated.  He talked about children whose parents don't speak English as a first language? Absolutely we've got to make sure they get educated.  And that's what the No Child Left Behind Act does.

column1: You don't measure it by a percentage increase. Mr. President
column2: you measure it by whether you're getting the job done. Five hundred thousand kids lost after-school programs because of your budget.  Now
column3: that's not in my gut. That's not in my value system
column4: and certainly not so that the wealthiest people in America can walk away with another tax cut.  $89 billion last year to the top 1 percent of Americans
column5: but kids lost their after-school programs. You be the judge.

column2: '13Oct'
column3: 10)	" Well
column4: I'm glad you raised that question. It's long overdue time to raise the minimum wage.  And
column5: America
column6: this is one of those issues that separates the president and myself.  We have fought to try to raise the minimum wage in the last years. But the Republican leadership of the House and Senate won't even let us have a vote on it. We're not allowed to vote on it. They don't want to raise the minimum wage. The minimum wage is the lowest minimum wage value it has been in our nation in 50 years.  If we raise the minimum wage
column7: which I will do over several years to $7 an hour
column8: 9. 2 million women who are trying to raise their families would earn another $3
column9: 800 a year.  The president has denied 9. 2 million women $3
column10: 800 a year
column11: but he doesn't hesitate to fight for $136
column12: 000 to a millionaire.  One percent of America got $89 billion last year in a tax cut
column13: but people working hard
column14: playing by the rules
column15: trying to take care of their kids
column16: family values
column17: that we're supposed to value so much in America -- I'm tired of politicians who talk about family values and don't value families.  What we need to do is raise the minimum wage. We also need to hold on to equal pay. Women work for 76 cents on the dollar for the same work that men do. That's not right in America.  And we had an initiative that we were working on to raise women's pay. They've cut it off. They've stopped it. They don't enforce these kinds of things.  Now
column18: I think that it's a matter of fundamental right that if we raise the minimum wage
column19: 15 million Americans would be positively affected. We'd put money into the hands of people who work hard
column20: who obey the rules
column21: who play for the American dream.  And if we did that
column22: we'd have more consumption ability in America
column23: which is what we need right now in order to kick our economy into gear. I will fight tooth and nail to pass the minimum wage.

column2: Mitch McConnell had a minimum-wage plan that I supported that would have increased the minimum wage. But let me talk about what's really important for the worker you're referring to. And that's to make sure the education system works. It's to make sure we raise standards.  Listen
column3: the No Child Left Behind Act is really a jobs act when you think about it. The No Child Left Behind Act says
column4: ""We'll raise standards. We'll increase federal spending. But in return for extra spending
column5: we now want people to measure -- states and local jurisdictions to measure to show us whether or not a child can read or write or add and subtract. ""  You cannot solve a problem unless you diagnose the problem. And we weren't diagnosing problems. And therefore just kids were being shuffled through the school.  And guess who would get shuffled through? Children whose parents wouldn't speak English as a first language just move through.  Many inner-city kids just move through. We've stopped that practice now by measuring early. And when we find a problem
column6: we spend extra money to correct it.  I remember a lady in Houston
column7: Texas
column8: told me
column9: ""Reading is the new civil right
column10: and she's right. In order to make sure people have jobs for the 21st century
column11: we've got to get it right in the education system
column12: and we're beginning to close a minority achievement gap now.  You see
column13: we'll never be able to compete in the 21st century unless we have an education system that doesn't quit on children
column14: an education system that raises standards
column15: an education that makes sure there's excellence in every classroom.

column2: will I have a litmus test for my judges? And the answer is
column3: no
column4: I will not have a litmus test. I will pick judges who will interpret the Constitution
column5: but I'll have no litmus test.

column1: Is that a new question or a 30-second question?

column2: again
column3: the president didn't answer the question.  I'll answer it straight to America. I'm not going to appoint a judge to the Court who's going to undo a constitutional right
column4: whether it's the First Amendment
column5: or the Fifth Amendment
column6: or some other right that's given under our courts today -- under the Constitution. And I believe that the right of choice is a constitutional right.  So I don't intend to see it undone.  Clearly
column7: the president wants to leave in ambivalence or intends to undo it.  But let me go a step further. We have a long distance yet to travel in terms of fairness in America. I don't know how you can govern in this country when you look at New York City and you see that 50 percent of the black males there are unemployed
column8: when you see 40 percent of Hispanic children -- of black children in some cities -- dropping out of high school.  And yet the president who talks about No Child Left Behind refused to fully fund -- by $28 billion -- that particular program so you can make a difference in the lives of those young people.  Now right here in Arizona
column9: that difference would have been $131 million to the state of Arizona to help its kids be able to have better education and to lift the property tax burden from its citizens. The president reneged on his promise to fund No Child Left Behind.  He'll tell you he's raised the money
column10: and he has. But he didn't put in what he promised
column11: and that makes a difference in the lives of our children.

column2: he clearly has a litmus test for his judges
column3: which I disagree with. And secondly
column4: only a liberal senator from Massachusetts would say that a 49 percent increase in funding for education was not enough.  We've increased funds. But more importantly
column5: we've reformed the system to make sure that we solve problems early
column6: before they're too late.  He talked about the unemployed. Absolutely we've got to make sure they get educated.  He talked about children whose parents don't speak English as a first language? Absolutely we've got to make sure they get educated.  And that's what the No Child Left Behind Act does.

column1: You don't measure it by a percentage increase. Mr. President
column2: you measure it by whether you're getting the job done. Five hundred thousand kids lost after-school programs because of your budget.  Now
column3: that's not in my gut. That's not in my value system
column4: and certainly not so that the wealthiest people in America can walk away with another tax cut.  $89 billion last year to the top 1 percent of Americans
column5: but kids lost their after-school programs. You be the judge.

column4: whether it's the First Amendment
column5: or the Fifth Amendment
column6: or some other right that's given under our courts today -- under the Constitution. And I believe that the right of choice is a constitutional right.  So I don't intend to see it undone.  Clearly
column7: the president wants to leave in ambivalence or intends to undo it.  But let me go a step further. We have a long distance yet to travel in terms of fairness in America. I don't know how you can govern in this country when you look at New York City and you see that 50 percent of the black males there are unemployed
column8: when you see 40 percent of Hispanic children -- of black children in some cities -- dropping out of high school.  And yet the president who talks about No Child Left Behind refused to fully fund -- by $28 billion -- that particular program so you can make a difference in the lives of those young people.  Now right here in Arizona
column9: that difference would have been $131 million to the state of Arizona to help its kids be able to have better education and to lift the property tax burden from its citizens. The president reneged on his promise to fund No Child Left Behind.  He'll tell you he's raised the money
column10: and he has. But he didn't put in what he promised
column11: and that makes a difference in the lives of our children.

column2: he clearly has a litmus test for his judges
column3: which I disagree with. And secondly
column4: only a liberal senator from Massachusetts would say that a 49 percent increase in funding for education was not enough.  We've increased funds. But more importantly
column5: we've reformed the system to make sure that we solve problems early
column6: before they're too late.  He talked about the unemployed. Absolutely we've got to make sure they get educated.  He talked about children whose parents don't speak English as a first language? Absolutely we've got to make sure they get educated.  And that's what the No Child Left Behind Act does.

column1: You don't measure it by a percentage increase. Mr. President
column2: you measure it by whether you're getting the job done. Five hundred thousand kids lost after-school programs because of your budget.  Now
column3: that's not in my gut. That's not in my value system
column4: and certainly not so that the wealthiest people in America can walk away with another tax cut.  $89 billion last year to the top 1 percent of Americans
column5: but kids lost their after-school programs. You be the judge.

column4: I'm glad you raised that question. It's long overdue time to raise the minimum wage.  And
column5: America
column6: this is one of those issues that separates the president and myself.  We have fought to try to raise the minimum wage in the last years. But the Republican leadership of the House and Senate won't even let us have a vote on it. We're not allowed to vote on it. They don't want to raise the minimum wage. The minimum wage is the lowest minimum wage value it has been in our nation in 50 years.  If we raise the minimum wage
column7: which I will do over several years to $7 an hour

We also need to hold on to equal pay. Women work for 76 cents on the dollar for the same work that men do. That's not right in America.  And we had an initiative that we were working on to raise women's pay. They've cut it off. They've stopped it. They don't enforce these kinds of things.  Now
column18: I think that it's a matter of fundamental right that if we raise the minimum wage

column23: which is what we need right now in order to kick our economy into gear. I will fight tooth and nail to pass the minimum wage.

column3: 10)	" Well
column4: I'm glad you raised that question. It's long overdue time to raise the minimum wage.  And
column5: America
column6: this is one of those issues that separates the president and myself.  We have fought to try to raise the minimum wage in the last years. But the Republican leadership of the House and Senate won't even let us have a vote on it. We're not allowed to vote on it. They don't want to raise the minimum wage. The minimum wage is the lowest minimum wage value it has been in our nation in 50 years.  If we raise the minimum wage
column7: which I will do over several years to $7 an hour
column8: 9. 2 million women who are trying to raise their families would earn another $3
column9: 800 a year.  The president has denied 9. 2 million women $3
column10: 800 a year
column11: but he doesn't hesitate to fight for $136
column12: 000 to a millionaire.  One percent of America got $89 billion last year in a tax cut
column13: but people working hard
column14: playing by the rules
column15: trying to take care of their kids
column16: family values
column17: that we're supposed to value so much in America -- I'm tired of politicians who talk about family values and don't value families.  What we need to do is raise the minimum wage. We also need to hold on to equal pay. Women work for 76 cents on the dollar for the same work that men do. That's not right in America.  And we had an initiative that we were working on to raise women's pay. They've cut it off. They've stopped it. They don't enforce these kinds of things.  Now
column18: I think that it's a matter of fundamental right that if we raise the minimum wage
column19: 15 million Americans would be positively affected. We'd put money into the hands of people who work hard
column20: who obey the rules
column21: who play for the American dream.  And if we did that
column22: we'd have more consumption ability in America
column23: which is what we need right now in order to kick our economy into gear. I will fight tooth and nail to pass the minimum wage.

column2: Mitch McConnell had a minimum-wage plan that I supported that would have increased the minimum wage. But let me talk about what's really important for the worker you're referring to. And that's to make sure the education system works. It's to make sure we raise standards.  Listen
column3: the No Child Left Behind Act is really a jobs act when you think about it. The No Child Left Behind Act says
column4: ""We'll raise standards. We'll increase federal spending. But in return for extra spending
column5: we now want people to measure -- states and local jurisdictions to measure to show us whether or not a child can read or write or add and subtract. ""  You cannot solve a problem unless you diagnose the problem. And we weren't diagnosing problems. And therefore just kids were being shuffled through the school.  And guess who would get shuffled through? Children whose parents wouldn't speak English as a first language just move through.  Many inner-city kids just move through. We've stopped that practice now by measuring early. And when we find a problem
column6: we spend extra money to correct it.  I remember a lady in Houston
column7: Texas
column8: told me
column9: ""Reading is the new civil right
column10: and she's right. In order to make sure people have jobs for the 21st century
column11: we've got to get it right in the education system
column12: and we're beginning to close a minority achievement gap now.  You see
column13: we'll never be able to compete in the 21st century unless we have an education system that doesn't quit on children
column14: an education system that raises standards
column15: an education that makes sure there's excellence in every classroom.

column2: will I have a litmus test for my judges? And the answer is
column3: no
column4: I will not have a litmus test. I will pick judges who will interpret the Constitution
column5: but I'll have no litmus test.

column1: Is that a new question or a 30-second question?

column2: again
column3: the president didn't answer the question.  I'll answer it straight to America. I'm not going to appoint a judge to the Court who's going to undo a constitutional right
column4: whether it's the First Amendment
column5: or the Fifth Amendment
column6: or some other right that's given under our courts today -- under the Constitution. And I believe that the right of choice is a constitutional right.  So I don't intend to see it undone.  Clearly
column7: the president wants to leave in ambivalence or intends to undo it.  But let me go a step further. We have a long distance yet to travel in terms of fairness in America. I don't know how you can govern in this country when you look at New York City and you see that 50 percent of the black males there are unemployed
column8: when you see 40 percent of Hispanic children -- of black children in some cities -- dropping out of high school.  And yet the president who talks about No Child Left Behind refused to fully fund -- by $28 billion -- that particular program so you can make a difference in the lives of those young people.  Now right here in Arizona
column9: that difference would have been $131 million to the state of Arizona to help its kids be able to have better education and to lift the property tax burden from its citizens. The president reneged on his promise to fund No Child Left Behind.  He'll tell you he's raised the money
column10: and he has. But he didn't put in what he promised
column11: and that makes a difference in the lives of our children.

column2: he clearly has a litmus test for his judges
column3: which I disagree with. And secondly
column4: only a liberal senator from Massachusetts would say that a 49 percent increase in funding for education was not enough.  We've increased funds. But more importantly
column5: we've reformed the system to make sure that we solve problems early
column6: before they're too late.  He talked about the unemployed. Absolutely we've got to make sure they get educated.  He talked about children whose parents don't speak English as a first language? Absolutely we've got to make sure they get educated.  And that's what the No Child Left Behind Act does.

column1: You don't measure it by a percentage increase. Mr. President
column2: you measure it by whether you're getting the job done. Five hundred thousand kids lost after-school programs because of your budget.  Now
column3: that's not in my gut. That's not in my value system
column4: and certainly not so that the wealthiest people in America can walk away with another tax cut.  $89 billion last year to the top 1 percent of Americans
column5: but kids lost their after-school programs. You be the judge.

column2: '13Oct'
column3: 10)	" Well
column4: I'm glad you raised that question. It's long overdue time to raise the minimum wage.  And
column5: America
column6: this is one of those issues that separates the president and myself.  We have fought to try to raise the minimum wage in the last years. But the Republican leadership of the House and Senate won't even let us have a vote on it. We're not allowed to vote on it. They don't want to raise the minimum wage. The minimum wage is the lowest minimum wage value it has been in our nation in 50 years.  If we raise the minimum wage
column7: which I will do over several years to $7 an hour
column8: 9. 2 million women who are trying to raise their families would earn another $3
column9: 800 a year.  The president has denied 9. 2 million women $3
column10: 800 a year
column11: but he doesn't hesitate to fight for $136
column12: 000 to a millionaire.  One percent of America got $89 billion last year in a tax cut
column13: but people working hard
column14: playing by the rules
column15: trying to take care of their kids
column16: family values
column17: that we're supposed to value so much in America -- I'm tired of politicians who talk about family values and don't value families.  What we need to do is raise the minimum wage. We also need to hold on to equal pay. Women work for 76 cents on the dollar for the same work that men do. That's not right in America.  And we had an initiative that we were working on to raise women's pay. They've cut it off. They've stopped it. They don't enforce these kinds of things.  Now
column18: I think that it's a matter of fundamental right that if we raise the minimum wage
column19: 15 million Americans would be positively affected. We'd put money into the hands of people who work hard
column20: who obey the rules
column21: who play for the American dream.  And if we did that
column22: we'd have more consumption ability in America
column23: which is what we need right now in order to kick our economy into gear. I will fight tooth and nail to pass the minimum wage.

column2: Mitch McConnell had a minimum-wage plan that I supported that would have increased the minimum wage. But let me talk about what's really important for the worker you're referring to. And that's to make sure the education system works. It's to make sure we raise standards.  Listen
column3: the No Child Left Behind Act is really a jobs act when you think about it. The No Child Left Behind Act says
column4: ""We'll raise standards. We'll increase federal spending. But in return for extra spending
column5: we now want people to measure -- states and local jurisdictions to measure to show us whether or not a child can read or write or add and subtract. ""  You cannot solve a problem unless you diagnose the problem. And we weren't diagnosing problems. And therefore just kids were being shuffled through the school.  And guess who would get shuffled through? Children whose parents wouldn't speak English as a first language just move through.  Many inner-city kids just move through. We've stopped that practice now by measuring early. And when we find a problem
column6: we spend extra money to correct it.  I remember a lady in Houston
column7: Texas
column8: told me
column9: ""Reading is the new civil right
column10: and she's right. In order to make sure people have jobs for the 21st century
column11: we've got to get it right in the education system
column12: and we're beginning to close a minority achievement gap now.  You see
column13: we'll never be able to compete in the 21st century unless we have an education system that doesn't quit on children
column14: an education system that raises standards
column15: an education that makes sure there's excellence in every classroom.

column2: will I have a litmus test for my judges? And the answer is
column3: no
column4: I will not have a litmus test. I will pick judges who will interpret the Constitution
column5: but I'll have no litmus test.

column1: Is that a new question or a 30-second question?

column2: again
column3: the president didn't answer the question.  I'll answer it straight to America. I'm not going to appoint a judge to the Court who's going to undo a constitutional right
column4: whether it's the First Amendment
column5: or the Fifth Amendment
column6: or some other right that's given under our courts today -- under the Constitution. And I believe that the right of choice is a constitutional right.  So I don't intend to see it undone.  Clearly
column7: the president wants to leave in ambivalence or intends to undo it.  But let me go a step further. We have a long distance yet to travel in terms of fairness in America. I don't know how you can govern in this country when you look at New York City and you see that 50 percent of the black males there are unemployed
column8: when you see 40 percent of Hispanic children -- of black children in some cities -- dropping out of high school.  And yet the president who talks about No Child Left Behind refused to fully fund -- by $28 billion -- that particular program so you can make a difference in the lives of those young people.  Now right here in Arizona
column9: that difference would have been $131 million to the state of Arizona to help its kids be able to have better education and to lift the property tax burden from its citizens. The president reneged on his promise to fund No Child Left Behind.  He'll tell you he's raised the money
column10: and he has. But he didn't put in what he promised
column11: and that makes a difference in the lives of our children.

column2: he clearly has a litmus test for his judges
column3: which I disagree with. And secondly
column4: only a liberal senator from Massachusetts would say that a 49 percent increase in funding for education was not enough.  We've increased funds. But more importantly
column5: we've reformed the system to make sure that we solve problems early
column6: before they're too late.  He talked about the unemployed. Absolutely we've got to make sure they get educated.  He talked about children whose parents don't speak English as a first language? Absolutely we've got to make sure they get educated.  And that's what the No Child Left Behind Act does.

column1: You don't measure it by a percentage increase. Mr. President
column2: you measure it by whether you're getting the job done. Five hundred thousand kids lost after-school programs because of your budget.  Now
column3: that's not in my gut. That's not in my value system
column4: and certainly not so that the wealthiest people in America can walk away with another tax cut.  $89 billion last year to the top 1 percent of Americans
column5: but kids lost their after-school programs. You be the judge.

column1: Is that a new question or a 30-second question?

column2: again
column3: the president didn't answer the question.  I'll answer it straight to America. I'm not going to appoint a judge to the Court who's going to undo a constitutional right
column4: whether it's the First Amendment
column5: or the Fifth Amendment
column6: or some other right that's given under our courts today -- under the Constitution. And I believe that the right of choice is a constitutional right.  So I don't intend to see it undone.  Clearly
column7: the president wants to leave in ambivalence or intends to undo it.  But let me go a step further. We have a long distance yet to travel in terms of fairness in America. I don't know how you can govern in this country when you look at New York City and you see that 50 percent of the black males there are unemployed
column8: when you see 40 percent of Hispanic children -- of black children in some cities -- dropping out of high school.  And yet the president who talks about No Child Left Behind refused to fully fund -- by $28 billion -- that particular program so you can make a difference in the lives of those young people.  Now right here in Arizona
column9: that difference would have been $131 million to the state of Arizona to help its kids be able to have better education and to lift the property tax burden from its citizens. The president reneged on his promise to fund No Child Left Behind.  He'll tell you he's raised the money
column10: and he has. But he didn't put in what he promised
column11: and that makes a difference in the lives of our children.

column2: he clearly has a litmus test for his judges
column3: which I disagree with. And secondly
column4: only a liberal senator from Massachusetts would say that a 49 percent increase in funding for education was not enough.  We've increased funds. But more importantly
column5: we've reformed the system to make sure that we solve problems early
column6: before they're too late.  He talked about the unemployed. Absolutely we've got to make sure they get educated.  He talked about children whose parents don't speak English as a first language? Absolutely we've got to make sure they get educated.  And that's what the No Child Left Behind Act does.

column1: You don't measure it by a percentage increase. Mr. President
column2: you measure it by whether you're getting the job done. Five hundred thousand kids lost after-school programs because of your budget.  Now
column3: that's not in my gut. That's not in my value system
column4: and certainly not so that the wealthiest people in America can walk away with another tax cut.  $89 billion last year to the top 1 percent of Americans
column5: but kids lost their after-school programs. You be the judge.

column6: this is one of those issues that separates the president and myself.  We have fought to try to raise the minimum wage in the last years. But the Republican leadership of the House and Senate won't even let us have a vote on it. We're not allowed to vote on it. They don't want to raise the minimum wage. The minimum wage is the lowest minimum wage value it has been in our nation in 50 years.  If we raise the minimum wage
column7: which I will do over several years to $7 an hour

We also need to hold on to equal pay. Women work for 76 cents on the dollar for the same work that men do. That's not right in America.  And we had an initiative that we were working on to raise women's pay. They've cut it off. They've stopped it. They don't enforce these kinds of things.  Now
column18: I think that it's a matter of fundamental right that if we raise the minimum wage
column19: 15 million Americans would be positively affected. We'd put money into the hands of people who work hard

column23: which is what we need right now in order to kick our economy into gear. I will fight tooth and nail to pass the minimum wage.

column4: I'm glad you raised that question. It's long overdue time to raise the minimum wage.  And
column5: America
column6: this is one of those issues that separates the president and myself.  We have fought to try to raise the minimum wage in the last years. But the Republican leadership of the House and Senate won't even let us have a vote on it. We're not allowed to vote on it. They don't want to raise the minimum wage. The minimum wage is the lowest minimum wage value it has been in our nation in 50 years.  If we raise the minimum wage
column7: which I will do over several years to $7 an hour
column8: 9. 2 million women who are trying to raise their families would earn another $3
column9: 800 a year.  The president has denied 9. 2 million women $3
column10: 800 a year
column11: but he doesn't hesitate to fight for $136
column12: 000 to a millionaire.  One percent of America got $89 billion last year in a tax cut
column13: but people working hard
column14: playing by the rules
column15: trying to take care of their kids
column16: family values
column17: that we're supposed to value so much in America -- I'm tired of politicians who talk about family values and don't value families.  What we need to do is raise the minimum wage. We also need to hold on to equal pay. Women work for 76 cents on the dollar for the same work that men do. That's not right in America.  And we had an initiative that we were working on to raise women's pay. They've cut it off. They've stopped it. They don't enforce these kinds of things.  Now
column18: I think that it's a matter of fundamental right that if we raise the minimum wage
column19: 15 million Americans would be positively affected. We'd put money into the hands of people who work hard
column20: who obey the rules
column21: who play for the American dream.  And if we did that
column22: we'd have more consumption ability in America
column23: which is what we need right now in order to kick our economy into gear. I will fight tooth and nail to pass the minimum wage.

column2: Mitch McConnell had a minimum-wage plan that I supported that would have increased the minimum wage. But let me talk about what's really important for the worker you're referring to. And that's to make sure the education system works. It's to make sure we raise standards.  Listen
column3: the No Child Left Behind Act is really a jobs act when you think about it. The No Child Left Behind Act says
column4: ""We'll raise standards. We'll increase federal spending. But in return for extra spending
column5: we now want people to measure -- states and local jurisdictions to measure to show us whether or not a child can read or write or add and subtract. ""  You cannot solve a problem unless you diagnose the problem. And we weren't diagnosing problems. And therefore just kids were being shuffled through the school.  And guess who would get shuffled through? Children whose parents wouldn't speak English as a first language just move through.  Many inner-city kids just move through. We've stopped that practice now by measuring early. And when we find a problem
column6: we spend extra money to correct it.  I remember a lady in Houston
column7: Texas
column8: told me
column9: ""Reading is the new civil right
column10: and she's right. In order to make sure people have jobs for the 21st century
column11: we've got to get it right in the education system
column12: and we're beginning to close a minority achievement gap now.  You see
column13: we'll never be able to compete in the 21st century unless we have an education system that doesn't quit on children
column14: an education system that raises standards
column15: an education that makes sure there's excellence in every classroom.

column2: will I have a litmus test for my judges? And the answer is
column3: no
column4: I will not have a litmus test. I will pick judges who will interpret the Constitution
column5: but I'll have no litmus test.

column1: Is that a new question or a 30-second question?

column2: again
column3: the president didn't answer the question.  I'll answer it straight to America. I'm not going to appoint a judge to the Court who's going to undo a constitutional right
column4: whether it's the First Amendment
column5: or the Fifth Amendment
column6: or some other right that's given under our courts today -- under the Constitution. And I believe that the right of choice is a constitutional right.  So I don't intend to see it undone.  Clearly
column7: the president wants to leave in ambivalence or intends to undo it.  But let me go a step further. We have a long distance yet to travel in terms of fairness in America. I don't know how you can govern in this country when you look at New York City and you see that 50 percent of the black males there are unemployed
column8: when you see 40 percent of Hispanic children -- of black children in some cities -- dropping out of high school.  And yet the president who talks about No Child Left Behind refused to fully fund -- by $28 billion -- that particular program so you can make a difference in the lives of those young people.  Now right here in Arizona
column9: that difference would have been $131 million to the state of Arizona to help its kids be able to have better education and to lift the property tax burden from its citizens. The president reneged on his promise to fund No Child Left Behind.  He'll tell you he's raised the money
column10: and he has. But he didn't put in what he promised
column11: and that makes a difference in the lives of our children.

column2: he clearly has a litmus test for his judges
column3: which I disagree with. And secondly
column4: only a liberal senator from Massachusetts would say that a 49 percent increase in funding for education was not enough.  We've increased funds. But more importantly
column5: we've reformed the system to make sure that we solve problems early
column6: before they're too late.  He talked about the unemployed. Absolutely we've got to make sure they get educated.  He talked about children whose parents don't speak English as a first language? Absolutely we've got to make sure they get educated.  And that's what the No Child Left Behind Act does.

column1: You don't measure it by a percentage increase. Mr. President
column2: you measure it by whether you're getting the job done. Five hundred thousand kids lost after-school programs because of your budget.  Now
column3: that's not in my gut. That's not in my value system
column4: and certainly not so that the wealthiest people in America can walk away with another tax cut.  $89 billion last year to the top 1 percent of Americans
column5: but kids lost their after-school programs. You be the judge.
