column2: '13Oct'
column3: 10)	" Well
column4: I'm glad you raised that question. It's long overdue time to raise the minimum wage.  And
column5: America
column6: this is one of those issues that separates the president and myself.  We have fought to try to raise the minimum wage in the last years. But the Republican leadership of the House and Senate won't even let us have a vote on it. We're not allowed to vote on it. They don't want to raise the minimum wage. The minimum wage is the lowest minimum wage value it has been in our nation in 50 years.  If we raise the minimum wage
column7: which I will do over several years to $7 an hour
column8: 9. 2 million women who are trying to raise their families would earn another $3
column9: 800 a year.  The president has denied 9. 2 million women $3
column10: 800 a year
column11: but he doesn't hesitate to fight for $136
column12: 000 to a millionaire.  One percent of America got $89 billion last year in a tax cut
column13: but people working hard
column14: playing by the rules
column15: trying to take care of their kids
column16: family values
column17: that we're supposed to value so much in America -- I'm tired of politicians who talk about family values and don't value families.  What we need to do is raise the minimum wage. We also need to hold on to equal pay. Women work for 76 cents on the dollar for the same work that men do. That's not right in America.  And we had an initiative that we were working on to raise women's pay. They've cut it off. They've stopped it. They don't enforce these kinds of things.  Now
column18: I think that it's a matter of fundamental right that if we raise the minimum wage
column19: 15 million Americans would be positively affected. We'd put money into the hands of people who work hard
column20: who obey the rules
column21: who play for the American dream.  And if we did that
column22: we'd have more consumption ability in America
column23: which is what we need right now in order to kick our economy into gear. I will fight tooth and nail to pass the minimum wage.

column2: Mitch McConnell had a minimum-wage plan that I supported that would have increased the minimum wage. But let me talk about what's really important for the worker you're referring to. And that's to make sure the education system works. It's to make sure we raise standards.  Listen
column3: the No Child Left Behind Act is really a jobs act when you think about it. The No Child Left Behind Act says
column4: ""We'll raise standards. We'll increase federal spending. But in return for extra spending
column5: we now want people to measure -- states and local jurisdictions to measure to show us whether or not a child can read or write or add and subtract. ""  You cannot solve a problem unless you diagnose the problem. And we weren't diagnosing problems. And therefore just kids were being shuffled through the school.  And guess who would get shuffled through? Children whose parents wouldn't speak English as a first language just move through.  Many inner-city kids just move through. We've stopped that practice now by measuring early. And when we find a problem
column6: we spend extra money to correct it.  I remember a lady in Houston
column7: Texas
column8: told me
column9: ""Reading is the new civil right
column10: and she's right. In order to make sure people have jobs for the 21st century
column11: we've got to get it right in the education system
column12: and we're beginning to close a minority achievement gap now.  You see
column13: we'll never be able to compete in the 21st century unless we have an education system that doesn't quit on children
column14: an education system that raises standards
column15: an education that makes sure there's excellence in every classroom.

column2: will I have a litmus test for my judges? And the answer is
column3: no
column4: I will not have a litmus test. I will pick judges who will interpret the Constitution
column5: but I'll have no litmus test.

column1: Is that a new question or a 30-second question?

column2: again
column3: the president didn't answer the question.  I'll answer it straight to America. I'm not going to appoint a judge to the Court who's going to undo a constitutional right
column4: whether it's the First Amendment
column5: or the Fifth Amendment
column6: or some other right that's given under our courts today -- under the Constitution. And I believe that the right of choice is a constitutional right.  So I don't intend to see it undone.  Clearly
column7: the president wants to leave in ambivalence or intends to undo it.  But let me go a step further. We have a long distance yet to travel in terms of fairness in America. I don't know how you can govern in this country when you look at New York City and you see that 50 percent of the black males there are unemployed
column8: when you see 40 percent of Hispanic children -- of black children in some cities -- dropping out of high school.  And yet the president who talks about No Child Left Behind refused to fully fund -- by $28 billion -- that particular program so you can make a difference in the lives of those young people.  Now right here in Arizona
column9: that difference would have been $131 million to the state of Arizona to help its kids be able to have better education and to lift the property tax burden from its citizens. The president reneged on his promise to fund No Child Left Behind.  He'll tell you he's raised the money
column10: and he has. But he didn't put in what he promised
column11: and that makes a difference in the lives of our children.

column2: he clearly has a litmus test for his judges
column3: which I disagree with. And secondly
column4: only a liberal senator from Massachusetts would say that a 49 percent increase in funding for education was not enough.  We've increased funds. But more importantly
column5: we've reformed the system to make sure that we solve problems early
column6: before they're too late.  He talked about the unemployed. Absolutely we've got to make sure they get educated.  He talked about children whose parents don't speak English as a first language? Absolutely we've got to make sure they get educated.  And that's what the No Child Left Behind Act does.

column1: You don't measure it by a percentage increase. Mr. President
column2: you measure it by whether you're getting the job done. Five hundred thousand kids lost after-school programs because of your budget.  Now
column3: that's not in my gut. That's not in my value system
column4: and certainly not so that the wealthiest people in America can walk away with another tax cut.  $89 billion last year to the top 1 percent of Americans
column5: but kids lost their after-school programs. You be the judge.

column2: '13Oct'
column3: 10)	" Well
column4: I'm glad you raised that question. It's long overdue time to raise the minimum wage.  And
column5: America
column6: this is one of those issues that separates the president and myself.  We have fought to try to raise the minimum wage in the last years. But the Republican leadership of the House and Senate won't even let us have a vote on it. We're not allowed to vote on it. They don't want to raise the minimum wage. The minimum wage is the lowest minimum wage value it has been in our nation in 50 years.  If we raise the minimum wage
column7: which I will do over several years to $7 an hour
column8: 9. 2 million women who are trying to raise their families would earn another $3
column9: 800 a year.  The president has denied 9. 2 million women $3
column10: 800 a year
column11: but he doesn't hesitate to fight for $136
column12: 000 to a millionaire.  One percent of America got $89 billion last year in a tax cut
column13: but people working hard
column14: playing by the rules
column15: trying to take care of their kids
column16: family values
column17: that we're supposed to value so much in America -- I'm tired of politicians who talk about family values and don't value families.  What we need to do is raise the minimum wage. We also need to hold on to equal pay. Women work for 76 cents on the dollar for the same work that men do. That's not right in America.  And we had an initiative that we were working on to raise women's pay. They've cut it off. They've stopped it. They don't enforce these kinds of things.  Now
column18: I think that it's a matter of fundamental right that if we raise the minimum wage
column19: 15 million Americans would be positively affected. We'd put money into the hands of people who work hard
column20: who obey the rules
column21: who play for the American dream.  And if we did that
column22: we'd have more consumption ability in America
column23: which is what we need right now in order to kick our economy into gear. I will fight tooth and nail to pass the minimum wage.

column2: Mitch McConnell had a minimum-wage plan that I supported that would have increased the minimum wage. But let me talk about what's really important for the worker you're referring to. And that's to make sure the education system works. It's to make sure we raise standards.  Listen
column3: the No Child Left Behind Act is really a jobs act when you think about it. The No Child Left Behind Act says
column4: ""We'll raise standards. We'll increase federal spending. But in return for extra spending
column5: we now want people to measure -- states and local jurisdictions to measure to show us whether or not a child can read or write or add and subtract. ""  You cannot solve a problem unless you diagnose the problem. And we weren't diagnosing problems. And therefore just kids were being shuffled through the school.  And guess who would get shuffled through? Children whose parents wouldn't speak English as a first language just move through.  Many inner-city kids just move through. We've stopped that practice now by measuring early. And when we find a problem
column6: we spend extra money to correct it.  I remember a lady in Houston
column7: Texas
column8: told me
column9: ""Reading is the new civil right
column10: and she's right. In order to make sure people have jobs for the 21st century
column11: we've got to get it right in the education system
column12: and we're beginning to close a minority achievement gap now.  You see
column13: we'll never be able to compete in the 21st century unless we have an education system that doesn't quit on children
column14: an education system that raises standards
column15: an education that makes sure there's excellence in every classroom.

column2: will I have a litmus test for my judges? And the answer is
column3: no
column4: I will not have a litmus test. I will pick judges who will interpret the Constitution
column5: but I'll have no litmus test.

column1: Is that a new question or a 30-second question?

column2: again
column3: the president didn't answer the question.  I'll answer it straight to America. I'm not going to appoint a judge to the Court who's going to undo a constitutional right
column4: whether it's the First Amendment
column5: or the Fifth Amendment
column6: or some other right that's given under our courts today -- under the Constitution. And I believe that the right of choice is a constitutional right.  So I don't intend to see it undone.  Clearly
column7: the president wants to leave in ambivalence or intends to undo it.  But let me go a step further. We have a long distance yet to travel in terms of fairness in America. I don't know how you can govern in this country when you look at New York City and you see that 50 percent of the black males there are unemployed
column8: when you see 40 percent of Hispanic children -- of black children in some cities -- dropping out of high school.  And yet the president who talks about No Child Left Behind refused to fully fund -- by $28 billion -- that particular program so you can make a difference in the lives of those young people.  Now right here in Arizona
column9: that difference would have been $131 million to the state of Arizona to help its kids be able to have better education and to lift the property tax burden from its citizens. The president reneged on his promise to fund No Child Left Behind.  He'll tell you he's raised the money
column10: and he has. But he didn't put in what he promised
column11: and that makes a difference in the lives of our children.

column2: he clearly has a litmus test for his judges
column3: which I disagree with. And secondly
column4: only a liberal senator from Massachusetts would say that a 49 percent increase in funding for education was not enough.  We've increased funds. But more importantly
column5: we've reformed the system to make sure that we solve problems early
column6: before they're too late.  He talked about the unemployed. Absolutely we've got to make sure they get educated.  He talked about children whose parents don't speak English as a first language? Absolutely we've got to make sure they get educated.  And that's what the No Child Left Behind Act does.

column1: You don't measure it by a percentage increase. Mr. President
column2: you measure it by whether you're getting the job done. Five hundred thousand kids lost after-school programs because of your budget.  Now
column3: that's not in my gut. That's not in my value system
column4: and certainly not so that the wealthiest people in America can walk away with another tax cut.  $89 billion last year to the top 1 percent of Americans
column5: but kids lost their after-school programs. You be the judge.

column2: '13Oct'
column3: 10)	" Well
column4: I'm glad you raised that question. It's long overdue time to raise the minimum wage.  And
column5: America
column6: this is one of those issues that separates the president and myself.  We have fought to try to raise the minimum wage in the last years. But the Republican leadership of the House and Senate won't even let us have a vote on it. We're not allowed to vote on it. They don't want to raise the minimum wage. The minimum wage is the lowest minimum wage value it has been in our nation in 50 years.  If we raise the minimum wage
column7: which I will do over several years to $7 an hour
column8: 9. 2 million women who are trying to raise their families would earn another $3
column9: 800 a year.  The president has denied 9. 2 million women $3
column10: 800 a year
column11: but he doesn't hesitate to fight for $136
column12: 000 to a millionaire.  One percent of America got $89 billion last year in a tax cut
column13: but people working hard
column14: playing by the rules
column15: trying to take care of their kids
column16: family values
column17: that we're supposed to value so much in America -- I'm tired of politicians who talk about family values and don't value families.  What we need to do is raise the minimum wage. We also need to hold on to equal pay. Women work for 76 cents on the dollar for the same work that men do. That's not right in America.  And we had an initiative that we were working on to raise women's pay. They've cut it off. They've stopped it. They don't enforce these kinds of things.  Now
column18: I think that it's a matter of fundamental right that if we raise the minimum wage
column19: 15 million Americans would be positively affected. We'd put money into the hands of people who work hard
column20: who obey the rules
column21: who play for the American dream.  And if we did that
column22: we'd have more consumption ability in America
column23: which is what we need right now in order to kick our economy into gear. I will fight tooth and nail to pass the minimum wage.

column2: Mitch McConnell had a minimum-wage plan that I supported that would have increased the minimum wage. But let me talk about what's really important for the worker you're referring to. And that's to make sure the education system works. It's to make sure we raise standards.  Listen
column3: the No Child Left Behind Act is really a jobs act when you think about it. The No Child Left Behind Act says
column4: ""We'll raise standards. We'll increase federal spending. But in return for extra spending
column5: we now want people to measure -- states and local jurisdictions to measure to show us whether or not a child can read or write or add and subtract. ""  You cannot solve a problem unless you diagnose the problem. And we weren't diagnosing problems. And therefore just kids were being shuffled through the school.  And guess who would get shuffled through? Children whose parents wouldn't speak English as a first language just move through.  Many inner-city kids just move through. We've stopped that practice now by measuring early. And when we find a problem
column6: we spend extra money to correct it.  I remember a lady in Houston
column7: Texas
column8: told me
column9: ""Reading is the new civil right
column10: and she's right. In order to make sure people have jobs for the 21st century
column11: we've got to get it right in the education system
column12: and we're beginning to close a minority achievement gap now.  You see
column13: we'll never be able to compete in the 21st century unless we have an education system that doesn't quit on children
column14: an education system that raises standards
column15: an education that makes sure there's excellence in every classroom.

column2: will I have a litmus test for my judges? And the answer is
column3: no
column4: I will not have a litmus test. I will pick judges who will interpret the Constitution
column5: but I'll have no litmus test.

column1: Is that a new question or a 30-second question?

column2: again
column3: the president didn't answer the question.  I'll answer it straight to America. I'm not going to appoint a judge to the Court who's going to undo a constitutional right
column4: whether it's the First Amendment
column5: or the Fifth Amendment
column6: or some other right that's given under our courts today -- under the Constitution. And I believe that the right of choice is a constitutional right.  So I don't intend to see it undone.  Clearly
column7: the president wants to leave in ambivalence or intends to undo it.  But let me go a step further. We have a long distance yet to travel in terms of fairness in America. I don't know how you can govern in this country when you look at New York City and you see that 50 percent of the black males there are unemployed
column8: when you see 40 percent of Hispanic children -- of black children in some cities -- dropping out of high school.  And yet the president who talks about No Child Left Behind refused to fully fund -- by $28 billion -- that particular program so you can make a difference in the lives of those young people.  Now right here in Arizona
column9: that difference would have been $131 million to the state of Arizona to help its kids be able to have better education and to lift the property tax burden from its citizens. The president reneged on his promise to fund No Child Left Behind.  He'll tell you he's raised the money
column10: and he has. But he didn't put in what he promised
column11: and that makes a difference in the lives of our children.

column2: he clearly has a litmus test for his judges
column3: which I disagree with. And secondly
column4: only a liberal senator from Massachusetts would say that a 49 percent increase in funding for education was not enough.  We've increased funds. But more importantly
column5: we've reformed the system to make sure that we solve problems early
column6: before they're too late.  He talked about the unemployed. Absolutely we've got to make sure they get educated.  He talked about children whose parents don't speak English as a first language? Absolutely we've got to make sure they get educated.  And that's what the No Child Left Behind Act does.

column1: You don't measure it by a percentage increase. Mr. President
column2: you measure it by whether you're getting the job done. Five hundred thousand kids lost after-school programs because of your budget.  Now
column3: that's not in my gut. That's not in my value system
column4: and certainly not so that the wealthiest people in America can walk away with another tax cut.  $89 billion last year to the top 1 percent of Americans
column5: but kids lost their after-school programs. You be the judge.

But the Republican leadership of the House and Senate won't even let us have a vote on it. We're not allowed to vote on it. They don't want to raise the minimum wage. The minimum wage is the lowest minimum wage value it has been in our nation in 50 years.  If we raise the minimum wage
column7: which I will do over several years to $7 an hour
column8: 9. 2 million women who are trying to raise their families would earn another $3
column9: 800 a year.  The president has denied 9. 2 million women $3
column10: 800 a year
column11: but he doesn't hesitate to fight for $136
column12: 000 to a millionaire.  One percent of America got $89 billion last year in a tax cut
column13: but people working hard
column14: playing by the rules
column15: trying to take care of their kids
column16: family values
column17: that we're supposed to value so much in America -- I'm tired of politicians who talk about family values and don't value families.  What we need to do is raise the minimum wage. We also need to hold on to equal pay. Women work for 76 cents on the dollar for the same work that men do. That's not right in America.  And we had an initiative that we were working on to raise women's pay. They've cut it off. They've stopped it. They don't enforce these kinds of things.  Now
column18: I think that it's a matter of fundamental right that if we raise the minimum wage
column19: 15 million Americans would be positively affected. We'd put money into the hands of people who work hard
column20: who obey the rules
column21: who play for the American dream.  And if we did that
column22: we'd have more consumption ability in America
column23: which is what we need right now in order to kick our economy into gear. I will fight tooth and nail to pass the minimum wage.

column2: Mitch McConnell had a minimum-wage plan that I supported that would have increased the minimum wage. But let me talk about what's really important for the worker you're referring to. And that's to make sure the education system works. It's to make sure we raise standards.  Listen
column3: the No Child Left Behind Act is really a jobs act when you think about it. The No Child Left Behind Act says
column4: ""We'll raise standards. We'll increase federal spending. But in return for extra spending
column5: we now want people to measure -- states and local jurisdictions to measure to show us whether or not a child can read or write or add and subtract. ""  You cannot solve a problem unless you diagnose the problem. And we weren't diagnosing problems. And therefore just kids were being shuffled through the school.  And guess who would get shuffled through? Children whose parents wouldn't speak English as a first language just move through.  Many inner-city kids just move through. We've stopped that practice now by measuring early. And when we find a problem
column6: we spend extra money to correct it.  I remember a lady in Houston
column7: Texas
column8: told me
column9: ""Reading is the new civil right
column10: and she's right. In order to make sure people have jobs for the 21st century
column11: we've got to get it right in the education system
column12: and we're beginning to close a minority achievement gap now.  You see
column13: we'll never be able to compete in the 21st century unless we have an education system that doesn't quit on children
column14: an education system that raises standards
column15: an education that makes sure there's excellence in every classroom.

column2: will I have a litmus test for my judges? And the answer is
column3: no
column4: I will not have a litmus test. I will pick judges who will interpret the Constitution
column5: but I'll have no litmus test.

column1: Is that a new question or a 30-second question?

column2: again
column3: the president didn't answer the question.  I'll answer it straight to America. I'm not going to appoint a judge to the Court who's going to undo a constitutional right
column4: whether it's the First Amendment
column5: or the Fifth Amendment
column6: or some other right that's given under our courts today -- under the Constitution. And I believe that the right of choice is a constitutional right.  So I don't intend to see it undone.  Clearly
column7: the president wants to leave in ambivalence or intends to undo it.  But let me go a step further. We have a long distance yet to travel in terms of fairness in America. I don't know how you can govern in this country when you look at New York City and you see that 50 percent of the black males there are unemployed
column8: when you see 40 percent of Hispanic children -- of black children in some cities -- dropping out of high school.  And yet the president who talks about No Child Left Behind refused to fully fund -- by $28 billion -- that particular program so you can make a difference in the lives of those young people.  Now right here in Arizona
column9: that difference would have been $131 million to the state of Arizona to help its kids be able to have better education and to lift the property tax burden from its citizens. The president reneged on his promise to fund No Child Left Behind.  He'll tell you he's raised the money
column10: and he has. But he didn't put in what he promised
column11: and that makes a difference in the lives of our children.

column2: he clearly has a litmus test for his judges
column3: which I disagree with. And secondly
column4: only a liberal senator from Massachusetts would say that a 49 percent increase in funding for education was not enough.  We've increased funds. But more importantly
column5: we've reformed the system to make sure that we solve problems early
column6: before they're too late.  He talked about the unemployed. Absolutely we've got to make sure they get educated.  He talked about children whose parents don't speak English as a first language? Absolutely we've got to make sure they get educated.  And that's what the No Child Left Behind Act does.

column1: You don't measure it by a percentage increase. Mr. President
column2: you measure it by whether you're getting the job done. Five hundred thousand kids lost after-school programs because of your budget.  Now
column3: that's not in my gut. That's not in my value system
column4: and certainly not so that the wealthiest people in America can walk away with another tax cut.  $89 billion last year to the top 1 percent of Americans
column5: but kids lost their after-school programs. You be the judge.

column2: '13Oct'
column3: 11)	" Well
column4: I think the fact that they're facing these repeated call-ups
column5: some of them two and three deployments
column6: and there's a stop- loss policy that prevents people from being able to get out when their time was up
column7: is a reflection of the bad judgment this president exercised in how he has engaged in the world and deployed our forces. Our military is overextended. Nine out of 10 active-duty Army divisions are either in Iraq
column8: going to Iraq or have come back from Iraq. One way or the other
column9: they're wrapped up in it.  Now
column10: I've proposed adding two active-duty divisions to the armed forces of the United States -- one combat
column11: one support.  In addition
column12: I'm going to double the number of Special Forces so that we can fight a more effective war on terror
column13: with less pressure on the National Guard and Reserve. And what I would like to do is see the National Guard and Reserve be deployed differently here in our own country. There's much we can do with them with respect to homeland security. We ought to be doing that. And that would relieve an enormous amount of pressure.  But the most important thing to relieve the pressure on all of the armed forces is frankly to run a foreign policy that recognizes that America is strongest when we are working with real alliances
column14: when we are sharing the burdens of the world by working through our statesmanship at the highest levels and our diplomacy to bring other nations to our side.  I've said it before
column15: I say it again: I believe the president broke faith with the American people in the way that he took this nation to war. He said he would work through a real alliance. He said in Cincinnati we would plan carefully
column16: we would take every precaution. Well
column17: we didn't. And the result is our forces today are overextended.  The fact is that he did not choose to go to war as a last result. And America now is paying
column18: already $120 billion
column19: up to $200 billion before we're finished and much more probably. And that is the result of this president taking his eye off of Osama bin Laden.

column1: The best way to take the pressure off our troops is to succeed in Iraq
column2: is to train Iraqis so they can do the hard work of democracy
column3: is to give them a chance to defend their country
column4: which is precisely what we're doing. We'll have 125
column5: 000 troops trained by the end of this year. I remember going on an airplane in Bangor
column6: Maine
column7: to say thanks to the reservists and Guard that were headed overseas from Tennessee and North Carolina
column8: Georgia. Some of them had been there before.  The people I talked to their spirits were high. They didn't view their service as a back-door draft. They viewed their service as an opportunity to serve their country.  My opponent
column9: the senator
column10: talks about foreign policy.  In our first debate he proposed America pass a global test. In order to defend ourselves
column11: we'd have to get international approval. That's one of the major differences we have about defending our country.  I'll work with allies. I'll work with friends. We'll continue to build strong coalitions. But I will never turn over our national- security decisions to leaders of other countries.  We'll be resolute
column12: we'll be strong
column13: and we'll wage a comprehensive war against the terrorists.

column1: I have never suggested a test where we turn over our security to any nation. In fact
column2: I've said the opposite: I will never turn the security of the United States over to any nation. No nation will ever have a veto over us. But I think it makes sense
column3: I think most Americans in their guts know
column4: that we ought to pass a sort of truth standard. That's how you gain legitimacy with your own countrypeople
column5: and that's how you gain legitimacy in the world.  But I'll never fail to protect the United States of America.

column2: there was a vast coalition put together to run Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait. The international community
column3: the international world said this is the right thing to do
column4: but when it came time to authorize the use of force on the Senate floor
column5: my opponent voted against the use of force. Apparently you can't pass any test under his vision of the world.

column2: '13Oct'
column3: 11)	" Well
column4: I think the fact that they're facing these repeated call-ups
column5: some of them two and three deployments
column6: and there's a stop- loss policy that prevents people from being able to get out when their time was up
column7: is a reflection of the bad judgment this president exercised in how he has engaged in the world and deployed our forces. Our military is overextended. Nine out of 10 active-duty Army divisions are either in Iraq
column8: going to Iraq or have come back from Iraq. One way or the other
column9: they're wrapped up in it.  Now
column10: I've proposed adding two active-duty divisions to the armed forces of the United States -- one combat
column11: one support.  In addition
column12: I'm going to double the number of Special Forces so that we can fight a more effective war on terror
column13: with less pressure on the National Guard and Reserve. And what I would like to do is see the National Guard and Reserve be deployed differently here in our own country. There's much we can do with them with respect to homeland security. We ought to be doing that. And that would relieve an enormous amount of pressure.  But the most important thing to relieve the pressure on all of the armed forces is frankly to run a foreign policy that recognizes that America is strongest when we are working with real alliances
column14: when we are sharing the burdens of the world by working through our statesmanship at the highest levels and our diplomacy to bring other nations to our side.  I've said it before
column15: I say it again: I believe the president broke faith with the American people in the way that he took this nation to war. He said he would work through a real alliance. He said in Cincinnati we would plan carefully
column16: we would take every precaution. Well
column17: we didn't. And the result is our forces today are overextended.  The fact is that he did not choose to go to war as a last result. And America now is paying
column18: already $120 billion
column19: up to $200 billion before we're finished and much more probably. And that is the result of this president taking his eye off of Osama bin Laden.

column1: The best way to take the pressure off our troops is to succeed in Iraq
column2: is to train Iraqis so they can do the hard work of democracy
column3: is to give them a chance to defend their country
column4: which is precisely what we're doing. We'll have 125
column5: 000 troops trained by the end of this year. I remember going on an airplane in Bangor
column6: Maine
column7: to say thanks to the reservists and Guard that were headed overseas from Tennessee and North Carolina
column8: Georgia. Some of them had been there before.  The people I talked to their spirits were high. They didn't view their service as a back-door draft. They viewed their service as an opportunity to serve their country.  My opponent
column9: the senator
column10: talks about foreign policy.  In our first debate he proposed America pass a global test. In order to defend ourselves
column11: we'd have to get international approval. That's one of the major differences we have about defending our country.  I'll work with allies. I'll work with friends. We'll continue to build strong coalitions. But I will never turn over our national- security decisions to leaders of other countries.  We'll be resolute
column12: we'll be strong
column13: and we'll wage a comprehensive war against the terrorists.

column1: I have never suggested a test where we turn over our security to any nation. In fact
column2: I've said the opposite: I will never turn the security of the United States over to any nation. No nation will ever have a veto over us. But I think it makes sense
column3: I think most Americans in their guts know
column4: that we ought to pass a sort of truth standard. That's how you gain legitimacy with your own countrypeople
column5: and that's how you gain legitimacy in the world.  But I'll never fail to protect the United States of America.

column2: there was a vast coalition put together to run Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait. The international community
column3: the international world said this is the right thing to do
column4: but when it came time to authorize the use of force on the Senate floor
column5: my opponent voted against the use of force. Apparently you can't pass any test under his vision of the world.

column2: '13Oct'
column3: 11)	" Well
column4: I think the fact that they're facing these repeated call-ups
column5: some of them two and three deployments
column6: and there's a stop- loss policy that prevents people from being able to get out when their time was up
column7: is a reflection of the bad judgment this president exercised in how he has engaged in the world and deployed our forces. Our military is overextended. Nine out of 10 active-duty Army divisions are either in Iraq
column8: going to Iraq or have come back from Iraq. One way or the other
column9: they're wrapped up in it.  Now
column10: I've proposed adding two active-duty divisions to the armed forces of the United States -- one combat
column11: one support.  In addition
column12: I'm going to double the number of Special Forces so that we can fight a more effective war on terror
column13: with less pressure on the National Guard and Reserve. And what I would like to do is see the National Guard and Reserve be deployed differently here in our own country. There's much we can do with them with respect to homeland security. We ought to be doing that. And that would relieve an enormous amount of pressure.  But the most important thing to relieve the pressure on all of the armed forces is frankly to run a foreign policy that recognizes that America is strongest when we are working with real alliances
column14: when we are sharing the burdens of the world by working through our statesmanship at the highest levels and our diplomacy to bring other nations to our side.  I've said it before
column15: I say it again: I believe the president broke faith with the American people in the way that he took this nation to war. He said he would work through a real alliance. He said in Cincinnati we would plan carefully
column16: we would take every precaution. Well
column17: we didn't. And the result is our forces today are overextended.  The fact is that he did not choose to go to war as a last result. And America now is paying
column18: already $120 billion
column19: up to $200 billion before we're finished and much more probably. And that is the result of this president taking his eye off of Osama bin Laden.

column1: The best way to take the pressure off our troops is to succeed in Iraq
column2: is to train Iraqis so they can do the hard work of democracy
column3: is to give them a chance to defend their country
column4: which is precisely what we're doing. We'll have 125
column5: 000 troops trained by the end of this year. I remember going on an airplane in Bangor
column6: Maine
column7: to say thanks to the reservists and Guard that were headed overseas from Tennessee and North Carolina
column8: Georgia. Some of them had been there before.  The people I talked to their spirits were high. They didn't view their service as a back-door draft. They viewed their service as an opportunity to serve their country.  My opponent
column9: the senator
column10: talks about foreign policy.  In our first debate he proposed America pass a global test. In order to defend ourselves
column11: we'd have to get international approval. That's one of the major differences we have about defending our country.  I'll work with allies. I'll work with friends. We'll continue to build strong coalitions. But I will never turn over our national- security decisions to leaders of other countries.  We'll be resolute
column12: we'll be strong
column13: and we'll wage a comprehensive war against the terrorists.

column1: I have never suggested a test where we turn over our security to any nation. In fact
column2: I've said the opposite: I will never turn the security of the United States over to any nation. No nation will ever have a veto over us. But I think it makes sense
column3: I think most Americans in their guts know
column4: that we ought to pass a sort of truth standard. That's how you gain legitimacy with your own countrypeople
column5: and that's how you gain legitimacy in the world.  But I'll never fail to protect the United States of America.

column2: there was a vast coalition put together to run Saddam Hussein out of Kuwait. The international community
column3: the international world said this is the right thing to do
column4: but when it came time to authorize the use of force on the Senate floor
column5: my opponent voted against the use of force. Apparently you can't pass any test under his vision of the world.

column2: '13Oct'
column3: 12)	" Actually
column4: I made my intentions -- made my views clear. I did think we ought to extend the assault weapons ban
column5: and was told the fact that the bill was never going to move
column6: because Republicans and Democrats were against the assault weapon ban
column7: people of both parties. I believe law-abiding citizens ought to be able to own a gun. I believe in background checks at gun shows or anywhere to make sure that guns don't get in the hands of people that shouldn't have them. But the best way to protect our citizens from guns is to prosecute those who commit crimes with guns. And that's why early in my administration I called the attorney general and the U. S. attorneys and said: Put together a task force all around the country to prosecute those who commit crimes with guns. And the prosecutions are up by about 68 percent -- I believe -- is the number.  Neighborhoods are safer when we crack down on people who commit crimes with guns.  To me
column8: that's the best way to secure America.

column1: I believe it was a failure of presidential leadership not to reauthorize the assault weapons ban. I am a hunter. I'm a gun owner. I've been a hunter since I was a kid
column3: 13 years old. And I respect the Second Amendment and I will not tamper with the Second Amendment.  But I'll tell you this. I'm also a former law enforcement officer. I ran one of the largest district attorney's offices in America
column4: one of the ten largest. I put people behind bars for the rest of their life. I've broken up organized crime. I know something about prosecuting.  And most of the law enforcement agencies in America wanted that assault weapons ban. They don't want to go into a drug bust and be facing an AK-47.  I was hunting in Iowa last year with a sheriff from one of the counties there
column5: and he pointed to a house in back of us
column6: and said
column7: ""See the house over? We just did a drug bust a week earlier
column8: and the guy we arrested had an AK-47 lying on the bed right beside him. ""  Because of the president's decision today
column9: law enforcement officers will walk into a place that will be more dangerous. Terrorists can now come into America and go to a gun show and
column10: without even a background check
column11: buy an assault weapon today.  And that's what Osama bin Laden's handbook said
column12: because we captured it in Afghanistan. It encouraged them to do it.  So I believe America's less safe.  If Tom DeLay or someone in the House said to me
column13: ""Sorry
column14: we don't have the votes
column15: I'd have said
column16: ""Then we're going to have a fight. ""  And I'd have taken it out to the country and I'd have had every law enforcement officer in the country visit those congressmen. We'd have won what Bill Clinton won.

column10: ""And that's why early in my administration I called the attorney general and the U. S. attorneys and said: Put together a task force all around the country to prosecute those who commit crimes with guns.""
column11: 'And the prosecutions are up by about 68 percent -- I believe -- is the number.'
column12: 'Neighborhoods are safer when we crack down on people who commit crimes with guns.'
column13: ""To me
column14: that's the best way to secure America.""
column15: 'I believe it was a failure of presidential leadership not to reauthorize the assault weapons ban.'
column16: 'I am a hunter.'
column17: ""I'm a gun owner.""
column18: ""I've been a hunter since I was a kid
column20: 13 years old.""
column21: 'And I respect the Second Amendment and I will not tamper with the Second Amendment.'
column22: ""But I'll tell you this.""
column23: ""I'm also a former law enforcement officer.""
column24: ""I ran one of the largest district attorney's offices in America
column25: one of the ten largest.""
column26: 'I put people behind bars for the rest of their life.'
column27: ""I've broken up organized crime.""
column28: 'I know something about prosecuting.'
column29: 'And most of the law enforcement agencies in America wanted that assault weapons ban.'
column30: ""They don't want to go into a drug bust and be facing an AK-47.""
column31: 'I was hunting in Iowa last year with a sheriff from one of the counties there
column32: and he pointed to a house in back of us
column33: and said
column34: ""See the house over?'
column35: 'We just did a drug bust a week earlier
column36: and the guy we arrested had an AK-47 lying on the bed right beside him. ""'
column37: ""Because of the president's decision today
column38: law enforcement officers will walk into a place that will be more dangerous.""
column39: 'Terrorists can now come into America and go to a gun show and
column40: without even a background check
column41: buy an assault weapon today.'
column42: ""And that's what Osama bin Laden's handbook said
column43: because we captured it in Afghanistan.""
column44: 'It encouraged them to do it.'
column45: ""So I believe America's less safe.""
column46: 'If Tom DeLay or someone in the House said to me
column47: ""Sorry
column48: we don\'t have the votes
column49: I\'d have said
column50: ""Then we\'re going to have a fight. ""'
column51: ""And I'd have taken it out to the country and I'd have had every law enforcement officer in the country visit those congressmen.""
column52: ""We'd have won what Bill Clinton won.""]"	4036.88	4188.0	NOT_FOUND

column2: '13Oct'
column4: Bob
column5: regrettably
column6: we have not moved far enough along. And I regret to say that this administration has even blocked steps that could help us move further along. I'll give you an example.  I served on the Small Business Committee for a long time. I was chairman of it once. Now I'm the senior Democrat on it. We used to -- you know
column7: we have a goal there for minority set-aside programs
column8: to try to encourage ownership in the country. They don't reach those goals. They don't even fight to reach those goals. They've tried to undo them.  The fact is that in too many parts of our country
column9: we still have discrimination. And affirmative action is not just something that applies to people of color. Some people have a mistaken view of it in America. It also is with respect to women
column10: it's with respect to other efforts to try to reach out and be inclusive in our country.  I think that we have a long way to go
column11: regrettably. If you look at what's happened -- we've made progress
column12: I want to say that at the same time.  During the Clinton years
column13: as you may recall
column14: there was a fight over affirmative action. And there were many people
column15: like myself
column16: who opposed quotas
column17: who felt there were places where it was overreaching. So we had a policy called ""Mend it
column18: don't end it. ""We fixed it.  And we fixed it for a reason: because there are too many people still in this country who feel the stark resistance of racism
column19: and so we have a distance to travel. As president
column20: I will make certain we travel it.  Now
column21: let me just share something. This president is the first president ever
column22: I think
column23: not to meet with the NAACP. This is a president who hasn't met with the Black Congressional Caucus. This is a president who has not met with the civil rights leadership of our country.  If a president doesn't reach out and bring people in and be inclusive
column24: then how are we going to get over those barriers? I see that as part of my job as president
column25: and I'll make my best effort to do it.

column2: first of all
column3: it is just not true that I haven't met with the Black Congressional Caucus. I met with the Black Congressional Caucus at the White House. And secondly
column4: like my opponent
column5: I don't agree we ought to have quotas. I agree
column6: we shouldn't have quotas.  But we ought to have an aggressive effort to make sure people are educated
column7: to make sure when they get out of high school there's Pell Grants available for them
column8: which is what we've done. We've expanded Pell Grants by a million students.  Do you realize today in America
column9: we spend $73 billion to help 10 million low- and middle-income families better afford college?  That's the access I believe is necessary
column10: is to make sure every child learns to read
column11: write
column12: add and subtract early
column13: to be able to build on that education by going to college so they can start their careers with a college diploma.  I believe the best way to help our small businesses is not only through small-business loans
column14: which we have increased since I've been the president of the United States
column15: but to unbundle government contracts so people have a chance to be able to bid and receive a contract to help get their business going.  Minority ownership of businesses are up
column16: because we created an environment for the entrepreneurial spirit to be strong.  I believe part of a hopeful society is one in which somebody owns something. Today in America more minorities own a home than ever before. And that's hopeful
column17: and that's positive.

column2: I respect everything that the president has said and certainly respect his faith. I think it's important and I share it. I think that he just said that freedom is a gift from the Almighty. Everything is a gift from the Almighty. And as I measure the words of the Bible -- and we all do; different people measure different things -- the Koran
column3: the Torah
column4: or
column5: you know
column6: Native Americans who gave me a blessing the other day had their own special sense of connectedness to a higher being. And people all find their ways to express it.  I was taught -- I went to a church school and I was taught that the two greatest commandments are: Love the Lord
column7: your God
column8: with all your mind
column9: your body and your soul
column10: and love your neighbor as yourself. And frankly
column11: I think we have a lot more loving of our neighbor to do in this country and on this planet.  We have a separate and unequal school system in the United States of America. There's one for the people who have
column12: and there's one for the people who don't have. And we're struggling with that today.  And the president and I have a difference of opinion about how we live out our sense of our faith.  I talked about it earlier when I talked about the works and faith without works being dead.  I think we've got a lot more work to do. And as president
column13: I will always respect everybody's right to practice religion as they choose -- or not to practice -- because that's part of America.

column2: '13Oct'
column4: Bob
column5: regrettably
column6: we have not moved far enough along. And I regret to say that this administration has even blocked steps that could help us move further along. I'll give you an example.  I served on the Small Business Committee for a long time. I was chairman of it once. Now I'm the senior Democrat on it. We used to -- you know
column7: we have a goal there for minority set-aside programs
column8: to try to encourage ownership in the country. They don't reach those goals. They don't even fight to reach those goals. They've tried to undo them.  The fact is that in too many parts of our country
column9: we still have discrimination. And affirmative action is not just something that applies to people of color. Some people have a mistaken view of it in America. It also is with respect to women
column10: it's with respect to other efforts to try to reach out and be inclusive in our country.  I think that we have a long way to go
column11: regrettably. If you look at what's happened -- we've made progress
column12: I want to say that at the same time.  During the Clinton years
column13: as you may recall
column14: there was a fight over affirmative action. And there were many people
column15: like myself
column16: who opposed quotas
column17: who felt there were places where it was overreaching. So we had a policy called ""Mend it
column18: don't end it. ""We fixed it.  And we fixed it for a reason: because there are too many people still in this country who feel the stark resistance of racism
column19: and so we have a distance to travel. As president
column20: I will make certain we travel it.  Now
column21: let me just share something. This president is the first president ever
column22: I think
column23: not to meet with the NAACP. This is a president who hasn't met with the Black Congressional Caucus. This is a president who has not met with the civil rights leadership of our country.  If a president doesn't reach out and bring people in and be inclusive
column24: then how are we going to get over those barriers? I see that as part of my job as president
column25: and I'll make my best effort to do it.

column2: first of all
column3: it is just not true that I haven't met with the Black Congressional Caucus. I met with the Black Congressional Caucus at the White House. And secondly
column4: like my opponent
column5: I don't agree we ought to have quotas. I agree
column6: we shouldn't have quotas.  But we ought to have an aggressive effort to make sure people are educated
column7: to make sure when they get out of high school there's Pell Grants available for them
column8: which is what we've done. We've expanded Pell Grants by a million students.  Do you realize today in America
column9: we spend $73 billion to help 10 million low- and middle-income families better afford college?  That's the access I believe is necessary
column10: is to make sure every child learns to read
column11: write
column12: add and subtract early
column13: to be able to build on that education by going to college so they can start their careers with a college diploma.  I believe the best way to help our small businesses is not only through small-business loans
column14: which we have increased since I've been the president of the United States
column15: but to unbundle government contracts so people have a chance to be able to bid and receive a contract to help get their business going.  Minority ownership of businesses are up
column16: because we created an environment for the entrepreneurial spirit to be strong.  I believe part of a hopeful society is one in which somebody owns something. Today in America more minorities own a home than ever before. And that's hopeful
column17: and that's positive.

column2: I respect everything that the president has said and certainly respect his faith. I think it's important and I share it. I think that he just said that freedom is a gift from the Almighty. Everything is a gift from the Almighty. And as I measure the words of the Bible -- and we all do; different people measure different things -- the Koran
column3: the Torah
column4: or
column5: you know
column6: Native Americans who gave me a blessing the other day had their own special sense of connectedness to a higher being. And people all find their ways to express it.  I was taught -- I went to a church school and I was taught that the two greatest commandments are: Love the Lord
column7: your God
column8: with all your mind
column9: your body and your soul
column10: and love your neighbor as yourself. And frankly
column11: I think we have a lot more loving of our neighbor to do in this country and on this planet.  We have a separate and unequal school system in the United States of America. There's one for the people who have
column12: and there's one for the people who don't have. And we're struggling with that today.  And the president and I have a difference of opinion about how we live out our sense of our faith.  I talked about it earlier when I talked about the works and faith without works being dead.  I think we've got a lot more work to do. And as president
column13: I will always respect everybody's right to practice religion as they choose -- or not to practice -- because that's part of America.

column2: '13Oct'
column4: Bob
column5: regrettably
column6: we have not moved far enough along. And I regret to say that this administration has even blocked steps that could help us move further along. I'll give you an example.  I served on the Small Business Committee for a long time. I was chairman of it once. Now I'm the senior Democrat on it. We used to -- you know
column7: we have a goal there for minority set-aside programs
column8: to try to encourage ownership in the country. They don't reach those goals. They don't even fight to reach those goals. They've tried to undo them.  The fact is that in too many parts of our country
column9: we still have discrimination. And affirmative action is not just something that applies to people of color. Some people have a mistaken view of it in America. It also is with respect to women
column10: it's with respect to other efforts to try to reach out and be inclusive in our country.  I think that we have a long way to go
column11: regrettably. If you look at what's happened -- we've made progress
column12: I want to say that at the same time.  During the Clinton years
column13: as you may recall
column14: there was a fight over affirmative action. And there were many people
column15: like myself
column16: who opposed quotas
column17: who felt there were places where it was overreaching. So we had a policy called ""Mend it
column18: don't end it. ""We fixed it.  And we fixed it for a reason: because there are too many people still in this country who feel the stark resistance of racism
column19: and so we have a distance to travel. As president
column20: I will make certain we travel it.  Now
column21: let me just share something. This president is the first president ever
column22: I think
column23: not to meet with the NAACP. This is a president who hasn't met with the Black Congressional Caucus. This is a president who has not met with the civil rights leadership of our country.  If a president doesn't reach out and bring people in and be inclusive
column24: then how are we going to get over those barriers? I see that as part of my job as president
column25: and I'll make my best effort to do it.

column2: first of all
column3: it is just not true that I haven't met with the Black Congressional Caucus. I met with the Black Congressional Caucus at the White House. And secondly
column4: like my opponent
column5: I don't agree we ought to have quotas. I agree
column6: we shouldn't have quotas.  But we ought to have an aggressive effort to make sure people are educated
column7: to make sure when they get out of high school there's Pell Grants available for them
column8: which is what we've done. We've expanded Pell Grants by a million students.  Do you realize today in America
column9: we spend $73 billion to help 10 million low- and middle-income families better afford college?  That's the access I believe is necessary
column10: is to make sure every child learns to read
column11: write
column12: add and subtract early
column13: to be able to build on that education by going to college so they can start their careers with a college diploma.  I believe the best way to help our small businesses is not only through small-business loans
column14: which we have increased since I've been the president of the United States
column15: but to unbundle government contracts so people have a chance to be able to bid and receive a contract to help get their business going.  Minority ownership of businesses are up
column16: because we created an environment for the entrepreneurial spirit to be strong.  I believe part of a hopeful society is one in which somebody owns something. Today in America more minorities own a home than ever before. And that's hopeful
column17: and that's positive.

column2: I respect everything that the president has said and certainly respect his faith. I think it's important and I share it. I think that he just said that freedom is a gift from the Almighty. Everything is a gift from the Almighty. And as I measure the words of the Bible -- and we all do; different people measure different things -- the Koran
column3: the Torah
column4: or
column5: you know
column6: Native Americans who gave me a blessing the other day had their own special sense of connectedness to a higher being. And people all find their ways to express it.  I was taught -- I went to a church school and I was taught that the two greatest commandments are: Love the Lord
column7: your God
column8: with all your mind
column9: your body and your soul
column10: and love your neighbor as yourself. And frankly
column11: I think we have a lot more loving of our neighbor to do in this country and on this planet.  We have a separate and unequal school system in the United States of America. There's one for the people who have
column12: and there's one for the people who don't have. And we're struggling with that today.  And the president and I have a difference of opinion about how we live out our sense of our faith.  I talked about it earlier when I talked about the works and faith without works being dead.  I think we've got a lot more work to do. And as president
column13: I will always respect everybody's right to practice religion as they choose -- or not to practice -- because that's part of America.

column2: '13Oct'
column3: 14)	" Very much so. Let me pay a compliment to the president
column4: if I may. I think in those days after 9/11
column5: I thought the president did a terrific job. And I really was moved
column6: as well as impressed
column7: by the speech that he gave to the Congress.  And I think the hug Tom Daschle gave him at that moment was about as genuine a sense of there being no Democrats
column8: no Republicans
column9: we were all just Americans. That's where we were.  That's not where we are today. I regret to say that the president who called himself a uniter
column10: not a divider
column11: is now presiding over the most divided America in the recent memory of our country. I've never seen such ideological squabbles in the Congress of the United States. I've never seen members of a party locked out of meetings the way they're locked out today.  We have to change that. And as president
column12: I am committed to changing that. I don't care if the idea comes from the other side or this side. I think we have to come together and work to change it.  And I've done that. Over 20 years in the United States Senate
column13: I've worked with John McCain
column14: who's sitting here
column15: I've worked with other colleagues. I've reached across the aisle. I've tried to find the common ground
column16: because that's what makes us strong as Americans.  And if Americans trust me with the presidency
column17: I can pledge to you
column18: we will have the most significant effort
column19: openly -- not secret meetings in the White House with special interests
column20: not ideologically driven efforts to push people aside -- but a genuine effort to try to restore America's hope and possibilities by bringing people together.  And one of the ways we're going to do it is
column21: I'm going to work with my friend
column22: John McCain
column23: to further campaign finance reform so we get these incredible amounts of money out of the system and open it up to average people
column24: so America is really represented by the people who make up America.

column1: My biggest disappointment in Washington is how partisan the town is. I had a record of working with Republicans and Democrats as the governor of Texas
column2: and I was hopeful I'd be able to do the same thing. And we made good progress early on. The No Child Left Behind Act
column3: incredibly enough
column4: was good work between me and my administration and people like Senator Ted Kennedy.  And we worked together with Democrats to relieve the tax burden on the middle class and all who pay taxes in order to make sure this economy continues to grow.  But Washington is a tough town. And the way I view it is there's a lot of entrenched special interests there
column5: people who are
column6: you know
column7: on one side of the issue or another and they spend enormous sums of money and they convince different senators to taut their way or different congressmen to talk about their issue
column8: and they dig in.  I'll continue
column9: in the four years
column10: to continue to try to work to do so.  My opponent said this is a bitterly divided time. Pretty divided in the 2000 election. So in other words
column11: it's pretty divided during the 1990s as well.  We're just in a period -- we've got to work to bring it -- my opponent keeps mentioning John McCain
column12: and I'm glad he did. John McCain is for me for president because he understands I have the right view in winning the war on terror and that my plan will succeed in Iraq. And my opponent has got a plan of retreat and defeat in Iraq.

column1: To listen to them. (LAUGHTER)  To stand up straight and not scowl.  (LAUGHTER)  I love the strong women around me. I can't tell you how much I love my wife and our daughters.  I am -- you know it's really interesting. I tell the people on the campaign trail
column2: when I asked Laura to marry me
column3: she said
column4: ""Fine
column5: just so long as I never have to give a speech. ""I said
column6: ""OK
column7: you've got a deal. ""Fortunately
column8: she didn't hold me to that deal. And she's out campaigning along with our girls. And she speaks English a lot better than I do. I think people understand what she's saying.  But they see a compassionate
column9: strong
column10: great first lady in Laura Bush. I can't tell you how lucky I am. When I met her in the backyard at Joe and Jan O'Neill's in Midland
column11: Texas
column12: it was the classic backyard barbecue. O'Neill said
column13: ""Come on over. I think you'll find somebody who might interest you. ""So I said all right. Bopped over there. There was only four of us there. And not only did she interest me
column14: I guess you would say it was love at first sight.

column2: I guess the president and you and I are three examples of lucky people who married up. (LAUGHTER)  And some would say maybe me more so than others.  (LAUGHTER)  But I can take it.  (LAUGHTER)  Can I say

column4: but my mom passed away a couple years ago
column5: just before I was deciding to run. And she was in the hospital
column6: and I went in to talk to her and tell her what I was thinking of doing.  And she looked at me from her hospital bed and she just looked at me and she said
column7: ""Remember: integrity

column9: integrity. ""Those are the three words that she left me with.  And my daughters and my wife are people who just are filled with that sense of what's right
column10: what's wrong.  They also kick me around. They keep me honest. They don't let me get away with anything. I can sometimes take myself too seriously. They surely don't let me do that.  And I'm blessed
column11: as I think the president is blessed
column12: as I said last time. I've watched him with the first lady
column13: who I admire a great deal
column14: and his daughters. He's a great father. And I think we're both very lucky.

column2: '13Oct'
column3: 14)	" Very much so. Let me pay a compliment to the president
column4: if I may. I think in those days after 9/11
column5: I thought the president did a terrific job. And I really was moved
column6: as well as impressed
column7: by the speech that he gave to the Congress.  And I think the hug Tom Daschle gave him at that moment was about as genuine a sense of there being no Democrats
column8: no Republicans
column9: we were all just Americans. That's where we were.  That's not where we are today. I regret to say that the president who called himself a uniter
column10: not a divider
column11: is now presiding over the most divided America in the recent memory of our country. I've never seen such ideological squabbles in the Congress of the United States. I've never seen members of a party locked out of meetings the way they're locked out today.  We have to change that. And as president
column12: I am committed to changing that. I don't care if the idea comes from the other side or this side. I think we have to come together and work to change it.  And I've done that. Over 20 years in the United States Senate
column13: I've worked with John McCain
column14: who's sitting here
column15: I've worked with other colleagues. I've reached across the aisle. I've tried to find the common ground
column16: because that's what makes us strong as Americans.  And if Americans trust me with the presidency
column17: I can pledge to you
column18: we will have the most significant effort
column19: openly -- not secret meetings in the White House with special interests
column20: not ideologically driven efforts to push people aside -- but a genuine effort to try to restore America's hope and possibilities by bringing people together.  And one of the ways we're going to do it is
column21: I'm going to work with my friend
column22: John McCain
column23: to further campaign finance reform so we get these incredible amounts of money out of the system and open it up to average people
column24: so America is really represented by the people who make up America.

column1: My biggest disappointment in Washington is how partisan the town is. I had a record of working with Republicans and Democrats as the governor of Texas
column2: and I was hopeful I'd be able to do the same thing. And we made good progress early on. The No Child Left Behind Act
column3: incredibly enough
column4: was good work between me and my administration and people like Senator Ted Kennedy.  And we worked together with Democrats to relieve the tax burden on the middle class and all who pay taxes in order to make sure this economy continues to grow.  But Washington is a tough town. And the way I view it is there's a lot of entrenched special interests there
column5: people who are
column6: you know
column7: on one side of the issue or another and they spend enormous sums of money and they convince different senators to taut their way or different congressmen to talk about their issue
column8: and they dig in.  I'll continue
column9: in the four years
column10: to continue to try to work to do so.  My opponent said this is a bitterly divided time. Pretty divided in the 2000 election. So in other words
column11: it's pretty divided during the 1990s as well.  We're just in a period -- we've got to work to bring it -- my opponent keeps mentioning John McCain
column12: and I'm glad he did. John McCain is for me for president because he understands I have the right view in winning the war on terror and that my plan will succeed in Iraq. And my opponent has got a plan of retreat and defeat in Iraq.

column1: To listen to them. (LAUGHTER)  To stand up straight and not scowl.  (LAUGHTER)  I love the strong women around me. I can't tell you how much I love my wife and our daughters.  I am -- you know it's really interesting. I tell the people on the campaign trail
column2: when I asked Laura to marry me
column3: she said
column4: ""Fine
column5: just so long as I never have to give a speech. ""I said
column6: ""OK
column7: you've got a deal. ""Fortunately
column8: she didn't hold me to that deal. And she's out campaigning along with our girls. And she speaks English a lot better than I do. I think people understand what she's saying.  But they see a compassionate
column9: strong
column10: great first lady in Laura Bush. I can't tell you how lucky I am. When I met her in the backyard at Joe and Jan O'Neill's in Midland
column11: Texas
column12: it was the classic backyard barbecue. O'Neill said
column13: ""Come on over. I think you'll find somebody who might interest you. ""So I said all right. Bopped over there. There was only four of us there. And not only did she interest me
column14: I guess you would say it was love at first sight.

column2: I guess the president and you and I are three examples of lucky people who married up. (LAUGHTER)  And some would say maybe me more so than others.  (LAUGHTER)  But I can take it.  (LAUGHTER)  Can I say
column3: if I could just say a word about a woman that you didn't ask about
column4: but my mom passed away a couple years ago
column5: just before I was deciding to run. And she was in the hospital
column6: and I went in to talk to her and tell her what I was thinking of doing.  And she looked at me from her hospital bed and she just looked at me and she said
column7: ""Remember: integrity
column8: integrity
column9: integrity. ""Those are the three words that she left me with.  And my daughters and my wife are people who just are filled with that sense of what's right
column10: what's wrong.  They also kick me around. They keep me honest. They don't let me get away with anything. I can sometimes take myself too seriously. They surely don't let me do that.  And I'm blessed
column11: as I think the president is blessed
column12: as I said last time. I've watched him with the first lady
column13: who I admire a great deal
column14: and his daughters. He's a great father. And I think we're both very lucky.

column3: 14)	" Very much so. Let me pay a compliment to the president
column4: if I may. I think in those days after 9/11
column5: I thought the president did a terrific job. And I really was moved
column6: as well as impressed
column7: by the speech that he gave to the Congress.  And I think the hug Tom Daschle gave him at that moment was about as genuine a sense of there being no Democrats
column8: no Republicans
column9: we were all just Americans. That's where we were.  That's not where we are today. I regret to say that the president who called himself a uniter
column10: not a divider
column11: is now presiding over the most divided America in the recent memory of our country. I've never seen such ideological squabbles in the Congress of the United States. I've never seen members of a party locked out of meetings the way they're locked out today.  We have to change that. And as president
column12: I am committed to changing that. I don't care if the idea comes from the other side or this side. I think we have to come together and work to change it.  And I've done that. Over 20 years in the United States Senate
column13: I've worked with John McCain
column14: who's sitting here
column15: I've worked with other colleagues. I've reached across the aisle. I've tried to find the common ground
column16: because that's what makes us strong as Americans.  And if Americans trust me with the presidency
column17: I can pledge to you
column18: we will have the most significant effort
column19: openly -- not secret meetings in the White House with special interests
column20: not ideologically driven efforts to push people aside -- but a genuine effort to try to restore America's hope and possibilities by bringing people together.  And one of the ways we're going to do it is
column21: I'm going to work with my friend
column22: John McCain
column23: to further campaign finance reform so we get these incredible amounts of money out of the system and open it up to average people
column24: so America is really represented by the people who make up America.

column1: My biggest disappointment in Washington is how partisan the town is. I had a record of working with Republicans and Democrats as the governor of Texas
column2: and I was hopeful I'd be able to do the same thing. And we made good progress early on. The No Child Left Behind Act
column3: incredibly enough
column4: was good work between me and my administration and people like Senator Ted Kennedy.  And we worked together with Democrats to relieve the tax burden on the middle class and all who pay taxes in order to make sure this economy continues to grow.  But Washington is a tough town. And the way I view it is there's a lot of entrenched special interests there
column5: people who are
column6: you know
column7: on one side of the issue or another and they spend enormous sums of money and they convince different senators to taut their way or different congressmen to talk about their issue
column8: and they dig in.  I'll continue
column9: in the four years
column10: to continue to try to work to do so.  My opponent said this is a bitterly divided time. Pretty divided in the 2000 election. So in other words
column11: it's pretty divided during the 1990s as well.  We're just in a period -- we've got to work to bring it -- my opponent keeps mentioning John McCain
column12: and I'm glad he did. John McCain is for me for president because he understands I have the right view in winning the war on terror and that my plan will succeed in Iraq. And my opponent has got a plan of retreat and defeat in Iraq.

column1: To listen to them. (LAUGHTER)  To stand up straight and not scowl.  (LAUGHTER)  I love the strong women around me. I can't tell you how much I love my wife and our daughters.  I am -- you know it's really interesting. I tell the people on the campaign trail
column2: when I asked Laura to marry me
column3: she said
column4: ""Fine
column5: just so long as I never have to give a speech. ""I said
column6: ""OK
column7: you've got a deal. ""Fortunately
column8: she didn't hold me to that deal. And she's out campaigning along with our girls. And she speaks English a lot better than I do. I think people understand what she's saying.  But they see a compassionate
column9: strong
column10: great first lady in Laura Bush. I can't tell you how lucky I am. When I met her in the backyard at Joe and Jan O'Neill's in Midland
column11: Texas
column12: it was the classic backyard barbecue. O'Neill said
column13: ""Come on over. I think you'll find somebody who might interest you. ""So I said all right. Bopped over there. There was only four of us there. And not only did she interest me
column14: I guess you would say it was love at first sight.

column2: I guess the president and you and I are three examples of lucky people who married up. (LAUGHTER)  And some would say maybe me more so than others.  (LAUGHTER)  But I can take it.  (LAUGHTER)  Can I say
column3: if I could just say a word about a woman that you didn't ask about
column4: but my mom passed away a couple years ago
column5: just before I was deciding to run. And she was in the hospital
column6: and I went in to talk to her and tell her what I was thinking of doing.  And she looked at me from her hospital bed and she just looked at me and she said
column7: ""Remember: integrity
column8: integrity
column9: integrity. ""Those are the three words that she left me with.  And my daughters and my wife are people who just are filled with that sense of what's right
column10: what's wrong.  They also kick me around. They keep me honest. They don't let me get away with anything. I can sometimes take myself too seriously. They surely don't let me do that.  And I'm blessed
column11: as I think the president is blessed
column12: as I said last time. I've watched him with the first lady
column13: who I admire a great deal
column14: and his daughters. He's a great father. And I think we're both very lucky.
