And we worked together with Democrats to relieve the tax burden on the middle class and all who pay taxes in order to make sure this economy continues to grow.  But Washington is a tough town. And the way I view it is there's a lot of entrenched special interests there
column5: people who are
column6: you know
column7: on one side of the issue or another and they spend enormous sums of money and they convince different senators to taut their way or different congressmen to talk about their issue
column8: and they dig in.  I'll continue
column9: in the four years
column10: to continue to try to work to do so.  My opponent said this is a bitterly divided time. Pretty divided in the 2000 election. So in other words
column11: it's pretty divided during the 1990s as well.  We're just in a period -- we've got to work to bring it -- my opponent keeps mentioning John McCain
column12: and I'm glad he did. John McCain is for me for president because he understands I have the right view in winning the war on terror and that my plan will succeed in Iraq. And my opponent has got a plan of retreat and defeat in Iraq.

column1: To listen to them. (LAUGHTER)  To stand up straight and not scowl.  (LAUGHTER)  I love the strong women around me. I can't tell you how much I love my wife and our daughters.  I am -- you know it's really interesting. I tell the people on the campaign trail
column2: when I asked Laura to marry me
column3: she said
column4: ""Fine
column5: just so long as I never have to give a speech. ""I said
column6: ""OK
column7: you've got a deal. ""Fortunately
column8: she didn't hold me to that deal. And she's out campaigning along with our girls. And she speaks English a lot better than I do. I think people understand what she's saying.  But they see a compassionate
column9: strong
column10: great first lady in Laura Bush. I can't tell you how lucky I am. When I met her in the backyard at Joe and Jan O'Neill's in Midland
column11: Texas
column12: it was the classic backyard barbecue. O'Neill said
column13: ""Come on over. I think you'll find somebody who might interest you. ""So I said all right. Bopped over there. There was only four of us there. And not only did she interest me
column14: I guess you would say it was love at first sight.

column2: I guess the president and you and I are three examples of lucky people who married up. (LAUGHTER)  And some would say maybe me more so than others.  (LAUGHTER)  But I can take it.  (LAUGHTER)  Can I say
column3: if I could just say a word about a woman that you didn't ask about
column4: but my mom passed away a couple years ago
column5: just before I was deciding to run. And she was in the hospital
column6: and I went in to talk to her and tell her what I was thinking of doing.  And she looked at me from her hospital bed and she just looked at me and she said
column7: ""Remember: integrity
column8: integrity
column9: integrity. ""Those are the three words that she left me with.  And my daughters and my wife are people who just are filled with that sense of what's right
column10: what's wrong.  They also kick me around. They keep me honest. They don't let me get away with anything. I can sometimes take myself too seriously. They surely don't let me do that.  And I'm blessed
column11: as I think the president is blessed
column12: as I said last time. I've watched him with the first lady
column13: who I admire a great deal
column14: and his daughters. He's a great father. And I think we're both very lucky.

column3: 14)	" Very much so. Let me pay a compliment to the president
column4: if I may. I think in those days after 9/11
column5: I thought the president did a terrific job. And I really was moved
column6: as well as impressed
column7: by the speech that he gave to the Congress.  And I think the hug Tom Daschle gave him at that moment was about as genuine a sense of there being no Democrats
column8: no Republicans
column9: we were all just Americans. That's where we were.  That's not where we are today. I regret to say that the president who called himself a uniter
column10: not a divider
column11: is now presiding over the most divided America in the recent memory of our country. I've never seen such ideological squabbles in the Congress of the United States. I've never seen members of a party locked out of meetings the way they're locked out today.  We have to change that. And as president
column12: I am committed to changing that. I don't care if the idea comes from the other side or this side. I think we have to come together and work to change it.  And I've done that. Over 20 years in the United States Senate
column13: I've worked with John McCain
column14: who's sitting here
column15: I've worked with other colleagues. I've reached across the aisle. I've tried to find the common ground
column16: because that's what makes us strong as Americans.  And if Americans trust me with the presidency
column17: I can pledge to you
column18: we will have the most significant effort
column19: openly -- not secret meetings in the White House with special interests
column20: not ideologically driven efforts to push people aside -- but a genuine effort to try to restore America's hope and possibilities by bringing people together.  And one of the ways we're going to do it is
column21: I'm going to work with my friend
column22: John McCain
column23: to further campaign finance reform so we get these incredible amounts of money out of the system and open it up to average people
column24: so America is really represented by the people who make up America.

column1: My biggest disappointment in Washington is how partisan the town is. I had a record of working with Republicans and Democrats as the governor of Texas
column2: and I was hopeful I'd be able to do the same thing. And we made good progress early on. The No Child Left Behind Act
column3: incredibly enough
column4: was good work between me and my administration and people like Senator Ted Kennedy.  And we worked together with Democrats to relieve the tax burden on the middle class and all who pay taxes in order to make sure this economy continues to grow.  But Washington is a tough town. And the way I view it is there's a lot of entrenched special interests there
column5: people who are
column6: you know
column7: on one side of the issue or another and they spend enormous sums of money and they convince different senators to taut their way or different congressmen to talk about their issue
column8: and they dig in.  I'll continue
column9: in the four years
column10: to continue to try to work to do so.  My opponent said this is a bitterly divided time. Pretty divided in the 2000 election. So in other words
column11: it's pretty divided during the 1990s as well.  We're just in a period -- we've got to work to bring it -- my opponent keeps mentioning John McCain
column12: and I'm glad he did. John McCain is for me for president because he understands I have the right view in winning the war on terror and that my plan will succeed in Iraq. And my opponent has got a plan of retreat and defeat in Iraq.

column2: '13Oct'
column3: 14)	" Very much so. Let me pay a compliment to the president
column4: if I may. I think in those days after 9/11
column5: I thought the president did a terrific job. And I really was moved
column6: as well as impressed
column7: by the speech that he gave to the Congress.  And I think the hug Tom Daschle gave him at that moment was about as genuine a sense of there being no Democrats
column8: no Republicans
column9: we were all just Americans. That's where we were.  That's not where we are today. I regret to say that the president who called himself a uniter
column10: not a divider
column11: is now presiding over the most divided America in the recent memory of our country. I've never seen such ideological squabbles in the Congress of the United States. I've never seen members of a party locked out of meetings the way they're locked out today.  We have to change that. And as president
column12: I am committed to changing that. I don't care if the idea comes from the other side or this side. I think we have to come together and work to change it.  And I've done that. Over 20 years in the United States Senate
column13: I've worked with John McCain
column14: who's sitting here
column15: I've worked with other colleagues. I've reached across the aisle. I've tried to find the common ground
column16: because that's what makes us strong as Americans.  And if Americans trust me with the presidency
column17: I can pledge to you
column18: we will have the most significant effort
column19: openly -- not secret meetings in the White House with special interests
column20: not ideologically driven efforts to push people aside -- but a genuine effort to try to restore America's hope and possibilities by bringing people together.  And one of the ways we're going to do it is
column21: I'm going to work with my friend
column22: John McCain
column23: to further campaign finance reform so we get these incredible amounts of money out of the system and open it up to average people
column24: so America is really represented by the people who make up America.

column1: My biggest disappointment in Washington is how partisan the town is. I had a record of working with Republicans and Democrats as the governor of Texas
column2: and I was hopeful I'd be able to do the same thing. And we made good progress early on. The No Child Left Behind Act
column3: incredibly enough
column4: was good work between me and my administration and people like Senator Ted Kennedy.  And we worked together with Democrats to relieve the tax burden on the middle class and all who pay taxes in order to make sure this economy continues to grow.  But Washington is a tough town. And the way I view it is there's a lot of entrenched special interests there
column5: people who are
column6: you know
column7: on one side of the issue or another and they spend enormous sums of money and they convince different senators to taut their way or different congressmen to talk about their issue
column8: and they dig in.  I'll continue
column9: in the four years
column10: to continue to try to work to do so.  My opponent said this is a bitterly divided time. Pretty divided in the 2000 election. So in other words
column11: it's pretty divided during the 1990s as well.  We're just in a period -- we've got to work to bring it -- my opponent keeps mentioning John McCain
column12: and I'm glad he did. John McCain is for me for president because he understands I have the right view in winning the war on terror and that my plan will succeed in Iraq. And my opponent has got a plan of retreat and defeat in Iraq.

column1: To listen to them. (LAUGHTER)  To stand up straight and not scowl.  (LAUGHTER)  I love the strong women around me. I can't tell you how much I love my wife and our daughters.  I am -- you know it's really interesting. I tell the people on the campaign trail
column2: when I asked Laura to marry me
column3: she said
column4: ""Fine
column5: just so long as I never have to give a speech. ""I said
column6: ""OK
column7: you've got a deal. ""Fortunately
column8: she didn't hold me to that deal. And she's out campaigning along with our girls. And she speaks English a lot better than I do. I think people understand what she's saying.  But they see a compassionate
column9: strong
column10: great first lady in Laura Bush. I can't tell you how lucky I am. When I met her in the backyard at Joe and Jan O'Neill's in Midland
column11: Texas
column12: it was the classic backyard barbecue. O'Neill said
column13: ""Come on over. I think you'll find somebody who might interest you. ""So I said all right. Bopped over there. There was only four of us there. And not only did she interest me
column14: I guess you would say it was love at first sight.

column2: I guess the president and you and I are three examples of lucky people who married up. (LAUGHTER)  And some would say maybe me more so than others.  (LAUGHTER)  But I can take it.  (LAUGHTER)  Can I say
column3: if I could just say a word about a woman that you didn't ask about
column4: but my mom passed away a couple years ago
column5: just before I was deciding to run. And she was in the hospital
column6: and I went in to talk to her and tell her what I was thinking of doing.  And she looked at me from her hospital bed and she just looked at me and she said
column7: ""Remember: integrity
column8: integrity
column9: integrity. ""Those are the three words that she left me with.  And my daughters and my wife are people who just are filled with that sense of what's right
column10: what's wrong.  They also kick me around. They keep me honest. They don't let me get away with anything. I can sometimes take myself too seriously. They surely don't let me do that.  And I'm blessed
column11: as I think the president is blessed
column12: as I said last time. I've watched him with the first lady
column13: who I admire a great deal
column14: and his daughters. He's a great father. And I think we're both very lucky.

column9: we were all just Americans. That's where we were.  That's not where we are today. I regret to say that the president who called himself a uniter
column10: not a divider
column11: is now presiding over the most divided America in the recent memory of our country. I've never seen such ideological squabbles in the Congress of the United States. I've never seen members of a party locked out of meetings the way they're locked out today.  We have to change that. And as president
column12: I am committed to changing that. I don't care if the idea comes from the other side or this side. I think we have to come together and work to change it.  And I've done that. Over 20 years in the United States Senate
column13: I've worked with John McCain
column14: who's sitting here
column15: I've worked with other colleagues. I've reached across the aisle. I've tried to find the common ground
column16: because that's what makes us strong as Americans.  And if Americans trust me with the presidency
column17: I can pledge to you
column18: we will have the most significant effort
column19: openly -- not secret meetings in the White House with special interests
column20: not ideologically driven efforts to push people aside -- but a genuine effort to try to restore America's hope and possibilities by bringing people together.  And one of the ways we're going to do it is
column21: I'm going to work with my friend
column22: John McCain
column23: to further campaign finance reform so we get these incredible amounts of money out of the system and open it up to average people
column24: so America is really represented by the people who make up America.

column1: My biggest disappointment in Washington is how partisan the town is. I had a record of working with Republicans and Democrats as the governor of Texas
column2: and I was hopeful I'd be able to do the same thing. And we made good progress early on. The No Child Left Behind Act
column3: incredibly enough
column4: was good work between me and my administration and people like Senator Ted Kennedy.  And we worked together with Democrats to relieve the tax burden on the middle class and all who pay taxes in order to make sure this economy continues to grow.  But Washington is a tough town. And the way I view it is there's a lot of entrenched special interests there
column5: people who are
column6: you know
column7: on one side of the issue or another and they spend enormous sums of money and they convince different senators to taut their way or different congressmen to talk about their issue
column8: and they dig in.  I'll continue
column9: in the four years
column10: to continue to try to work to do so.  My opponent said this is a bitterly divided time. Pretty divided in the 2000 election. So in other words
column11: it's pretty divided during the 1990s as well.  We're just in a period -- we've got to work to bring it -- my opponent keeps mentioning John McCain
column12: and I'm glad he did. John McCain is for me for president because he understands I have the right view in winning the war on terror and that my plan will succeed in Iraq. And my opponent has got a plan of retreat and defeat in Iraq.

column1: To listen to them. (LAUGHTER)  To stand up straight and not scowl.  (LAUGHTER)  I love the strong women around me. I can't tell you how much I love my wife and our daughters.  I am -- you know it's really interesting. I tell the people on the campaign trail
column2: when I asked Laura to marry me
column3: she said
column4: ""Fine
column5: just so long as I never have to give a speech. ""I said
column6: ""OK
column7: you've got a deal. ""Fortunately
column8: she didn't hold me to that deal. And she's out campaigning along with our girls. And she speaks English a lot better than I do. I think people understand what she's saying.  But they see a compassionate
column9: strong
column10: great first lady in Laura Bush. I can't tell you how lucky I am. When I met her in the backyard at Joe and Jan O'Neill's in Midland
column11: Texas
column12: it was the classic backyard barbecue. O'Neill said
column13: ""Come on over. I think you'll find somebody who might interest you. ""So I said all right. Bopped over there. There was only four of us there. And not only did she interest me
column14: I guess you would say it was love at first sight.

column2: I guess the president and you and I are three examples of lucky people who married up. (LAUGHTER)  And some would say maybe me more so than others.  (LAUGHTER)  But I can take it.  (LAUGHTER)  Can I say
column3: if I could just say a word about a woman that you didn't ask about
column4: but my mom passed away a couple years ago
column5: just before I was deciding to run. And she was in the hospital
column6: and I went in to talk to her and tell her what I was thinking of doing.  And she looked at me from her hospital bed and she just looked at me and she said
column7: ""Remember: integrity
column8: integrity
column9: integrity. ""Those are the three words that she left me with.  And my daughters and my wife are people who just are filled with that sense of what's right
column10: what's wrong.  They also kick me around. They keep me honest. They don't let me get away with anything. I can sometimes take myself too seriously. They surely don't let me do that.  And I'm blessed
column11: as I think the president is blessed
column12: as I said last time. I've watched him with the first lady
column13: who I admire a great deal
column14: and his daughters. He's a great father. And I think we're both very lucky.

column3: 14)	" Very much so. Let me pay a compliment to the president
column4: if I may. I think in those days after 9/11
column5: I thought the president did a terrific job. And I really was moved
column6: as well as impressed
column7: by the speech that he gave to the Congress.  And I think the hug Tom Daschle gave him at that moment was about as genuine a sense of there being no Democrats
column8: no Republicans
column9: we were all just Americans. That's where we were.  That's not where we are today. I regret to say that the president who called himself a uniter
column10: not a divider
column11: is now presiding over the most divided America in the recent memory of our country. I've never seen such ideological squabbles in the Congress of the United States. I've never seen members of a party locked out of meetings the way they're locked out today.  We have to change that. And as president
column12: I am committed to changing that. I don't care if the idea comes from the other side or this side. I think we have to come together and work to change it.  And I've done that. Over 20 years in the United States Senate
column13: I've worked with John McCain
column14: who's sitting here
column15: I've worked with other colleagues. I've reached across the aisle. I've tried to find the common ground
column16: because that's what makes us strong as Americans.  And if Americans trust me with the presidency
column17: I can pledge to you
column18: we will have the most significant effort
column19: openly -- not secret meetings in the White House with special interests
column20: not ideologically driven efforts to push people aside -- but a genuine effort to try to restore America's hope and possibilities by bringing people together.  And one of the ways we're going to do it is
column21: I'm going to work with my friend
column22: John McCain
column23: to further campaign finance reform so we get these incredible amounts of money out of the system and open it up to average people
column24: so America is really represented by the people who make up America.

column1: My biggest disappointment in Washington is how partisan the town is. I had a record of working with Republicans and Democrats as the governor of Texas
column2: and I was hopeful I'd be able to do the same thing. And we made good progress early on. The No Child Left Behind Act
column3: incredibly enough
column4: was good work between me and my administration and people like Senator Ted Kennedy.  And we worked together with Democrats to relieve the tax burden on the middle class and all who pay taxes in order to make sure this economy continues to grow.  But Washington is a tough town. And the way I view it is there's a lot of entrenched special interests there
column5: people who are
column6: you know
column7: on one side of the issue or another and they spend enormous sums of money and they convince different senators to taut their way or different congressmen to talk about their issue
column8: and they dig in.  I'll continue
column9: in the four years
column10: to continue to try to work to do so.  My opponent said this is a bitterly divided time. Pretty divided in the 2000 election. So in other words
column11: it's pretty divided during the 1990s as well.  We're just in a period -- we've got to work to bring it -- my opponent keeps mentioning John McCain
column12: and I'm glad he did. John McCain is for me for president because he understands I have the right view in winning the war on terror and that my plan will succeed in Iraq. And my opponent has got a plan of retreat and defeat in Iraq.

column1: To listen to them. (LAUGHTER)  To stand up straight and not scowl.  (LAUGHTER)  I love the strong women around me. I can't tell you how much I love my wife and our daughters.  I am -- you know it's really interesting. I tell the people on the campaign trail
column2: when I asked Laura to marry me
column3: she said
column4: ""Fine
column5: just so long as I never have to give a speech. ""I said
column6: ""OK
column7: you've got a deal. ""Fortunately
column8: she didn't hold me to that deal. And she's out campaigning along with our girls. And she speaks English a lot better than I do. I think people understand what she's saying.  But they see a compassionate
column9: strong
column10: great first lady in Laura Bush. I can't tell you how lucky I am. When I met her in the backyard at Joe and Jan O'Neill's in Midland
column11: Texas
column12: it was the classic backyard barbecue. O'Neill said
column13: ""Come on over. I think you'll find somebody who might interest you. ""So I said all right. Bopped over there. There was only four of us there. And not only did she interest me
column14: I guess you would say it was love at first sight.

column2: I guess the president and you and I are three examples of lucky people who married up. (LAUGHTER)  And some would say maybe me more so than others.  (LAUGHTER)  But I can take it.  (LAUGHTER)  Can I say
column3: if I could just say a word about a woman that you didn't ask about
column4: but my mom passed away a couple years ago
column5: just before I was deciding to run. And she was in the hospital
column6: and I went in to talk to her and tell her what I was thinking of doing.  And she looked at me from her hospital bed and she just looked at me and she said
column7: ""Remember: integrity
column8: integrity
column9: integrity. ""Those are the three words that she left me with.  And my daughters and my wife are people who just are filled with that sense of what's right
column10: what's wrong.  They also kick me around. They keep me honest. They don't let me get away with anything. I can sometimes take myself too seriously. They surely don't let me do that.  And I'm blessed
column11: as I think the president is blessed
column12: as I said last time. I've watched him with the first lady
column13: who I admire a great deal
column14: and his daughters. He's a great father. And I think we're both very lucky.

column2: '13Oct'
column3: 14)	" Very much so. Let me pay a compliment to the president
column4: if I may. I think in those days after 9/11
column5: I thought the president did a terrific job. And I really was moved
column6: as well as impressed
column7: by the speech that he gave to the Congress.  And I think the hug Tom Daschle gave him at that moment was about as genuine a sense of there being no Democrats
column8: no Republicans
column9: we were all just Americans. That's where we were.  That's not where we are today. I regret to say that the president who called himself a uniter
column10: not a divider
column11: is now presiding over the most divided America in the recent memory of our country. I've never seen such ideological squabbles in the Congress of the United States. I've never seen members of a party locked out of meetings the way they're locked out today.  We have to change that. And as president
column12: I am committed to changing that. I don't care if the idea comes from the other side or this side. I think we have to come together and work to change it.  And I've done that. Over 20 years in the United States Senate
column13: I've worked with John McCain
column14: who's sitting here
column15: I've worked with other colleagues. I've reached across the aisle. I've tried to find the common ground
column16: because that's what makes us strong as Americans.  And if Americans trust me with the presidency
column17: I can pledge to you
column18: we will have the most significant effort
column19: openly -- not secret meetings in the White House with special interests
column20: not ideologically driven efforts to push people aside -- but a genuine effort to try to restore America's hope and possibilities by bringing people together.  And one of the ways we're going to do it is
column21: I'm going to work with my friend
column22: John McCain
column23: to further campaign finance reform so we get these incredible amounts of money out of the system and open it up to average people
column24: so America is really represented by the people who make up America.

column1: My biggest disappointment in Washington is how partisan the town is. I had a record of working with Republicans and Democrats as the governor of Texas
column2: and I was hopeful I'd be able to do the same thing. And we made good progress early on. The No Child Left Behind Act
column3: incredibly enough
column4: was good work between me and my administration and people like Senator Ted Kennedy.  And we worked together with Democrats to relieve the tax burden on the middle class and all who pay taxes in order to make sure this economy continues to grow.  But Washington is a tough town. And the way I view it is there's a lot of entrenched special interests there
column5: people who are
column6: you know
column7: on one side of the issue or another and they spend enormous sums of money and they convince different senators to taut their way or different congressmen to talk about their issue
column8: and they dig in.  I'll continue
column9: in the four years
column10: to continue to try to work to do so.  My opponent said this is a bitterly divided time. Pretty divided in the 2000 election. So in other words
column11: it's pretty divided during the 1990s as well.  We're just in a period -- we've got to work to bring it -- my opponent keeps mentioning John McCain
column12: and I'm glad he did. John McCain is for me for president because he understands I have the right view in winning the war on terror and that my plan will succeed in Iraq. And my opponent has got a plan of retreat and defeat in Iraq.

column1: To listen to them. (LAUGHTER)  To stand up straight and not scowl.  (LAUGHTER)  I love the strong women around me. I can't tell you how much I love my wife and our daughters.  I am -- you know it's really interesting. I tell the people on the campaign trail
column2: when I asked Laura to marry me
column3: she said
column4: ""Fine
column5: just so long as I never have to give a speech. ""I said
column6: ""OK
column7: you've got a deal. ""Fortunately
column8: she didn't hold me to that deal. And she's out campaigning along with our girls. And she speaks English a lot better than I do. I think people understand what she's saying.  But they see a compassionate
column9: strong
column10: great first lady in Laura Bush. I can't tell you how lucky I am. When I met her in the backyard at Joe and Jan O'Neill's in Midland
column11: Texas
column12: it was the classic backyard barbecue. O'Neill said
column13: ""Come on over. I think you'll find somebody who might interest you. ""So I said all right. Bopped over there. There was only four of us there. And not only did she interest me
column14: I guess you would say it was love at first sight.

column2: I guess the president and you and I are three examples of lucky people who married up. (LAUGHTER)  And some would say maybe me more so than others.  (LAUGHTER)  But I can take it.  (LAUGHTER)  Can I say
column3: if I could just say a word about a woman that you didn't ask about
column4: but my mom passed away a couple years ago
column5: just before I was deciding to run. And she was in the hospital
column6: and I went in to talk to her and tell her what I was thinking of doing.  And she looked at me from her hospital bed and she just looked at me and she said
column7: ""Remember: integrity
column8: integrity
column9: integrity. ""Those are the three words that she left me with.  And my daughters and my wife are people who just are filled with that sense of what's right
column10: what's wrong.  They also kick me around. They keep me honest. They don't let me get away with anything. I can sometimes take myself too seriously. They surely don't let me do that.  And I'm blessed
column11: as I think the president is blessed
column12: as I said last time. I've watched him with the first lady
column13: who I admire a great deal
column14: and his daughters. He's a great father. And I think we're both very lucky.

column2: '13Oct'
column3: 15)	" My fellow Americans
column4: as you heard from Bob Schieffer a moment ago
column5: America is being tested by division. More than ever
column6: we need to be united as a country. And
column7: like Franklin Roosevelt
column8: I don't care whether an idea is a Republican idea or a Democrat idea. I just care whether it works for America and whether it's going to make us stronger.  These are dangerous times. I believe I offer tested
column9: strong leadership that can calm the waters of the troubled world. And I believe that we can together do things that are within the grasp of Americans.  We can lift our schools up. We can create jobs that pay more than the jobs we're losing overseas. We can have health care for all Americans. We can further the cause of equality in our nation.  Let me just make it clear: I will never allow any country to have a veto over our security. Just as I fought for our country as a young man
column10: with the same passion I will fight to defend this nation that I love.  And
column11: with faith in God and with conviction in the mission of America
column12: I believe that we can reach higher. I believe we can do better.  I think the greatest possibilities of our country
column13: our dreams and our hopes
column14: are out there just waiting for us to grab onto them. And I ask you to embark on that journey with me.  I ask you for your trust. I ask you for your help. I ask you to allow me the privilege of leading this great nation of ours
column15: of helping us to be stronger here at home and to be respected again in the world and
column16: most of all
column17: to be safer forever.  Thank you. Goodnight. And God bless the United States of America.

column2: there's a painting by a friend of Laura and mine named -- by Tom Lee. And it's a West Texas painting
column3: a painting of a mountain scene. And he said this about it.  He said
column4: ""Sarah and I live on the east side of the mountain. It's the sunrise side
column5: not the sunset side. It's the side to see the day that is coming
column6: not to see the day that is gone. ""  I love the optimism in that painting
column7: because that's how I feel about America. And we've been through a lot together during the last 3 3/4 years. We've come through a recession
column8: a stock market decline
column9: an attack on our country.  And yet
column10: because of the hard work of the American people and good policies
column11: this economy is growing. Over the next four years
column12: we'll make sure the economy continues to grow.  We reformed our school system
column13: and now there's an achievement gap in America that's beginning to close. Over the next four years
column14: we'll continue to insist on excellence in every classroom in America so that our children have a chance to realize the great promise of America.  Over the next four years
column15: we'll continue to work to make sure health care is available and affordable.  Over the next four years
column16: we'll continue to rally the armies of compassion
column17: to help heal the hurt that exists in some of our country's neighborhoods.  I'm optimistic that we'll win the war on terror
column18: but I understand it requires firm resolve and clear purpose. We must never waver in the face of this enemy that -- these ideologues of hate.  And as we pursue the enemy wherever it exists
column19: we'll also spread freedom and liberty. We got great faith in the ability of liberty to transform societies
column20: to convert a hostile world to a peaceful world.  My hope for America is a prosperous America
column21: a hopeful America and a safer world.  I want to thank you for listening tonight.  I'm asking for your vote.  God bless you.

safer world', 'I want to thank you for listening tonight', 'Im asking for your vote', 'God bless you']	['My fellow Americans
column2: as you heard from Bob Schieffer a moment ago
column3: America is being tested by division.'
column4: 'More than ever
column5: we need to be united as a country.'
column6: ""And
column7: like Franklin Roosevelt
column8: I don't care whether an idea is a Republican idea or a Democrat idea.""
column9: ""I just care whether it works for America and whether it's going to make us stronger.""
column10: 'These are dangerous times.'
column11: 'I believe I offer tested
column12: strong leadership that can calm the waters of the troubled world.'
column13: 'And I believe that we can together do things that are within the grasp of Americans.'
column14: 'We can lift our schools up.'
column15: ""We can create jobs that pay more than the jobs we're losing overseas.""
column16: 'We can have health care for all Americans.'
column17: 'We can further the cause of equality in our nation.'
column18: 'Let me just make it clear: I will never allow any country to have a veto over our security.'
column19: 'Just as I fought for our country as a young man
column20: with the same passion I will fight to defend this nation that I love.'
column22: with faith in God and with conviction in the mission of America
column23: I believe that we can reach higher.'
column24: 'I believe we can do better.'
column25: 'I think the greatest possibilities of our country
column26: our dreams and our hopes
column27: are out there just waiting for us to grab onto them.'
column28: 'And I ask you to embark on that journey with me.'
column29: 'I ask you for your trust.'
column30: 'I ask you for your help.'
column31: 'I ask you to allow me the privilege of leading this great nation of ours
column32: of helping us to be stronger here at home and to be respected again in the world and
column33: most of all
column34: to be safer forever.'
column35: 'Thank you.'
column36: 'Goodnight.'
column37: 'And God bless the United States of America.'
column38: ""In the Oval Office
column39: there's a painting by a friend of Laura and mine named -- by Tom Lee.""
column40: ""And it's a West Texas painting
column41: a painting of a mountain scene.""
column42: 'And he said this about it.'
column43: 'He said
column44: ""Sarah and I live on the east side of the mountain.'
column45: ""It's the sunrise side
column47: 'It\'s the side to see the day that is coming
column48: not to see the day that is gone. ""'
column49: ""I love the optimism in that painting
column50: because that's how I feel about America.""
column51: ""And we've been through a lot together during the last 3 3/4 years.""
column52: ""We've come through a recession
column53: a stock market decline
column54: an attack on our country.""
column56: because of the hard work of the American people and good policies
column57: this economy is growing.'
column58: ""Over the next four years
column59: we'll make sure the economy continues to grow.""
column60: ""We reformed our school system
column61: and now there's an achievement gap in America that's beginning to close.""
column62: ""Over the next four years
column63: we'll continue to insist on excellence in every classroom in America so that our children have a chance to realize the great promise of America.""
column64: ""Over the next four years
column65: we'll continue to work to make sure health care is available and affordable.""
column66: ""Over the next four years
column67: we'll continue to rally the armies of compassion
column68: to help heal the hurt that exists in some of our country's neighborhoods.""
column69: ""I'm optimistic that we'll win the war on terror
column70: but I understand it requires firm resolve and clear purpose.""
column71: 'We must never waver in the face of this enemy that -- these ideologues of hate.'
column72: ""And as we pursue the enemy wherever it exists
column73: we'll also spread freedom and liberty.""
column74: 'We got great faith in the ability of liberty to transform societies
column75: to convert a hostile world to a peaceful world.'
column76: 'My hope for America is a prosperous America
column77: a hopeful America and a safer world.'
column78: 'I want to thank you for listening tonight.'
column80: 'God bless you.']"	5098.92	5333.88	NOT_FOUND

column2: '13Oct'
column3: 2)	" Bob
column4: we relied upon a company out of England to provide about half of the flu vaccines for the United States citizen
column5: and it turned out that the vaccine they were producing was contaminated. And so we took the right action and didn't allow contaminated medicine into our country. We're working with Canada to hopefully -- that they'll produce a -- help us realize the vaccine necessary to make sure our citizens have got flu vaccinations during this upcoming season. My call to our fellow Americans is if you're healthy
column6: if you're younger
column7: don't get a flu shot this year. Help us prioritize those who need to get the flu shot
column8: the elderly and the young.  The CDC
column9: responsible for health in the United States
column10: is setting those priorities and is allocating the flu vaccine accordingly.  I haven't gotten a flu shot
column11: and I don't intend to because I want to make sure those who are most vulnerable get treated.  We have a problem with litigation in the United States of America. Vaccine manufacturers are worried about getting sued
column12: and therefore they have backed off from providing this kind of vaccine.  One of the reasons I'm such a strong believer in legal reform is so that people aren't afraid of producing a product that is necessary for the health of our citizens and then end up getting sued in a court of law.  But the best thing we can do now
column13: Bob
column14: given the circumstances with the company in England is for those of us who are younger and healthy
column15: don't get a flu shot.

column1: This really underscores the problem with the American health-care system. It's not working for the American family. And it's gotten worse under President Bush over the course of the last years. Five million Americans have lost their health insurance in this country. You've got about a million right here in Arizona
column2: just shy
column5: who have no health insurance at all. 82
column6: 000 Arizonians lost their health insurance under President Bush's watch. 223
column7: 000 kids in Arizona have no health insurance at all.  All across our country -- go to Ohio
column8: 1. 4 million Ohioans have no health insurance
column10: 000 of them lost it under President Bush; Wisconsin
column12: 000 Wisconsinites lost it under President Bush.  This president has turned his back on the wellness of America. And there is no system. In fact
column13: it's starting to fall apart not because of lawsuits -- though they are a problem
column14: and John Edwards and I are committed to fixing them -- but because of the larger issue that we don't cover Americans.  Children across our country don't have health care. We're the richest country on the face of the planet
column15: the only industrialized nation in the world not to do it.  I have a plan to cover all Americans. We're going to make it affordable and accessible. We're going to let everybody buy into the same health-care plan senators and congressmen give themselves.

column1: I would. Thank you. I want to remind people listening tonight that a plan is not a litany of complaints
column2: and a plan is not to lay out programs that you can't pay for.  He just said he wants everybody to be able to buy in to the same plan that senators and congressmen get. That costs the government $7
column3: 700 per family. If every family in America signed up
column4: like the senator suggested
column5: if would cost us $5 trillion over 10 years.  It's an empty promise. It's called bait and switch.

column2: it's not an empty promise. It's really interesting
column3: because the president used that very plan as a reason for seniors to accept his prescription drug plan. He said
column4: if it's good enough for the congressmen and senators to have choice
column5: seniors ought to have choice.  What we do is we have choice. I choose Blue Cross/Blue Shield. Other senators
column6: other congressmen choose other programs.  But the fact is
column7: we're going to help Americans be able to buy into it. Those that can afford it are going to buy in themselves. We're not giving this away for nothing.

We're working with Canada to hopefully -- that they'll produce a -- help us realize the vaccine necessary to make sure our citizens have got flu vaccinations during this upcoming season. My call to our fellow Americans is if you're healthy
column6: if you're younger
column7: don't get a flu shot this year. Help us prioritize those who need to get the flu shot

column13: Bob

column15: don't get a flu shot.

column1: This really underscores the problem with the American health-care system. It's not working for the American family. And it's gotten worse under President Bush over the course of the last years. Five million Americans have lost their health insurance in this country. You've got about a million right here in Arizona
column2: just shy
column5: who have no health insurance at all. 82
column6: 000 Arizonians lost their health insurance under President Bush's watch. 223
column7: 000 kids in Arizona have no health insurance at all.  All across our country -- go to Ohio
column8: 1. 4 million Ohioans have no health insurance
column10: 000 of them lost it under President Bush; Wisconsin
column12: 000 Wisconsinites lost it under President Bush.  This president has turned his back on the wellness of America. And there is no system. In fact
column13: it's starting to fall apart not because of lawsuits -- though they are a problem
column14: and John Edwards and I are committed to fixing them -- but because of the larger issue that we don't cover Americans.  Children across our country don't have health care. We're the richest country on the face of the planet
column15: the only industrialized nation in the world not to do it.  I have a plan to cover all Americans. We're going to make it affordable and accessible. We're going to let everybody buy into the same health-care plan senators and congressmen give themselves.

column2: '13Oct'
column3: 2)	" Bob
column4: we relied upon a company out of England to provide about half of the flu vaccines for the United States citizen
column5: and it turned out that the vaccine they were producing was contaminated. And so we took the right action and didn't allow contaminated medicine into our country. We're working with Canada to hopefully -- that they'll produce a -- help us realize the vaccine necessary to make sure our citizens have got flu vaccinations during this upcoming season. My call to our fellow Americans is if you're healthy
column6: if you're younger
column7: don't get a flu shot this year. Help us prioritize those who need to get the flu shot
column8: the elderly and the young.  The CDC
column9: responsible for health in the United States
column10: is setting those priorities and is allocating the flu vaccine accordingly.  I haven't gotten a flu shot
column11: and I don't intend to because I want to make sure those who are most vulnerable get treated.  We have a problem with litigation in the United States of America. Vaccine manufacturers are worried about getting sued
column12: and therefore they have backed off from providing this kind of vaccine.  One of the reasons I'm such a strong believer in legal reform is so that people aren't afraid of producing a product that is necessary for the health of our citizens and then end up getting sued in a court of law.  But the best thing we can do now
column13: Bob
column14: given the circumstances with the company in England is for those of us who are younger and healthy
column15: don't get a flu shot.

column1: This really underscores the problem with the American health-care system. It's not working for the American family. And it's gotten worse under President Bush over the course of the last years. Five million Americans have lost their health insurance in this country. You've got about a million right here in Arizona
column2: just shy
column5: who have no health insurance at all. 82
column6: 000 Arizonians lost their health insurance under President Bush's watch. 223
column7: 000 kids in Arizona have no health insurance at all.  All across our country -- go to Ohio
column8: 1. 4 million Ohioans have no health insurance
column10: 000 of them lost it under President Bush; Wisconsin
column12: 000 Wisconsinites lost it under President Bush.  This president has turned his back on the wellness of America. And there is no system. In fact
column13: it's starting to fall apart not because of lawsuits -- though they are a problem
column14: and John Edwards and I are committed to fixing them -- but because of the larger issue that we don't cover Americans.  Children across our country don't have health care. We're the richest country on the face of the planet
column15: the only industrialized nation in the world not to do it.  I have a plan to cover all Americans. We're going to make it affordable and accessible. We're going to let everybody buy into the same health-care plan senators and congressmen give themselves.

column1: I would. Thank you. I want to remind people listening tonight that a plan is not a litany of complaints
column2: and a plan is not to lay out programs that you can't pay for.  He just said he wants everybody to be able to buy in to the same plan that senators and congressmen get. That costs the government $7
column3: 700 per family. If every family in America signed up
column4: like the senator suggested
column5: if would cost us $5 trillion over 10 years.  It's an empty promise. It's called bait and switch.

column2: it's not an empty promise. It's really interesting
column3: because the president used that very plan as a reason for seniors to accept his prescription drug plan. He said
column4: if it's good enough for the congressmen and senators to have choice
column5: seniors ought to have choice.  What we do is we have choice. I choose Blue Cross/Blue Shield. Other senators
column6: other congressmen choose other programs.  But the fact is
column7: we're going to help Americans be able to buy into it. Those that can afford it are going to buy in themselves. We're not giving this away for nothing.

column13: it's starting to fall apart not because of lawsuits -- though they are a problem
column14: and John Edwards and I are committed to fixing them -- but because of the larger issue that we don't cover Americans.  Children across our country don't have health care. We're the richest country on the face of the planet
column15: the only industrialized nation in the world not to do it.  I have a plan to cover all Americans. We're going to make it affordable and accessible. We're going to let everybody buy into the same health-care plan senators and congressmen give themselves.

column1: I would. Thank you. I want to remind people listening tonight that a plan is not a litany of complaints
column2: and a plan is not to lay out programs that you can't pay for.  He just said he wants everybody to be able to buy in to the same plan that senators and congressmen get. That costs the government $7
column3: 700 per family. If every family in America signed up
column4: like the senator suggested
column5: if would cost us $5 trillion over 10 years.  It's an empty promise. It's called bait and switch.

column2: it's not an empty promise. It's really interesting
column3: because the president used that very plan as a reason for seniors to accept his prescription drug plan. He said
column4: if it's good enough for the congressmen and senators to have choice
column5: seniors ought to have choice.  What we do is we have choice. I choose Blue Cross/Blue Shield. Other senators
column6: other congressmen choose other programs.  But the fact is
column7: we're going to help Americans be able to buy into it. Those that can afford it are going to buy in themselves. We're not giving this away for nothing.

column3: 2)	" Bob
column4: we relied upon a company out of England to provide about half of the flu vaccines for the United States citizen
column5: and it turned out that the vaccine they were producing was contaminated. And so we took the right action and didn't allow contaminated medicine into our country. We're working with Canada to hopefully -- that they'll produce a -- help us realize the vaccine necessary to make sure our citizens have got flu vaccinations during this upcoming season. My call to our fellow Americans is if you're healthy
column6: if you're younger
column7: don't get a flu shot this year. Help us prioritize those who need to get the flu shot
column8: the elderly and the young.  The CDC
column9: responsible for health in the United States
column10: is setting those priorities and is allocating the flu vaccine accordingly.  I haven't gotten a flu shot
column11: and I don't intend to because I want to make sure those who are most vulnerable get treated.  We have a problem with litigation in the United States of America. Vaccine manufacturers are worried about getting sued
column12: and therefore they have backed off from providing this kind of vaccine.  One of the reasons I'm such a strong believer in legal reform is so that people aren't afraid of producing a product that is necessary for the health of our citizens and then end up getting sued in a court of law.  But the best thing we can do now
column13: Bob
column14: given the circumstances with the company in England is for those of us who are younger and healthy
column15: don't get a flu shot.

column4: ""And so we took the right action and didn't allow contaminated medicine into our country.""
column5: ""We're working with Canada to hopefully -- that they'll produce a -- help us realize the vaccine necessary to make sure our citizens have got flu vaccinations during this upcoming season.""

column16: 'We have a problem with litigation in the United States of America.'
column17: 'Vaccine manufacturers are worried about getting sued
column18: and therefore they have backed off from providing this kind of vaccine.'
column19: ""One of the reasons I'm such a strong believer in legal reform is so that people aren't afraid of producing a product that is necessary for the health of our citizens and then end up getting sued in a court of law.""
column20: ""But the best thing we can do now
column22: given the circumstances with the company in England is for those of us who are younger and healthy
column23: don't get a flu shot.""

column2: '13Oct'
column3: 2)	" Bob
column4: we relied upon a company out of England to provide about half of the flu vaccines for the United States citizen
column5: and it turned out that the vaccine they were producing was contaminated. And so we took the right action and didn't allow contaminated medicine into our country. We're working with Canada to hopefully -- that they'll produce a -- help us realize the vaccine necessary to make sure our citizens have got flu vaccinations during this upcoming season. My call to our fellow Americans is if you're healthy
column6: if you're younger
column7: don't get a flu shot this year. Help us prioritize those who need to get the flu shot
column8: the elderly and the young.  The CDC
column9: responsible for health in the United States
column10: is setting those priorities and is allocating the flu vaccine accordingly.  I haven't gotten a flu shot
column11: and I don't intend to because I want to make sure those who are most vulnerable get treated.  We have a problem with litigation in the United States of America. Vaccine manufacturers are worried about getting sued
column12: and therefore they have backed off from providing this kind of vaccine.  One of the reasons I'm such a strong believer in legal reform is so that people aren't afraid of producing a product that is necessary for the health of our citizens and then end up getting sued in a court of law.  But the best thing we can do now
column13: Bob
column14: given the circumstances with the company in England is for those of us who are younger and healthy
column15: don't get a flu shot.

column1: This really underscores the problem with the American health-care system. It's not working for the American family. And it's gotten worse under President Bush over the course of the last years. Five million Americans have lost their health insurance in this country. You've got about a million right here in Arizona
column2: just shy
column5: who have no health insurance at all. 82
column6: 000 Arizonians lost their health insurance under President Bush's watch. 223
column7: 000 kids in Arizona have no health insurance at all.  All across our country -- go to Ohio
column8: 1. 4 million Ohioans have no health insurance
column10: 000 of them lost it under President Bush; Wisconsin
column12: 000 Wisconsinites lost it under President Bush.  This president has turned his back on the wellness of America. And there is no system. In fact
column13: it's starting to fall apart not because of lawsuits -- though they are a problem
column14: and John Edwards and I are committed to fixing them -- but because of the larger issue that we don't cover Americans.  Children across our country don't have health care. We're the richest country on the face of the planet
column15: the only industrialized nation in the world not to do it.  I have a plan to cover all Americans. We're going to make it affordable and accessible. We're going to let everybody buy into the same health-care plan senators and congressmen give themselves.

column1: I would. Thank you. I want to remind people listening tonight that a plan is not a litany of complaints
column2: and a plan is not to lay out programs that you can't pay for.  He just said he wants everybody to be able to buy in to the same plan that senators and congressmen get. That costs the government $7
column3: 700 per family. If every family in America signed up
column4: like the senator suggested
column5: if would cost us $5 trillion over 10 years.  It's an empty promise. It's called bait and switch.

column2: it's not an empty promise. It's really interesting
column3: because the president used that very plan as a reason for seniors to accept his prescription drug plan. He said
column4: if it's good enough for the congressmen and senators to have choice
column5: seniors ought to have choice.  What we do is we have choice. I choose Blue Cross/Blue Shield. Other senators
column6: other congressmen choose other programs.  But the fact is
column7: we're going to help Americans be able to buy into it. Those that can afford it are going to buy in themselves. We're not giving this away for nothing.

We're working with Canada to hopefully -- that they'll produce a -- help us realize the vaccine necessary to make sure our citizens have got flu vaccinations during this upcoming season. My call to our fellow Americans is if you're healthy

column1: This really underscores the problem with the American health-care system. It's not working for the American family. And it's gotten worse under President Bush over the course of the last years. Five million Americans have lost their health insurance in this country. You've got about a million right here in Arizona
column2: just shy
column5: who have no health insurance at all. 82
column6: 000 Arizonians lost their health insurance under President Bush's watch. 223
column7: 000 kids in Arizona have no health insurance at all.  All across our country -- go to Ohio
column8: 1. 4 million Ohioans have no health insurance
column10: 000 of them lost it under President Bush; Wisconsin
column12: 000 Wisconsinites lost it under President Bush.  This president has turned his back on the wellness of America. And there is no system. In fact
column13: it's starting to fall apart not because of lawsuits -- though they are a problem
column14: and John Edwards and I are committed to fixing them -- but because of the larger issue that we don't cover Americans.  Children across our country don't have health care. We're the richest country on the face of the planet
column15: the only industrialized nation in the world not to do it.  I have a plan to cover all Americans. We're going to make it affordable and accessible. We're going to let everybody buy into the same health-care plan senators and congressmen give themselves.

column1: I would. Thank you. I want to remind people listening tonight that a plan is not a litany of complaints
column2: and a plan is not to lay out programs that you can't pay for.  He just said he wants everybody to be able to buy in to the same plan that senators and congressmen get. That costs the government $7
column3: 700 per family. If every family in America signed up
column4: like the senator suggested
column5: if would cost us $5 trillion over 10 years.  It's an empty promise. It's called bait and switch.

column2: it's not an empty promise. It's really interesting
column3: because the president used that very plan as a reason for seniors to accept his prescription drug plan. He said
column4: if it's good enough for the congressmen and senators to have choice
column5: seniors ought to have choice.  What we do is we have choice. I choose Blue Cross/Blue Shield. Other senators
column6: other congressmen choose other programs.  But the fact is
column7: we're going to help Americans be able to buy into it. Those that can afford it are going to buy in themselves. We're not giving this away for nothing.

column2: '13Oct'
column3: 3)	" I'll tell you exactly how I can do it: by reinstating what President Bush took away
column4: which is called pay as you go. During the 1990s
column5: we had pay-as-you-go rules. If you were going to pass something in the Congress
column6: you had to show where you are going to pay for it and how.  President Bush has taken -- he's the only president in history to do this. He's also the only president in 72 years to lose jobs -- 1. 6 million jobs lost. He's the only president to have incomes of families go down for the last three years; the only president to see exports go down; the only president to see the lowest level of business investment in our country as it is today.  Now
column7: I'm going to reverse that. I'm going to change that. We're going to restore the fiscal discipline we had in the 1990s.  Every plan that I have laid out -- my health-care plan
column8: my plan for education
column9: my plan for kids to be able to get better college loans -- I've shown exactly how I'm going to pay for those.  And we start -- we don't do it exclusively -- but we start by rolling back George Bush's unaffordable tax cut for the wealthiest people
column10: people earning more than $200
column11: 000 a year
column12: and we pass
column13: hopefully
column14: the McCain-Kerry Commission which identified some $60 billion that we can get.  We shut the loophole which has American workers actually subsidizing the loss of their own job. They just passed an expansion of that loophole in the last few days: $43 billion of giveaways
column15: including favors to the oil and gas industry and the people importing ceiling fans from China.  I'm going to stand up and fight for the American worker. And I am going to do it in a way that's fiscally sound. I show how I pay for the health care
column16: how we pay for the education.  I have a manufacturing jobs credit. We pay for it by shutting that loophole overseas. We raise the student loans. I pay for it by changing the relationship with the banks.  This president has never once vetoed one bill; the first president in a hundred years not to do that.

column2: his rhetoric doesn't match his record. He been a senator for 20 years. He voted to increase taxes 98 times. When they tried to reduce taxes
column3: he voted against that 127 times. He talks about being a fiscal conservative
column4: or fiscally sound
column5: but he voted over -- he voted 277 times to waive the budget caps
column6: which would have cost the taxpayers $4. 2 trillion.  He talks about PAYGO. I'll tell you what PAYGO means
column7: when you're a senator from Massachusetts
column8: when you're a colleague of Ted Kennedy
column9: pay go means: You pay
column10: and he goes ahead and spends.  He's proposed $2. 2 trillion of new spending
column11: and yet the so-called tax on the rich
column12: which is also a tax on many small-business owners in America
column13: raises $600 million by our account -- billion
column14: $800 billion by his account.  There is a tax gap. And guess who usually ends up filling the tax gap? The middle class.  I propose a detailed budget
column15: Bob. I sent up my budget man to the Congress
column16: and he says
column17: here's how we're going to reduce the deficit in half by five years. It requires pro-growth policies that grow our economy and fiscal sanity in the halls of Congress.

column2: '13Oct'
column3: 3)	" I'll tell you exactly how I can do it: by reinstating what President Bush took away
column4: which is called pay as you go. During the 1990s
column5: we had pay-as-you-go rules. If you were going to pass something in the Congress
column6: you had to show where you are going to pay for it and how.  President Bush has taken -- he's the only president in history to do this. He's also the only president in 72 years to lose jobs -- 1. 6 million jobs lost. He's the only president to have incomes of families go down for the last three years; the only president to see exports go down; the only president to see the lowest level of business investment in our country as it is today.  Now
column7: I'm going to reverse that. I'm going to change that. We're going to restore the fiscal discipline we had in the 1990s.  Every plan that I have laid out -- my health-care plan
column8: my plan for education
column9: my plan for kids to be able to get better college loans -- I've shown exactly how I'm going to pay for those.  And we start -- we don't do it exclusively -- but we start by rolling back George Bush's unaffordable tax cut for the wealthiest people
column10: people earning more than $200
column11: 000 a year
column12: and we pass
column13: hopefully
column14: the McCain-Kerry Commission which identified some $60 billion that we can get.  We shut the loophole which has American workers actually subsidizing the loss of their own job. They just passed an expansion of that loophole in the last few days: $43 billion of giveaways
column15: including favors to the oil and gas industry and the people importing ceiling fans from China.  I'm going to stand up and fight for the American worker. And I am going to do it in a way that's fiscally sound. I show how I pay for the health care
column16: how we pay for the education.  I have a manufacturing jobs credit. We pay for it by shutting that loophole overseas. We raise the student loans. I pay for it by changing the relationship with the banks.  This president has never once vetoed one bill; the first president in a hundred years not to do that.

column2: his rhetoric doesn't match his record. He been a senator for 20 years. He voted to increase taxes 98 times. When they tried to reduce taxes
column3: he voted against that 127 times. He talks about being a fiscal conservative
column4: or fiscally sound
column5: but he voted over -- he voted 277 times to waive the budget caps
column6: which would have cost the taxpayers $4. 2 trillion.  He talks about PAYGO. I'll tell you what PAYGO means
column7: when you're a senator from Massachusetts
column8: when you're a colleague of Ted Kennedy
column9: pay go means: You pay
column10: and he goes ahead and spends.  He's proposed $2. 2 trillion of new spending
column11: and yet the so-called tax on the rich
column12: which is also a tax on many small-business owners in America
column13: raises $600 million by our account -- billion
column14: $800 billion by his account.  There is a tax gap. And guess who usually ends up filling the tax gap? The middle class.  I propose a detailed budget
column15: Bob. I sent up my budget man to the Congress
column16: and he says
column17: here's how we're going to reduce the deficit in half by five years. It requires pro-growth policies that grow our economy and fiscal sanity in the halls of Congress.

column3: 3)	" I'll tell you exactly how I can do it: by reinstating what President Bush took away
column4: which is called pay as you go. During the 1990s
column5: we had pay-as-you-go rules. If you were going to pass something in the Congress
column6: you had to show where you are going to pay for it and how.  President Bush has taken -- he's the only president in history to do this. He's also the only president in 72 years to lose jobs -- 1. 6 million jobs lost. He's the only president to have incomes of families go down for the last three years; the only president to see exports go down; the only president to see the lowest level of business investment in our country as it is today.  Now
column7: I'm going to reverse that. I'm going to change that. We're going to restore the fiscal discipline we had in the 1990s.  Every plan that I have laid out -- my health-care plan
column8: my plan for education
column9: my plan for kids to be able to get better college loans -- I've shown exactly how I'm going to pay for those.  And we start -- we don't do it exclusively -- but we start by rolling back George Bush's unaffordable tax cut for the wealthiest people
column10: people earning more than $200
column11: 000 a year
column12: and we pass
column13: hopefully
column14: the McCain-Kerry Commission which identified some $60 billion that we can get.  We shut the loophole which has American workers actually subsidizing the loss of their own job. They just passed an expansion of that loophole in the last few days: $43 billion of giveaways
column15: including favors to the oil and gas industry and the people importing ceiling fans from China.  I'm going to stand up and fight for the American worker. And I am going to do it in a way that's fiscally sound. I show how I pay for the health care
column16: how we pay for the education.  I have a manufacturing jobs credit. We pay for it by shutting that loophole overseas. We raise the student loans. I pay for it by changing the relationship with the banks.  This president has never once vetoed one bill; the first president in a hundred years not to do that.

column2: his rhetoric doesn't match his record. He been a senator for 20 years. He voted to increase taxes 98 times. When they tried to reduce taxes
column3: he voted against that 127 times. He talks about being a fiscal conservative
column4: or fiscally sound
column5: but he voted over -- he voted 277 times to waive the budget caps
column6: which would have cost the taxpayers $4. 2 trillion.  He talks about PAYGO. I'll tell you what PAYGO means
column7: when you're a senator from Massachusetts
column8: when you're a colleague of Ted Kennedy
column9: pay go means: You pay
column10: and he goes ahead and spends.  He's proposed $2. 2 trillion of new spending
column11: and yet the so-called tax on the rich
column12: which is also a tax on many small-business owners in America
column13: raises $600 million by our account -- billion
column14: $800 billion by his account.  There is a tax gap. And guess who usually ends up filling the tax gap? The middle class.  I propose a detailed budget
column15: Bob. I sent up my budget man to the Congress
column16: and he says
column17: here's how we're going to reduce the deficit in half by five years. It requires pro-growth policies that grow our economy and fiscal sanity in the halls of Congress.

column2: '13Oct'
column3: 3)	" I'll tell you exactly how I can do it: by reinstating what President Bush took away
column4: which is called pay as you go. During the 1990s
column5: we had pay-as-you-go rules. If you were going to pass something in the Congress
column6: you had to show where you are going to pay for it and how.  President Bush has taken -- he's the only president in history to do this. He's also the only president in 72 years to lose jobs -- 1. 6 million jobs lost. He's the only president to have incomes of families go down for the last three years; the only president to see exports go down; the only president to see the lowest level of business investment in our country as it is today.  Now
column7: I'm going to reverse that. I'm going to change that. We're going to restore the fiscal discipline we had in the 1990s.  Every plan that I have laid out -- my health-care plan
column8: my plan for education
column9: my plan for kids to be able to get better college loans -- I've shown exactly how I'm going to pay for those.  And we start -- we don't do it exclusively -- but we start by rolling back George Bush's unaffordable tax cut for the wealthiest people
column10: people earning more than $200
column11: 000 a year
column12: and we pass
column13: hopefully
column14: the McCain-Kerry Commission which identified some $60 billion that we can get.  We shut the loophole which has American workers actually subsidizing the loss of their own job. They just passed an expansion of that loophole in the last few days: $43 billion of giveaways
column15: including favors to the oil and gas industry and the people importing ceiling fans from China.  I'm going to stand up and fight for the American worker. And I am going to do it in a way that's fiscally sound. I show how I pay for the health care
column16: how we pay for the education.  I have a manufacturing jobs credit. We pay for it by shutting that loophole overseas. We raise the student loans. I pay for it by changing the relationship with the banks.  This president has never once vetoed one bill; the first president in a hundred years not to do that.

column2: his rhetoric doesn't match his record. He been a senator for 20 years. He voted to increase taxes 98 times. When they tried to reduce taxes
column3: he voted against that 127 times. He talks about being a fiscal conservative
column4: or fiscally sound
column5: but he voted over -- he voted 277 times to waive the budget caps
column6: which would have cost the taxpayers $4. 2 trillion.  He talks about PAYGO. I'll tell you what PAYGO means
column7: when you're a senator from Massachusetts
column8: when you're a colleague of Ted Kennedy
column9: pay go means: You pay
column10: and he goes ahead and spends.  He's proposed $2. 2 trillion of new spending
column11: and yet the so-called tax on the rich
column12: which is also a tax on many small-business owners in America
column13: raises $600 million by our account -- billion
column14: $800 billion by his account.  There is a tax gap. And guess who usually ends up filling the tax gap? The middle class.  I propose a detailed budget
column15: Bob. I sent up my budget man to the Congress
column16: and he says
column17: here's how we're going to reduce the deficit in half by five years. It requires pro-growth policies that grow our economy and fiscal sanity in the halls of Congress.
