column5: I don't know. I just don't know. I do know that we have a choice to make in America and that is to treat people with tolerance and respect and dignity. It's important that we do that. And I also know in a free society people
column6: consenting adults can live the way they want to live.  And that's to be honored.  But as we respect someone's rights
column7: and as we profess tolerance
column8: we shouldn't change -- or have to change -- our basic views on the sanctity of marriage. I believe in the sanctity of marriage. I think it's very important that we protect marriage as an institution
column9: between a man and a woman.  I proposed a constitutional amendment. The reason I did so was because I was worried that activist judges are actually defining the definition of marriage
column10: and the surest way to protect marriage between a man and woman is to amend the Constitution.  It has also the benefit of allowing citizens to participate in the process. After all
column11: when you amend the Constitution
column12: state legislatures must participate in the ratification of the Constitution.  I'm deeply concerned that judges are making those decisions and not the citizenry of the United States. You know
column13: Congress passed a law called DOMA
column14: the Defense of Marriage Act.  My opponent was against it. It basically protected states from the action of one state to another. It also defined marriage as between a man and woman.  But I'm concerned that that will get overturned. And if it gets overturned
column15: then we'll end up with marriage being defined by courts
column16: and I don't think that's in our nation's interests.

column2: Bob. And I think if you were to talk to Dick Cheney's daughter
column3: who is a lesbian
column4: she would tell you that she's being who she was
column5: she's being who she was born as. I think if you talk to anybody
column6: it's not choice. I've met people who struggled with this for years
column7: people who were in a marriage because they were living a sort of convention
column8: and they struggled with it.  And I've met wives who are supportive of their husbands or vice versa when they finally sort of broke out and allowed themselves to live who they were
column9: who they felt God had made them.  I think we have to respect that.  The president and I share the belief that marriage is between a man and a woman. I believe that. I believe marriage is between a man and a woman.  But I also believe that because we are the United States of America
column10: we're a country with a great
column11: unbelievable Constitution
column12: with rights that we afford people
column13: that you can't discriminate in the workplace. You can't discriminate in the rights that you afford people.  You can't disallow someone the right to visit their partner in a hospital. You have to allow people to transfer property
column14: which is why I'm for partnership rights and so forth.  Now
column15: with respect to DOMA and the marriage laws
column16: the states have always been able to manage those laws. And they're proving today
column17: every state
column18: that they can manage them adequately.

column1: I respect their views. I completely respect their views. I am a Catholic. And I grew up learning how to respect those views. But I disagree with them
column2: as do many. I believe that I can't legislate or transfer to another American citizen my article of faith. What is an article of faith for me is not something that I can legislate on somebody who doesn't share that article of faith.  I believe that choice is a woman's choice. It's between a woman
column3: God and her doctor. And that's why I support that.  Now
column4: I will not allow somebody to come in and change Roe v. Wade.  The president has never said whether or not he would do that. But we know from the people he's tried to appoint to the court he wants to.  I will not. I will defend the right of Roe v. Wade.  Now
column5: with respect to religion
column6: you know
column7: as I said
column8: I grew up a Catholic. I was an altar boy. I know that throughout my life this has made a difference to me.  And as President Kennedy said when he ran for president
column9: he said
column10: ""I'm not running to be a Catholic president. I'm running to be a president who happens to be Catholic. ""  My faith affects everything that I do
column11: in truth. There's a great passage of the Bible that says
column12: ""What does it mean
column13: my brother
column14: to say you have faith if there are no deeds? Faith without works is dead. ""  And I think that everything you do in public life has to be guided by your faith
column15: affected by your faith
column16: but without transferring it in any official way to other people.  That's why I fight against poverty. That's why I fight to clean up the environment and protect this earth.  That's why I fight for equality and justice. All of those things come out of that fundamental teaching and belief of faith.  But I know this
column17: that President Kennedy in his inaugural address told all of us that here on Earth
column18: God's work must truly be our own. And that's what we have to -- I think that's the test of public service.

column1: I think it's important to promote a culture of life. I think a hospitable society is a society where every being counts and every person matters. I believe the ideal world is one in which every child is protected in law and welcomed to life. I understand there's great differences on this issue of abortion
column2: but I believe reasonable people can come together and put good law in place that will help reduce the number of abortions. Take
column3: for example
column4: the ban on partial birth abortion. It's a brutal practice. People from both political parties came together in the halls of Congress and voted overwhelmingly to ban that practice. It made a lot of sense. My opponent
column5: in that he's out of the mainstream
column6: voted against that law.  What I'm saying is
column7: is that as we promote life and promote a culture of life
column8: surely there are ways we can work together to reduce the number of abortions: continue to promote adoption laws -- it's a great alternative to abortion -- continue to fund and promote maternity group homes; I will continue to promote abstinence programs.  The last debate
column9: my opponent said his wife was involved with those programs. That's great. I appreciate that very much. All of us ought to be involved with programs that provide a viable alternative to abortion.

column2: '13Oct'
column3: 6)	" Gosh
column4: I sure hope it's not the administration. There's a -- no
column5: look
column6: there's a systemic problem. Health-care costs are on the rise because the consumers are not involved in the decision-making process. Most health-care costs are covered by third parties. And therefore
column7: the actual user of health care is not the purchaser of health care. And there's no market forces involved with health care.  It's one of the reasons I'm a strong believer in what they call health savings accounts. These are accounts that allow somebody to buy a low-premium
column8: high-deductible catastrophic plan and couple it with tax-free savings. Businesses can contribute
column9: employees can contribute on a contractual basis. But this is a way to make sure people are actually involved with the decision-making process on health care.  Secondly
column10: I do believe the lawsuits -- I don't believe
column11: I know -- that the lawsuits are causing health-care costs to rise in America. That's why I'm such a strong believer in medical liability reform.  In the last debate
column12: my opponent said those lawsuits only caused the cost to go up by 1 percent. Well
column13: he didn't include the defensive practice of medicine that costs the federal government some $28 billion a year and costs our society between $60 billion and $100 billion a year.  Thirdly
column14: one of the reasons why there's still high cost in medicine is because this is -- they don't use any information technology. It's like if you looked at the -- it's the equivalent of the buggy and horse days
column15: compared to other industries here in America.  And so
column16: we've got to introduce high technology into health care. We're beginning to do it. We're changing the language. We want there to be electronic medical records to cut down on error
column17: as well as reduce cost.  People tell me that when the health-care field is fully integrated with information technology
column18: it'll wring some 20 percent of the cost out of the system.  And finally
column19: moving generic drugs to the market quicker.  And so
column20: those are four ways to help control the costs in health care.

column1: The reason health-care costs are getting higher
column2: one of the principal reasons is that this administration has stood in the way of common-sense efforts that would have reduced the costs. Let me give you a prime example. In the Senate we passed the right of Americans to import drugs from Canada. But the president and his friends took it out in the House
column3: and now you don't have that right. The president blocked you from the right to have less expensive drugs from Canada.  We also wanted Medicare to be able to negotiate bulk purchasing. The VA does that. The VA provides lower-cost drugs to our veterans. We could have done that in Medicare.  Medicare is paid for by the American taxpayer. Medicare belongs to you. Medicare is for seniors
column4: who many of them are on fixed income
column5: to lift them out of poverty.  But rather than help you
column6: the taxpayer
column7: have lower cost
column8: rather than help seniors have less expensive drugs
column9: the president made it illegal -- illegal -- for Medicare to actually go out and bargain for lower prices.  Result: $139 billion windfall profit to the drug companies coming out of your pockets. That's a large part of your 17 percent increase in Medicare premiums.  When I'm president
column10: I'm sending that back to Congress and we're going to get a real prescription drug benefit.  Now
column11: we also have people sicker because they don't have health insurance. So whether it's diabetes or cancer
column12: they come to hospitals later and it costs America more.  We got to have health care for all Americans.

column2: since he talked about the Medicare plan
column3: has he been in the United States Senate for 20 years? He has no record on reforming of health care. No record at all. He introduced some 300 bills and he's passed five.  No record of leadership.  I came to Washington to solve problems. I was deeply concerned about seniors having to choose between prescription drugs and food. And so I led. And in 2006
column4: our seniors will get a prescription drug coverage in Medicare.

column2: the president is misleading America. I've actually passed 56 individual bills that I've personally written and
column3: in addition to that
column4: and not always under my name
column5: there is amendments on certain bills. But more importantly
column6: with respect to the question of no record
column7: I helped write -- I did write
column8: I was one of the original authors of the early childhood health care and the expansion of health care that we did in the middle of the 1990s. And I'm very proud of that.  So the president's wrong.

column2: '13Oct'
column3: 6)	" Gosh
column4: I sure hope it's not the administration. There's a -- no
column5: look
column6: there's a systemic problem. Health-care costs are on the rise because the consumers are not involved in the decision-making process. Most health-care costs are covered by third parties. And therefore
column7: the actual user of health care is not the purchaser of health care. And there's no market forces involved with health care.  It's one of the reasons I'm a strong believer in what they call health savings accounts. These are accounts that allow somebody to buy a low-premium
column8: high-deductible catastrophic plan and couple it with tax-free savings. Businesses can contribute
column9: employees can contribute on a contractual basis. But this is a way to make sure people are actually involved with the decision-making process on health care.  Secondly
column10: I do believe the lawsuits -- I don't believe
column11: I know -- that the lawsuits are causing health-care costs to rise in America. That's why I'm such a strong believer in medical liability reform.  In the last debate
column12: my opponent said those lawsuits only caused the cost to go up by 1 percent. Well
column13: he didn't include the defensive practice of medicine that costs the federal government some $28 billion a year and costs our society between $60 billion and $100 billion a year.  Thirdly
column14: one of the reasons why there's still high cost in medicine is because this is -- they don't use any information technology. It's like if you looked at the -- it's the equivalent of the buggy and horse days
column15: compared to other industries here in America.  And so
column16: we've got to introduce high technology into health care. We're beginning to do it. We're changing the language. We want there to be electronic medical records to cut down on error
column17: as well as reduce cost.  People tell me that when the health-care field is fully integrated with information technology
column18: it'll wring some 20 percent of the cost out of the system.  And finally
column19: moving generic drugs to the market quicker.  And so
column20: those are four ways to help control the costs in health care.

column1: The reason health-care costs are getting higher
column2: one of the principal reasons is that this administration has stood in the way of common-sense efforts that would have reduced the costs. Let me give you a prime example. In the Senate we passed the right of Americans to import drugs from Canada. But the president and his friends took it out in the House
column3: and now you don't have that right. The president blocked you from the right to have less expensive drugs from Canada.  We also wanted Medicare to be able to negotiate bulk purchasing. The VA does that. The VA provides lower-cost drugs to our veterans. We could have done that in Medicare.  Medicare is paid for by the American taxpayer. Medicare belongs to you. Medicare is for seniors
column4: who many of them are on fixed income
column5: to lift them out of poverty.  But rather than help you
column6: the taxpayer
column7: have lower cost
column8: rather than help seniors have less expensive drugs
column9: the president made it illegal -- illegal -- for Medicare to actually go out and bargain for lower prices.  Result: $139 billion windfall profit to the drug companies coming out of your pockets. That's a large part of your 17 percent increase in Medicare premiums.  When I'm president
column10: I'm sending that back to Congress and we're going to get a real prescription drug benefit.  Now
column11: we also have people sicker because they don't have health insurance. So whether it's diabetes or cancer
column12: they come to hospitals later and it costs America more.  We got to have health care for all Americans.

column2: since he talked about the Medicare plan
column3: has he been in the United States Senate for 20 years? He has no record on reforming of health care. No record at all. He introduced some 300 bills and he's passed five.  No record of leadership.  I came to Washington to solve problems. I was deeply concerned about seniors having to choose between prescription drugs and food. And so I led. And in 2006
column4: our seniors will get a prescription drug coverage in Medicare.

column2: the president is misleading America. I've actually passed 56 individual bills that I've personally written and
column3: in addition to that
column4: and not always under my name
column5: there is amendments on certain bills. But more importantly
column6: with respect to the question of no record
column7: I helped write -- I did write
column8: I was one of the original authors of the early childhood health care and the expansion of health care that we did in the middle of the 1990s. And I'm very proud of that.  So the president's wrong.

column2: '13Oct'
column3: 6)	" Gosh
column4: I sure hope it's not the administration. There's a -- no
column5: look
column6: there's a systemic problem. Health-care costs are on the rise because the consumers are not involved in the decision-making process. Most health-care costs are covered by third parties. And therefore
column7: the actual user of health care is not the purchaser of health care. And there's no market forces involved with health care.  It's one of the reasons I'm a strong believer in what they call health savings accounts. These are accounts that allow somebody to buy a low-premium
column8: high-deductible catastrophic plan and couple it with tax-free savings. Businesses can contribute
column9: employees can contribute on a contractual basis. But this is a way to make sure people are actually involved with the decision-making process on health care.  Secondly
column10: I do believe the lawsuits -- I don't believe
column11: I know -- that the lawsuits are causing health-care costs to rise in America. That's why I'm such a strong believer in medical liability reform.  In the last debate
column12: my opponent said those lawsuits only caused the cost to go up by 1 percent. Well
column13: he didn't include the defensive practice of medicine that costs the federal government some $28 billion a year and costs our society between $60 billion and $100 billion a year.  Thirdly
column14: one of the reasons why there's still high cost in medicine is because this is -- they don't use any information technology. It's like if you looked at the -- it's the equivalent of the buggy and horse days
column15: compared to other industries here in America.  And so
column16: we've got to introduce high technology into health care. We're beginning to do it. We're changing the language. We want there to be electronic medical records to cut down on error
column17: as well as reduce cost.  People tell me that when the health-care field is fully integrated with information technology
column18: it'll wring some 20 percent of the cost out of the system.  And finally
column19: moving generic drugs to the market quicker.  And so
column20: those are four ways to help control the costs in health care.

column1: The reason health-care costs are getting higher
column2: one of the principal reasons is that this administration has stood in the way of common-sense efforts that would have reduced the costs. Let me give you a prime example. In the Senate we passed the right of Americans to import drugs from Canada. But the president and his friends took it out in the House
column3: and now you don't have that right. The president blocked you from the right to have less expensive drugs from Canada.  We also wanted Medicare to be able to negotiate bulk purchasing. The VA does that. The VA provides lower-cost drugs to our veterans. We could have done that in Medicare.  Medicare is paid for by the American taxpayer. Medicare belongs to you. Medicare is for seniors
column4: who many of them are on fixed income
column5: to lift them out of poverty.  But rather than help you
column6: the taxpayer
column7: have lower cost
column8: rather than help seniors have less expensive drugs
column9: the president made it illegal -- illegal -- for Medicare to actually go out and bargain for lower prices.  Result: $139 billion windfall profit to the drug companies coming out of your pockets. That's a large part of your 17 percent increase in Medicare premiums.  When I'm president
column10: I'm sending that back to Congress and we're going to get a real prescription drug benefit.  Now
column11: we also have people sicker because they don't have health insurance. So whether it's diabetes or cancer
column12: they come to hospitals later and it costs America more.  We got to have health care for all Americans.

column2: since he talked about the Medicare plan
column3: has he been in the United States Senate for 20 years? He has no record on reforming of health care. No record at all. He introduced some 300 bills and he's passed five.  No record of leadership.  I came to Washington to solve problems. I was deeply concerned about seniors having to choose between prescription drugs and food. And so I led. And in 2006
column4: our seniors will get a prescription drug coverage in Medicare.

column2: the president is misleading America. I've actually passed 56 individual bills that I've personally written and
column3: in addition to that
column4: and not always under my name
column5: there is amendments on certain bills. But more importantly
column6: with respect to the question of no record
column7: I helped write -- I did write
column8: I was one of the original authors of the early childhood health care and the expansion of health care that we did in the middle of the 1990s. And I'm very proud of that.  So the president's wrong.

column2: '13Oct'
column3: 6)	" Gosh
column4: I sure hope it's not the administration. There's a -- no
column5: look
column6: there's a systemic problem. Health-care costs are on the rise because the consumers are not involved in the decision-making process. Most health-care costs are covered by third parties. And therefore
column7: the actual user of health care is not the purchaser of health care. And there's no market forces involved with health care.  It's one of the reasons I'm a strong believer in what they call health savings accounts. These are accounts that allow somebody to buy a low-premium
column8: high-deductible catastrophic plan and couple it with tax-free savings. Businesses can contribute
column9: employees can contribute on a contractual basis. But this is a way to make sure people are actually involved with the decision-making process on health care.  Secondly
column10: I do believe the lawsuits -- I don't believe
column11: I know -- that the lawsuits are causing health-care costs to rise in America. That's why I'm such a strong believer in medical liability reform.  In the last debate
column12: my opponent said those lawsuits only caused the cost to go up by 1 percent. Well
column13: he didn't include the defensive practice of medicine that costs the federal government some $28 billion a year and costs our society between $60 billion and $100 billion a year.  Thirdly
column14: one of the reasons why there's still high cost in medicine is because this is -- they don't use any information technology. It's like if you looked at the -- it's the equivalent of the buggy and horse days
column15: compared to other industries here in America.  And so
column16: we've got to introduce high technology into health care. We're beginning to do it. We're changing the language. We want there to be electronic medical records to cut down on error
column17: as well as reduce cost.  People tell me that when the health-care field is fully integrated with information technology
column18: it'll wring some 20 percent of the cost out of the system.  And finally
column19: moving generic drugs to the market quicker.  And so
column20: those are four ways to help control the costs in health care.

column1: The reason health-care costs are getting higher
column2: one of the principal reasons is that this administration has stood in the way of common-sense efforts that would have reduced the costs. Let me give you a prime example. In the Senate we passed the right of Americans to import drugs from Canada. But the president and his friends took it out in the House
column3: and now you don't have that right. The president blocked you from the right to have less expensive drugs from Canada.  We also wanted Medicare to be able to negotiate bulk purchasing. The VA does that. The VA provides lower-cost drugs to our veterans. We could have done that in Medicare.  Medicare is paid for by the American taxpayer. Medicare belongs to you. Medicare is for seniors
column4: who many of them are on fixed income
column5: to lift them out of poverty.  But rather than help you
column6: the taxpayer
column7: have lower cost
column8: rather than help seniors have less expensive drugs
column9: the president made it illegal -- illegal -- for Medicare to actually go out and bargain for lower prices.  Result: $139 billion windfall profit to the drug companies coming out of your pockets. That's a large part of your 17 percent increase in Medicare premiums.  When I'm president
column10: I'm sending that back to Congress and we're going to get a real prescription drug benefit.  Now
column11: we also have people sicker because they don't have health insurance. So whether it's diabetes or cancer
column12: they come to hospitals later and it costs America more.  We got to have health care for all Americans.

column2: since he talked about the Medicare plan
column3: has he been in the United States Senate for 20 years? He has no record on reforming of health care. No record at all. He introduced some 300 bills and he's passed five.  No record of leadership.  I came to Washington to solve problems. I was deeply concerned about seniors having to choose between prescription drugs and food. And so I led. And in 2006
column4: our seniors will get a prescription drug coverage in Medicare.

column2: the president is misleading America. I've actually passed 56 individual bills that I've personally written and
column3: in addition to that
column4: and not always under my name
column5: there is amendments on certain bills. But more importantly
column6: with respect to the question of no record
column7: I helped write -- I did write
column8: I was one of the original authors of the early childhood health care and the expansion of health care that we did in the middle of the 1990s. And I'm very proud of that.  So the president's wrong.

column2: '13Oct'
column3: 7)	" Well
column4: two leading national news networks have both said the president's characterization of my health-care plan is incorrect. One called it fiction. The other called it untrue. The fact is that my health-care plan
column5: America
column6: is very simple. It gives you the choice. I don't force you to do anything. It's not a government plan. The government doesn't require you to do anything. You choose your doctor. You choose your plan.  If you don't want to take the offer of the plan that I want to put forward
column7: you don't have do. You can keep what you have today
column8: keep a high deductible
column9: keep high premiums
column10: keep a high co-pay
column11: keep low benefits.  But I got a better plan. And I don't think a lot of people are going to want to keep what they have today.  Here's what I do: We take over Medicaid children from the states so that every child in America is covered. And in exchange
column12: if the states want to -- they're not forced to
column13: they can choose to -- they cover individuals up to 300 percent of poverty. It's their choice.  I think they'll choose it
column14: because it's a net plus of $5 billion to them.  We allow you -- if you choose to
column15: you don't have to -- but we give you broader competition to allow you to buy into the same health care plan that senators and congressmen give themselves. If it's good enough for us
column16: it's good enough for every American. I believe that your health care is just as important as any politician in Washington
column17: D. C.  You want to buy into it
column18: you can. We give you broader competition. That helps lower prices.  In addition to that
column19: we're going to allow people 55 to 64 to buy into Medicare early. And most importantly
column20: we give small business a 50 percent tax credit so that after we lower the costs of health care
column22: whether they're self-employed or a small business
column23: a lower cost to be able to cover their employees.  Now
column24: what happens is when you begin to get people covered like that -- for instance in diabetes
column25: if you diagnose diabetes early
column26: you could save $50 billion in the health care system of America by avoiding surgery and dialysis. It works. And I'm going to offer it to America.

column2: I'm not so sure it's credible to quote leading news organizations about -- oh
column3: never mind. Anyway
column4: let me quote the Lewin report. The Lewin report is a group of folks who are not politically affiliated. They analyzed the senator's plan. It cost $1.2 trillion. The Lewin report accurately noted that there are going to be 20 million people
column5: over 20 million people added to government-controlled health care. It would be the largest increase in government health care ever.  If you raise the Medicaid to 300 percent
column6: it provides an incentive for small businesses not to provide private insurance to their employees. Why should they insure somebody when the government's going to insure it for them?  It's estimated that 8 million people will go from private insurance to government insurance.  We have a fundamental difference of opinion. I think government- run health will lead to poor-quality health
column7: will lead to rationing
column8: will lead to less choice.  Once a health-care program ends up in a line item in the federal government budget
column9: it leads to more controls.  And just look at other countries that have tried to have federally controlled health care. They have poor-quality health care.  Our health-care system is the envy of the world because we believe in making sure that the decisions are made by doctors and patients
column10: not by officials in the nation's capital.

column1: The president just said that government-run health care results in poor quality. Now
column2: maybe that explains why he hasn't fully funded the VA and the VA hospital is having trouble and veterans are complaining. Maybe that explains why Medicare patients are complaining about being pushed off of Medicare. He doesn't adequately fund it.  But let me just say to America: I am not proposing a government-run program. That's not what I have. I have Blue Cross/Blue Shield. Senators and congressmen have a wide choice. Americans ought to have it too.

column1: Talk about the VA: We've increased VA funding by $22 billion in the four years since I've been president. That's twice the amount that my predecessor increased VA funding. Of course we're meeting our obligation to our veterans
column2: and the veterans know that.  We're expanding veterans' health care throughout the country. We're aligning facilities where the veterans live now. Veterans are getting very good health care under my administration
column3: and they will continue to do so during the next four years.

column2: '13Oct'
column3: 7)	" Well
column4: two leading national news networks have both said the president's characterization of my health-care plan is incorrect. One called it fiction. The other called it untrue. The fact is that my health-care plan
column5: America
column6: is very simple. It gives you the choice. I don't force you to do anything. It's not a government plan. The government doesn't require you to do anything. You choose your doctor. You choose your plan.  If you don't want to take the offer of the plan that I want to put forward
column7: you don't have do. You can keep what you have today
column8: keep a high deductible
column9: keep high premiums
column10: keep a high co-pay
column11: keep low benefits.  But I got a better plan. And I don't think a lot of people are going to want to keep what they have today.  Here's what I do: We take over Medicaid children from the states so that every child in America is covered. And in exchange
column12: if the states want to -- they're not forced to
column13: they can choose to -- they cover individuals up to 300 percent of poverty. It's their choice.  I think they'll choose it
column14: because it's a net plus of $5 billion to them.  We allow you -- if you choose to
column15: you don't have to -- but we give you broader competition to allow you to buy into the same health care plan that senators and congressmen give themselves. If it's good enough for us
column16: it's good enough for every American. I believe that your health care is just as important as any politician in Washington
column17: D. C.  You want to buy into it
column18: you can. We give you broader competition. That helps lower prices.  In addition to that
column19: we're going to allow people 55 to 64 to buy into Medicare early. And most importantly
column20: we give small business a 50 percent tax credit so that after we lower the costs of health care
column22: whether they're self-employed or a small business
column23: a lower cost to be able to cover their employees.  Now
column24: what happens is when you begin to get people covered like that -- for instance in diabetes
column25: if you diagnose diabetes early
column26: you could save $50 billion in the health care system of America by avoiding surgery and dialysis. It works. And I'm going to offer it to America.

column2: I'm not so sure it's credible to quote leading news organizations about -- oh
column3: never mind. Anyway
column4: let me quote the Lewin report. The Lewin report is a group of folks who are not politically affiliated. They analyzed the senator's plan. It cost $1.2 trillion. The Lewin report accurately noted that there are going to be 20 million people
column5: over 20 million people added to government-controlled health care. It would be the largest increase in government health care ever.  If you raise the Medicaid to 300 percent
column6: it provides an incentive for small businesses not to provide private insurance to their employees. Why should they insure somebody when the government's going to insure it for them?  It's estimated that 8 million people will go from private insurance to government insurance.  We have a fundamental difference of opinion. I think government- run health will lead to poor-quality health
column7: will lead to rationing
column8: will lead to less choice.  Once a health-care program ends up in a line item in the federal government budget
column9: it leads to more controls.  And just look at other countries that have tried to have federally controlled health care. They have poor-quality health care.  Our health-care system is the envy of the world because we believe in making sure that the decisions are made by doctors and patients
column10: not by officials in the nation's capital.

column1: The president just said that government-run health care results in poor quality. Now
column2: maybe that explains why he hasn't fully funded the VA and the VA hospital is having trouble and veterans are complaining. Maybe that explains why Medicare patients are complaining about being pushed off of Medicare. He doesn't adequately fund it.  But let me just say to America: I am not proposing a government-run program. That's not what I have. I have Blue Cross/Blue Shield. Senators and congressmen have a wide choice. Americans ought to have it too.

column1: Talk about the VA: We've increased VA funding by $22 billion in the four years since I've been president. That's twice the amount that my predecessor increased VA funding. Of course we're meeting our obligation to our veterans
column2: and the veterans know that.  We're expanding veterans' health care throughout the country. We're aligning facilities where the veterans live now. Veterans are getting very good health care under my administration
column3: and they will continue to do so during the next four years.

column2: '13Oct'
column3: 7)	" Well
column4: two leading national news networks have both said the president's characterization of my health-care plan is incorrect. One called it fiction. The other called it untrue. The fact is that my health-care plan
column5: America
column6: is very simple. It gives you the choice. I don't force you to do anything. It's not a government plan. The government doesn't require you to do anything. You choose your doctor. You choose your plan.  If you don't want to take the offer of the plan that I want to put forward
column7: you don't have do. You can keep what you have today
column8: keep a high deductible
column9: keep high premiums
column10: keep a high co-pay
column11: keep low benefits.  But I got a better plan. And I don't think a lot of people are going to want to keep what they have today.  Here's what I do: We take over Medicaid children from the states so that every child in America is covered. And in exchange
column12: if the states want to -- they're not forced to
column13: they can choose to -- they cover individuals up to 300 percent of poverty. It's their choice.  I think they'll choose it
column14: because it's a net plus of $5 billion to them.  We allow you -- if you choose to
column15: you don't have to -- but we give you broader competition to allow you to buy into the same health care plan that senators and congressmen give themselves. If it's good enough for us
column16: it's good enough for every American. I believe that your health care is just as important as any politician in Washington
column17: D. C.  You want to buy into it
column18: you can. We give you broader competition. That helps lower prices.  In addition to that
column19: we're going to allow people 55 to 64 to buy into Medicare early. And most importantly
column20: we give small business a 50 percent tax credit so that after we lower the costs of health care
column22: whether they're self-employed or a small business
column23: a lower cost to be able to cover their employees.  Now
column24: what happens is when you begin to get people covered like that -- for instance in diabetes
column25: if you diagnose diabetes early
column26: you could save $50 billion in the health care system of America by avoiding surgery and dialysis. It works. And I'm going to offer it to America.

column2: I'm not so sure it's credible to quote leading news organizations about -- oh
column3: never mind. Anyway
column4: let me quote the Lewin report. The Lewin report is a group of folks who are not politically affiliated. They analyzed the senator's plan. It cost $1.2 trillion. The Lewin report accurately noted that there are going to be 20 million people
column5: over 20 million people added to government-controlled health care. It would be the largest increase in government health care ever.  If you raise the Medicaid to 300 percent
column6: it provides an incentive for small businesses not to provide private insurance to their employees. Why should they insure somebody when the government's going to insure it for them?  It's estimated that 8 million people will go from private insurance to government insurance.  We have a fundamental difference of opinion. I think government- run health will lead to poor-quality health
column7: will lead to rationing
column8: will lead to less choice.  Once a health-care program ends up in a line item in the federal government budget
column9: it leads to more controls.  And just look at other countries that have tried to have federally controlled health care. They have poor-quality health care.  Our health-care system is the envy of the world because we believe in making sure that the decisions are made by doctors and patients
column10: not by officials in the nation's capital.

column1: The president just said that government-run health care results in poor quality. Now
column2: maybe that explains why he hasn't fully funded the VA and the VA hospital is having trouble and veterans are complaining. Maybe that explains why Medicare patients are complaining about being pushed off of Medicare. He doesn't adequately fund it.  But let me just say to America: I am not proposing a government-run program. That's not what I have. I have Blue Cross/Blue Shield. Senators and congressmen have a wide choice. Americans ought to have it too.

column1: Talk about the VA: We've increased VA funding by $22 billion in the four years since I've been president. That's twice the amount that my predecessor increased VA funding. Of course we're meeting our obligation to our veterans
column2: and the veterans know that.  We're expanding veterans' health care throughout the country. We're aligning facilities where the veterans live now. Veterans are getting very good health care under my administration
column3: and they will continue to do so during the next four years.

column2: '13Oct'
column3: 7)	" Well
column4: two leading national news networks have both said the president's characterization of my health-care plan is incorrect. One called it fiction. The other called it untrue. The fact is that my health-care plan
column5: America
column6: is very simple. It gives you the choice. I don't force you to do anything. It's not a government plan. The government doesn't require you to do anything. You choose your doctor. You choose your plan.  If you don't want to take the offer of the plan that I want to put forward
column7: you don't have do. You can keep what you have today
column8: keep a high deductible
column9: keep high premiums
column10: keep a high co-pay
column11: keep low benefits.  But I got a better plan. And I don't think a lot of people are going to want to keep what they have today.  Here's what I do: We take over Medicaid children from the states so that every child in America is covered. And in exchange
column12: if the states want to -- they're not forced to
column13: they can choose to -- they cover individuals up to 300 percent of poverty. It's their choice.  I think they'll choose it
column14: because it's a net plus of $5 billion to them.  We allow you -- if you choose to
column15: you don't have to -- but we give you broader competition to allow you to buy into the same health care plan that senators and congressmen give themselves. If it's good enough for us
column16: it's good enough for every American. I believe that your health care is just as important as any politician in Washington
column17: D. C.  You want to buy into it
column18: you can. We give you broader competition. That helps lower prices.  In addition to that
column19: we're going to allow people 55 to 64 to buy into Medicare early. And most importantly
column20: we give small business a 50 percent tax credit so that after we lower the costs of health care
column22: whether they're self-employed or a small business
column23: a lower cost to be able to cover their employees.  Now
column24: what happens is when you begin to get people covered like that -- for instance in diabetes
column25: if you diagnose diabetes early
column26: you could save $50 billion in the health care system of America by avoiding surgery and dialysis. It works. And I'm going to offer it to America.

column2: I'm not so sure it's credible to quote leading news organizations about -- oh
column3: never mind. Anyway
column4: let me quote the Lewin report. The Lewin report is a group of folks who are not politically affiliated. They analyzed the senator's plan. It cost $1.2 trillion. The Lewin report accurately noted that there are going to be 20 million people
column5: over 20 million people added to government-controlled health care. It would be the largest increase in government health care ever.  If you raise the Medicaid to 300 percent
column6: it provides an incentive for small businesses not to provide private insurance to their employees. Why should they insure somebody when the government's going to insure it for them?  It's estimated that 8 million people will go from private insurance to government insurance.  We have a fundamental difference of opinion. I think government- run health will lead to poor-quality health
column7: will lead to rationing
column8: will lead to less choice.  Once a health-care program ends up in a line item in the federal government budget
column9: it leads to more controls.  And just look at other countries that have tried to have federally controlled health care. They have poor-quality health care.  Our health-care system is the envy of the world because we believe in making sure that the decisions are made by doctors and patients
column10: not by officials in the nation's capital.

column1: The president just said that government-run health care results in poor quality. Now
column2: maybe that explains why he hasn't fully funded the VA and the VA hospital is having trouble and veterans are complaining. Maybe that explains why Medicare patients are complaining about being pushed off of Medicare. He doesn't adequately fund it.  But let me just say to America: I am not proposing a government-run program. That's not what I have. I have Blue Cross/Blue Shield. Senators and congressmen have a wide choice. Americans ought to have it too.

column1: Talk about the VA: We've increased VA funding by $22 billion in the four years since I've been president. That's twice the amount that my predecessor increased VA funding. Of course we're meeting our obligation to our veterans
column2: and the veterans know that.  We're expanding veterans' health care throughout the country. We're aligning facilities where the veterans live now. Veterans are getting very good health care under my administration
column3: and they will continue to do so during the next four years.

column2: '13Oct'
column3: 7)	" Well
column4: two leading national news networks have both said the president's characterization of my health-care plan is incorrect. One called it fiction. The other called it untrue. The fact is that my health-care plan
column5: America
column6: is very simple. It gives you the choice. I don't force you to do anything. It's not a government plan. The government doesn't require you to do anything. You choose your doctor. You choose your plan.  If you don't want to take the offer of the plan that I want to put forward
column7: you don't have do. You can keep what you have today
column8: keep a high deductible
column9: keep high premiums
column10: keep a high co-pay
column11: keep low benefits.  But I got a better plan. And I don't think a lot of people are going to want to keep what they have today.  Here's what I do: We take over Medicaid children from the states so that every child in America is covered. And in exchange
column12: if the states want to -- they're not forced to
column13: they can choose to -- they cover individuals up to 300 percent of poverty. It's their choice.  I think they'll choose it
column14: because it's a net plus of $5 billion to them.  We allow you -- if you choose to
column15: you don't have to -- but we give you broader competition to allow you to buy into the same health care plan that senators and congressmen give themselves. If it's good enough for us
column16: it's good enough for every American. I believe that your health care is just as important as any politician in Washington
column17: D. C.  You want to buy into it
column18: you can. We give you broader competition. That helps lower prices.  In addition to that
column19: we're going to allow people 55 to 64 to buy into Medicare early. And most importantly
column20: we give small business a 50 percent tax credit so that after we lower the costs of health care
column22: whether they're self-employed or a small business
column23: a lower cost to be able to cover their employees.  Now
column24: what happens is when you begin to get people covered like that -- for instance in diabetes
column25: if you diagnose diabetes early
column26: you could save $50 billion in the health care system of America by avoiding surgery and dialysis. It works. And I'm going to offer it to America.

column2: I'm not so sure it's credible to quote leading news organizations about -- oh
column3: never mind. Anyway
column4: let me quote the Lewin report. The Lewin report is a group of folks who are not politically affiliated. They analyzed the senator's plan. It cost $1.2 trillion. The Lewin report accurately noted that there are going to be 20 million people
column5: over 20 million people added to government-controlled health care. It would be the largest increase in government health care ever.  If you raise the Medicaid to 300 percent
column6: it provides an incentive for small businesses not to provide private insurance to their employees. Why should they insure somebody when the government's going to insure it for them?  It's estimated that 8 million people will go from private insurance to government insurance.  We have a fundamental difference of opinion. I think government- run health will lead to poor-quality health
column7: will lead to rationing
column8: will lead to less choice.  Once a health-care program ends up in a line item in the federal government budget
column9: it leads to more controls.  And just look at other countries that have tried to have federally controlled health care. They have poor-quality health care.  Our health-care system is the envy of the world because we believe in making sure that the decisions are made by doctors and patients
column10: not by officials in the nation's capital.

column1: The president just said that government-run health care results in poor quality. Now
column2: maybe that explains why he hasn't fully funded the VA and the VA hospital is having trouble and veterans are complaining. Maybe that explains why Medicare patients are complaining about being pushed off of Medicare. He doesn't adequately fund it.  But let me just say to America: I am not proposing a government-run program. That's not what I have. I have Blue Cross/Blue Shield. Senators and congressmen have a wide choice. Americans ought to have it too.

column1: Talk about the VA: We've increased VA funding by $22 billion in the four years since I've been president. That's twice the amount that my predecessor increased VA funding. Of course we're meeting our obligation to our veterans
column2: and the veterans know that.  We're expanding veterans' health care throughout the country. We're aligning facilities where the veterans live now. Veterans are getting very good health care under my administration
column3: and they will continue to do so during the next four years.

column1: And just look at other countries that have tried to have federally controlled health care. They have poor-quality health care. column2: '13Oct'
column3: 8)	" First
column4: let me make sure that every senior listening today understands that when we're talking about reforming Social Security
column5: that they'll still get their checks. I remember the 2000 campaign
column6: people said if George W. gets elected
column7: your check will be taken away. Well
column8: people got their checks
column9: and they'll continue to get their checks.  There is a problem for our youngsters
column10: a real problem. And if we don't act today
column11: the problem will be valued in the trillions. And so I think we need to think differently. We'll honor our commitment to our seniors. But for our children and our grandchildren
column12: we need to have a different strategy.  And recognizing that
column13: I called together a group of our fellow citizens to study the issue. It was a committee chaired by the late Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York
column14: a Democrat. And they came up with a variety of ideas for people to look at.  I believe that younger workers ought to be allowed to take some of their own money and put it in a personal savings account
column15: because I understand that they need to get better rates of return than the rates of return being given in the current Social Security trust.  And the compounding rate of interest effect will make it more likely that the Social Security system is solvent for our children and our grandchildren. I will work with Republicans and Democrats. It'll be a vital issue in my second term. It is an issue that I am willing to take on
column16: and so I'll bring Republicans and Democrats together.  And we're of course going to have to consider the costs. But I want to warn my fellow citizens: The cost of doing nothing
column17: the cost of saying the current system is OK
column18: far exceeds the costs of trying to make sure we save the system for our children.

column1: You just heard the president say that young people ought to be able to take money out of Social Security and put it in their own accounts. Now
column2: my fellow Americans
column3: that's an invitation to disaster.  The CBO said very clearly that if you were to adopt the president's plan
column4: there would be a $2 trillion hole in Social Security
column5: because today's workers pay in to the system for today's retirees. And the CBO said -- that's the Congressional Budget Office; it's bipartisan -- they said that there would have to be a cut in benefits of 25 percent to 40 percent.  Now
column6: the president has never explained to America
column7: ever
column8: hasn't done it tonight
column9: where does the transitional money
column10: that $2 trillion
column11: come from?  He's already got $3 trillion
column12: according to The Washington Post
column13: of expenses that he's put on the line from his convention and the promises of this campaign
column14: none of which are paid for. Not one of them are paid for.  The fact is that the president is driving the largest deficits in American history. He's broken the pay-as-you-go rules.  I have a record of fighting for fiscal responsibility. In 1985
column15: I was one of the first Democrats -- broke with my party. We balanced the budget in the '90s. We paid down the debt for two years.  And that's what we're going to do. We're going to protect Social Security. I will not privatize it. I will not cut the benefits. And we're going to be fiscally responsible. And we will take care of Social Security.

column2: Bob. This is the same thing we heard -- remember
column3: I appeared on ""Meet the Press"" with Tim Russert in 1990-something. We heard the same thing. We fixed it. In fact
column4: we put together a $5. 6 trillion surplus in the '90s that was for the purpose of saving Social Security. If you take the tax cut that the president of the United States has given -- President Bush gave to Americans in the top 1 percent of America -- just that tax cut that went to the top 1 percent of America would have saved Social Security until the year 2075.  The president decided to give it to the wealthiest Americans in a tax cut. Now
column5: Alan Greenspan
column6: who I think has done a terrific job in monetary policy
column7: supports the president's tax cut. I don't. I support it for the middle class
column8: not that part of it that goes to people earning more than $200
column9: 000 a year.  And when I roll it back and we invest in the things that I have talked about to move our economy
column10: we're going to grow sufficiently
column11: it would begin to cut the deficit in half
column12: and we get back to where we were at the end of the 1990s when we balanced the budget and paid down the debt of this country.  Now
column13: we can do that.  Now
column14: if later on after a period of time we find that Social Security is in trouble
column15: we'll pull together the top experts of the country. We'll do exactly what we did in the 1990s. And we'll make whatever adjustment is necessary.  But the first and most important thing is to start creating jobs in America. The jobs the president is creating pay $9
column16: 000 less than the jobs that we're losing. And this is the first president in 72 years to preside over an economy in America that has lost jobs
column17: 1. 6 million jobs.  Eleven other presidents -- six Democrats and five Republicans -- had wars
column18: had recessions
column19: had great difficulties; none of them lost jobs the way this president has.  I have a plan to put America back to work. And if we're fiscally responsible and put America back to work
column20: we're going to fix Social Security.

column1: He forgot to tell you he voted to tax Social Security benefits more than one time. I didn't hear any plan to fix Social Security. I heard more of the same. He talks about middle-class tax cuts. That's exactly where the tax cuts went. Most of the tax cuts went to low- and middle-income Americans. And now the tax code is more fair. Twenty percent of the upper-income people pay about 80 percent of the taxes in America today because of how we structured the tax cuts. People listening out there know the benefits of the tax cuts we passed. If you have a child
column2: you got tax relief. If you're married
column3: you got tax relief. If you pay any tax at all
column4: you got tax relief. All of which was opposed by my opponent.  And the tax relief was important to spur consumption and investment to get us out of this recession.  People need to remember: Six months prior to my arrival
column5: the stock market started to go down. And it was one of the largest declines in our history. And then we had a recession and we got attacked
column6: which cost us 1 million jobs.  But we acted. I led the Congress. We passed tax relief. And now this economy is growing. We added 1. 9 million new jobs over the last 13 months.  Sure
column7: there's more work to do. But the way to make sure our economy grows is not to raise taxes on small-business owners. It's not to increase the scope of the federal government. It's to make sure we have fiscal sanity and keep taxes low.

column1: But I want to warn my fellow citizens: The cost of doing nothing, the cost of saying the current system is OK, far exceeds the costs of trying to make sure we save the system for our children. column2: '13Oct'
column3: 8)	" First
column4: let me make sure that every senior listening today understands that when we're talking about reforming Social Security
column5: that they'll still get their checks. I remember the 2000 campaign
column6: people said if George W. gets elected
column7: your check will be taken away. Well
column8: people got their checks
column9: and they'll continue to get their checks.  There is a problem for our youngsters
column10: a real problem. And if we don't act today
column11: the problem will be valued in the trillions. And so I think we need to think differently. We'll honor our commitment to our seniors. But for our children and our grandchildren
column12: we need to have a different strategy.  And recognizing that
column13: I called together a group of our fellow citizens to study the issue. It was a committee chaired by the late Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York
column14: a Democrat. And they came up with a variety of ideas for people to look at.  I believe that younger workers ought to be allowed to take some of their own money and put it in a personal savings account
column15: because I understand that they need to get better rates of return than the rates of return being given in the current Social Security trust.  And the compounding rate of interest effect will make it more likely that the Social Security system is solvent for our children and our grandchildren. I will work with Republicans and Democrats. It'll be a vital issue in my second term. It is an issue that I am willing to take on
column16: and so I'll bring Republicans and Democrats together.  And we're of course going to have to consider the costs. But I want to warn my fellow citizens: The cost of doing nothing
column17: the cost of saying the current system is OK
column18: far exceeds the costs of trying to make sure we save the system for our children.

column1: You just heard the president say that young people ought to be able to take money out of Social Security and put it in their own accounts. Now
column2: my fellow Americans
column3: that's an invitation to disaster.  The CBO said very clearly that if you were to adopt the president's plan
column4: there would be a $2 trillion hole in Social Security
column5: because today's workers pay in to the system for today's retirees. And the CBO said -- that's the Congressional Budget Office; it's bipartisan -- they said that there would have to be a cut in benefits of 25 percent to 40 percent.  Now
column6: the president has never explained to America
column7: ever
column8: hasn't done it tonight
column9: where does the transitional money
column10: that $2 trillion
column11: come from?  He's already got $3 trillion
column12: according to The Washington Post
column13: of expenses that he's put on the line from his convention and the promises of this campaign
column14: none of which are paid for. Not one of them are paid for.  The fact is that the president is driving the largest deficits in American history. He's broken the pay-as-you-go rules.  I have a record of fighting for fiscal responsibility. In 1985
column15: I was one of the first Democrats -- broke with my party. We balanced the budget in the '90s. We paid down the debt for two years.  And that's what we're going to do. We're going to protect Social Security. I will not privatize it. I will not cut the benefits. And we're going to be fiscally responsible. And we will take care of Social Security.

column2: Bob. This is the same thing we heard -- remember
column3: I appeared on ""Meet the Press"" with Tim Russert in 1990-something. We heard the same thing. We fixed it. In fact
column4: we put together a $5. 6 trillion surplus in the '90s that was for the purpose of saving Social Security. If you take the tax cut that the president of the United States has given -- President Bush gave to Americans in the top 1 percent of America -- just that tax cut that went to the top 1 percent of America would have saved Social Security until the year 2075.  The president decided to give it to the wealthiest Americans in a tax cut. Now
column5: Alan Greenspan
column6: who I think has done a terrific job in monetary policy
column7: supports the president's tax cut. I don't. I support it for the middle class
column8: not that part of it that goes to people earning more than $200
column9: 000 a year.  And when I roll it back and we invest in the things that I have talked about to move our economy
column10: we're going to grow sufficiently
column11: it would begin to cut the deficit in half
column12: and we get back to where we were at the end of the 1990s when we balanced the budget and paid down the debt of this country.  Now
column13: we can do that.  Now
column14: if later on after a period of time we find that Social Security is in trouble
column15: we'll pull together the top experts of the country. We'll do exactly what we did in the 1990s. And we'll make whatever adjustment is necessary.  But the first and most important thing is to start creating jobs in America. The jobs the president is creating pay $9
column16: 000 less than the jobs that we're losing. And this is the first president in 72 years to preside over an economy in America that has lost jobs
column17: 1. 6 million jobs.  Eleven other presidents -- six Democrats and five Republicans -- had wars
column18: had recessions
column19: had great difficulties; none of them lost jobs the way this president has.  I have a plan to put America back to work. And if we're fiscally responsible and put America back to work
column20: we're going to fix Social Security.

column1: He forgot to tell you he voted to tax Social Security benefits more than one time. I didn't hear any plan to fix Social Security. I heard more of the same. He talks about middle-class tax cuts. That's exactly where the tax cuts went. Most of the tax cuts went to low- and middle-income Americans. And now the tax code is more fair. Twenty percent of the upper-income people pay about 80 percent of the taxes in America today because of how we structured the tax cuts. People listening out there know the benefits of the tax cuts we passed. If you have a child
column2: you got tax relief. If you're married
column3: you got tax relief. If you pay any tax at all
column4: you got tax relief. All of which was opposed by my opponent.  And the tax relief was important to spur consumption and investment to get us out of this recession.  People need to remember: Six months prior to my arrival
column5: the stock market started to go down. And it was one of the largest declines in our history. And then we had a recession and we got attacked
column6: which cost us 1 million jobs.  But we acted. I led the Congress. We passed tax relief. And now this economy is growing. We added 1. 9 million new jobs over the last 13 months.  Sure
column7: there's more work to do. But the way to make sure our economy grows is not to raise taxes on small-business owners. It's not to increase the scope of the federal government. It's to make sure we have fiscal sanity and keep taxes low.

column2: '13Oct'
column3: 8)	" First
column4: let me make sure that every senior listening today understands that when we're talking about reforming Social Security
column5: that they'll still get their checks. I remember the 2000 campaign
column6: people said if George W. gets elected
column7: your check will be taken away. Well
column8: people got their checks
column9: and they'll continue to get their checks.  There is a problem for our youngsters
column10: a real problem. And if we don't act today
column11: the problem will be valued in the trillions. And so I think we need to think differently. We'll honor our commitment to our seniors. But for our children and our grandchildren
column12: we need to have a different strategy.  And recognizing that
column13: I called together a group of our fellow citizens to study the issue. It was a committee chaired by the late Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York
column14: a Democrat. And they came up with a variety of ideas for people to look at.  I believe that younger workers ought to be allowed to take some of their own money and put it in a personal savings account
column15: because I understand that they need to get better rates of return than the rates of return being given in the current Social Security trust.  And the compounding rate of interest effect will make it more likely that the Social Security system is solvent for our children and our grandchildren. I will work with Republicans and Democrats. It'll be a vital issue in my second term. It is an issue that I am willing to take on
column16: and so I'll bring Republicans and Democrats together.  And we're of course going to have to consider the costs. But I want to warn my fellow citizens: The cost of doing nothing
column17: the cost of saying the current system is OK
column18: far exceeds the costs of trying to make sure we save the system for our children.

column1: You just heard the president say that young people ought to be able to take money out of Social Security and put it in their own accounts. Now
column2: my fellow Americans
column3: that's an invitation to disaster.  The CBO said very clearly that if you were to adopt the president's plan
column4: there would be a $2 trillion hole in Social Security
column5: because today's workers pay in to the system for today's retirees. And the CBO said -- that's the Congressional Budget Office; it's bipartisan -- they said that there would have to be a cut in benefits of 25 percent to 40 percent.  Now
column6: the president has never explained to America
column7: ever
column8: hasn't done it tonight
column9: where does the transitional money
column10: that $2 trillion
column11: come from?  He's already got $3 trillion
column12: according to The Washington Post
column13: of expenses that he's put on the line from his convention and the promises of this campaign
column14: none of which are paid for. Not one of them are paid for.  The fact is that the president is driving the largest deficits in American history. He's broken the pay-as-you-go rules.  I have a record of fighting for fiscal responsibility. In 1985
column15: I was one of the first Democrats -- broke with my party. We balanced the budget in the '90s. We paid down the debt for two years.  And that's what we're going to do. We're going to protect Social Security. I will not privatize it. I will not cut the benefits. And we're going to be fiscally responsible. And we will take care of Social Security.

column2: Bob. This is the same thing we heard -- remember
column3: I appeared on ""Meet the Press"" with Tim Russert in 1990-something. We heard the same thing. We fixed it. In fact
column4: we put together a $5. 6 trillion surplus in the '90s that was for the purpose of saving Social Security. If you take the tax cut that the president of the United States has given -- President Bush gave to Americans in the top 1 percent of America -- just that tax cut that went to the top 1 percent of America would have saved Social Security until the year 2075.  The president decided to give it to the wealthiest Americans in a tax cut. Now
column5: Alan Greenspan
column6: who I think has done a terrific job in monetary policy
column7: supports the president's tax cut. I don't. I support it for the middle class
column8: not that part of it that goes to people earning more than $200
column9: 000 a year.  And when I roll it back and we invest in the things that I have talked about to move our economy
column10: we're going to grow sufficiently
column11: it would begin to cut the deficit in half
column12: and we get back to where we were at the end of the 1990s when we balanced the budget and paid down the debt of this country.  Now
column13: we can do that.  Now
column14: if later on after a period of time we find that Social Security is in trouble
column15: we'll pull together the top experts of the country. We'll do exactly what we did in the 1990s. And we'll make whatever adjustment is necessary.  But the first and most important thing is to start creating jobs in America. The jobs the president is creating pay $9
column16: 000 less than the jobs that we're losing. And this is the first president in 72 years to preside over an economy in America that has lost jobs
column17: 1. 6 million jobs.  Eleven other presidents -- six Democrats and five Republicans -- had wars
column18: had recessions
column19: had great difficulties; none of them lost jobs the way this president has.  I have a plan to put America back to work. And if we're fiscally responsible and put America back to work
column20: we're going to fix Social Security.

column1: He forgot to tell you he voted to tax Social Security benefits more than one time. I didn't hear any plan to fix Social Security. I heard more of the same. He talks about middle-class tax cuts. That's exactly where the tax cuts went. Most of the tax cuts went to low- and middle-income Americans. And now the tax code is more fair. Twenty percent of the upper-income people pay about 80 percent of the taxes in America today because of how we structured the tax cuts. People listening out there know the benefits of the tax cuts we passed. If you have a child
column2: you got tax relief. If you're married
column3: you got tax relief. If you pay any tax at all
column4: you got tax relief. All of which was opposed by my opponent.  And the tax relief was important to spur consumption and investment to get us out of this recession.  People need to remember: Six months prior to my arrival
column5: the stock market started to go down. And it was one of the largest declines in our history. And then we had a recession and we got attacked
column6: which cost us 1 million jobs.  But we acted. I led the Congress. We passed tax relief. And now this economy is growing. We added 1. 9 million new jobs over the last 13 months.  Sure
column7: there's more work to do. But the way to make sure our economy grows is not to raise taxes on small-business owners. It's not to increase the scope of the federal government. It's to make sure we have fiscal sanity and keep taxes low.

column2: '13Oct'
column3: 8)	" First
column4: let me make sure that every senior listening today understands that when we're talking about reforming Social Security
column5: that they'll still get their checks. I remember the 2000 campaign
column6: people said if George W. gets elected
column7: your check will be taken away. Well
column8: people got their checks
column9: and they'll continue to get their checks.  There is a problem for our youngsters
column10: a real problem. And if we don't act today
column11: the problem will be valued in the trillions. And so I think we need to think differently. We'll honor our commitment to our seniors. But for our children and our grandchildren
column12: we need to have a different strategy.  And recognizing that
column13: I called together a group of our fellow citizens to study the issue. It was a committee chaired by the late Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York
column14: a Democrat. And they came up with a variety of ideas for people to look at.  I believe that younger workers ought to be allowed to take some of their own money and put it in a personal savings account
column15: because I understand that they need to get better rates of return than the rates of return being given in the current Social Security trust.  And the compounding rate of interest effect will make it more likely that the Social Security system is solvent for our children and our grandchildren. I will work with Republicans and Democrats. It'll be a vital issue in my second term. It is an issue that I am willing to take on
column16: and so I'll bring Republicans and Democrats together.  And we're of course going to have to consider the costs. But I want to warn my fellow citizens: The cost of doing nothing
column17: the cost of saying the current system is OK
column18: far exceeds the costs of trying to make sure we save the system for our children.

column1: You just heard the president say that young people ought to be able to take money out of Social Security and put it in their own accounts. Now
column2: my fellow Americans
column3: that's an invitation to disaster.  The CBO said very clearly that if you were to adopt the president's plan
column4: there would be a $2 trillion hole in Social Security
column5: because today's workers pay in to the system for today's retirees. And the CBO said -- that's the Congressional Budget Office; it's bipartisan -- they said that there would have to be a cut in benefits of 25 percent to 40 percent.  Now
column6: the president has never explained to America
column7: ever
column8: hasn't done it tonight
column9: where does the transitional money
column10: that $2 trillion
column11: come from?  He's already got $3 trillion
column12: according to The Washington Post
column13: of expenses that he's put on the line from his convention and the promises of this campaign
column14: none of which are paid for. Not one of them are paid for.  The fact is that the president is driving the largest deficits in American history. He's broken the pay-as-you-go rules.  I have a record of fighting for fiscal responsibility. In 1985
column15: I was one of the first Democrats -- broke with my party. We balanced the budget in the '90s. We paid down the debt for two years.  And that's what we're going to do. We're going to protect Social Security. I will not privatize it. I will not cut the benefits. And we're going to be fiscally responsible. And we will take care of Social Security.

column2: Bob. This is the same thing we heard -- remember
column3: I appeared on ""Meet the Press"" with Tim Russert in 1990-something. We heard the same thing. We fixed it. In fact
column4: we put together a $5. 6 trillion surplus in the '90s that was for the purpose of saving Social Security. If you take the tax cut that the president of the United States has given -- President Bush gave to Americans in the top 1 percent of America -- just that tax cut that went to the top 1 percent of America would have saved Social Security until the year 2075.  The president decided to give it to the wealthiest Americans in a tax cut. Now
column5: Alan Greenspan
column6: who I think has done a terrific job in monetary policy
column7: supports the president's tax cut. I don't. I support it for the middle class
column8: not that part of it that goes to people earning more than $200
column9: 000 a year.  And when I roll it back and we invest in the things that I have talked about to move our economy
column10: we're going to grow sufficiently
column11: it would begin to cut the deficit in half
column12: and we get back to where we were at the end of the 1990s when we balanced the budget and paid down the debt of this country.  Now
column13: we can do that.  Now
column14: if later on after a period of time we find that Social Security is in trouble
column15: we'll pull together the top experts of the country. We'll do exactly what we did in the 1990s. And we'll make whatever adjustment is necessary.  But the first and most important thing is to start creating jobs in America. The jobs the president is creating pay $9
column16: 000 less than the jobs that we're losing. And this is the first president in 72 years to preside over an economy in America that has lost jobs
column17: 1. 6 million jobs.  Eleven other presidents -- six Democrats and five Republicans -- had wars
column18: had recessions
column19: had great difficulties; none of them lost jobs the way this president has.  I have a plan to put America back to work. And if we're fiscally responsible and put America back to work
column20: we're going to fix Social Security.

column1: He forgot to tell you he voted to tax Social Security benefits more than one time. I didn't hear any plan to fix Social Security. I heard more of the same. He talks about middle-class tax cuts. That's exactly where the tax cuts went. Most of the tax cuts went to low- and middle-income Americans. And now the tax code is more fair. Twenty percent of the upper-income people pay about 80 percent of the taxes in America today because of how we structured the tax cuts. People listening out there know the benefits of the tax cuts we passed. If you have a child
column2: you got tax relief. If you're married
column3: you got tax relief. If you pay any tax at all
column4: you got tax relief. All of which was opposed by my opponent.  And the tax relief was important to spur consumption and investment to get us out of this recession.  People need to remember: Six months prior to my arrival
column5: the stock market started to go down. And it was one of the largest declines in our history. And then we had a recession and we got attacked
column6: which cost us 1 million jobs.  But we acted. I led the Congress. We passed tax relief. And now this economy is growing. We added 1. 9 million new jobs over the last 13 months.  Sure
column7: there's more work to do. But the way to make sure our economy grows is not to raise taxes on small-business owners. It's not to increase the scope of the federal government. It's to make sure we have fiscal sanity and keep taxes low.
