column15: I was one of the first Democrats -- broke with my party. We balanced the budget in the '90s. We paid down the debt for two years.  And that's what we're going to do. We're going to protect Social Security. I will not privatize it. I will not cut the benefits. And we're going to be fiscally responsible. And we will take care of Social Security.

column2: Bob. This is the same thing we heard -- remember
column3: I appeared on ""Meet the Press"" with Tim Russert in 1990-something. We heard the same thing. We fixed it. In fact
column4: we put together a $5. 6 trillion surplus in the '90s that was for the purpose of saving Social Security. If you take the tax cut that the president of the United States has given -- President Bush gave to Americans in the top 1 percent of America -- just that tax cut that went to the top 1 percent of America would have saved Social Security until the year 2075.  The president decided to give it to the wealthiest Americans in a tax cut. Now
column5: Alan Greenspan
column6: who I think has done a terrific job in monetary policy
column7: supports the president's tax cut. I don't. I support it for the middle class
column8: not that part of it that goes to people earning more than $200
column9: 000 a year.  And when I roll it back and we invest in the things that I have talked about to move our economy
column10: we're going to grow sufficiently
column11: it would begin to cut the deficit in half
column12: and we get back to where we were at the end of the 1990s when we balanced the budget and paid down the debt of this country.  Now
column13: we can do that.  Now
column14: if later on after a period of time we find that Social Security is in trouble
column15: we'll pull together the top experts of the country. We'll do exactly what we did in the 1990s. And we'll make whatever adjustment is necessary.  But the first and most important thing is to start creating jobs in America. The jobs the president is creating pay $9
column16: 000 less than the jobs that we're losing. And this is the first president in 72 years to preside over an economy in America that has lost jobs
column17: 1. 6 million jobs.  Eleven other presidents -- six Democrats and five Republicans -- had wars
column18: had recessions
column19: had great difficulties; none of them lost jobs the way this president has.  I have a plan to put America back to work. And if we're fiscally responsible and put America back to work
column20: we're going to fix Social Security.

column1: He forgot to tell you he voted to tax Social Security benefits more than one time. I didn't hear any plan to fix Social Security. I heard more of the same. He talks about middle-class tax cuts. That's exactly where the tax cuts went. Most of the tax cuts went to low- and middle-income Americans. And now the tax code is more fair. Twenty percent of the upper-income people pay about 80 percent of the taxes in America today because of how we structured the tax cuts. People listening out there know the benefits of the tax cuts we passed. If you have a child
column2: you got tax relief. If you're married
column3: you got tax relief. If you pay any tax at all
column4: you got tax relief. All of which was opposed by my opponent.  And the tax relief was important to spur consumption and investment to get us out of this recession.  People need to remember: Six months prior to my arrival
column5: the stock market started to go down. And it was one of the largest declines in our history. And then we had a recession and we got attacked
column6: which cost us 1 million jobs.  But we acted. I led the Congress. We passed tax relief. And now this economy is growing. We added 1. 9 million new jobs over the last 13 months.  Sure
column7: there's more work to do. But the way to make sure our economy grows is not to raise taxes on small-business owners. It's not to increase the scope of the federal government. It's to make sure we have fiscal sanity and keep taxes low.

column2: '13Oct'
column3: 8)	" First
column4: let me make sure that every senior listening today understands that when we're talking about reforming Social Security
column5: that they'll still get their checks. I remember the 2000 campaign
column6: people said if George W. gets elected
column7: your check will be taken away. Well
column8: people got their checks
column9: and they'll continue to get their checks.  There is a problem for our youngsters
column10: a real problem. And if we don't act today
column11: the problem will be valued in the trillions. And so I think we need to think differently. We'll honor our commitment to our seniors. But for our children and our grandchildren
column12: we need to have a different strategy.  And recognizing that
column13: I called together a group of our fellow citizens to study the issue. It was a committee chaired by the late Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York
column14: a Democrat. And they came up with a variety of ideas for people to look at.  I believe that younger workers ought to be allowed to take some of their own money and put it in a personal savings account
column15: because I understand that they need to get better rates of return than the rates of return being given in the current Social Security trust.  And the compounding rate of interest effect will make it more likely that the Social Security system is solvent for our children and our grandchildren. I will work with Republicans and Democrats. It'll be a vital issue in my second term. It is an issue that I am willing to take on
column16: and so I'll bring Republicans and Democrats together.  And we're of course going to have to consider the costs. But I want to warn my fellow citizens: The cost of doing nothing
column17: the cost of saying the current system is OK
column18: far exceeds the costs of trying to make sure we save the system for our children.

column1: You just heard the president say that young people ought to be able to take money out of Social Security and put it in their own accounts. Now
column2: my fellow Americans
column3: that's an invitation to disaster.  The CBO said very clearly that if you were to adopt the president's plan
column4: there would be a $2 trillion hole in Social Security
column5: because today's workers pay in to the system for today's retirees. And the CBO said -- that's the Congressional Budget Office; it's bipartisan -- they said that there would have to be a cut in benefits of 25 percent to 40 percent.  Now
column6: the president has never explained to America
column7: ever
column8: hasn't done it tonight
column9: where does the transitional money
column10: that $2 trillion
column11: come from?  He's already got $3 trillion
column12: according to The Washington Post
column13: of expenses that he's put on the line from his convention and the promises of this campaign
column14: none of which are paid for. Not one of them are paid for.  The fact is that the president is driving the largest deficits in American history. He's broken the pay-as-you-go rules.  I have a record of fighting for fiscal responsibility. In 1985
column15: I was one of the first Democrats -- broke with my party. We balanced the budget in the '90s. We paid down the debt for two years.  And that's what we're going to do. We're going to protect Social Security. I will not privatize it. I will not cut the benefits. And we're going to be fiscally responsible. And we will take care of Social Security.

column2: Bob. This is the same thing we heard -- remember
column3: I appeared on ""Meet the Press"" with Tim Russert in 1990-something. We heard the same thing. We fixed it. In fact
column4: we put together a $5. 6 trillion surplus in the '90s that was for the purpose of saving Social Security. If you take the tax cut that the president of the United States has given -- President Bush gave to Americans in the top 1 percent of America -- just that tax cut that went to the top 1 percent of America would have saved Social Security until the year 2075.  The president decided to give it to the wealthiest Americans in a tax cut. Now
column5: Alan Greenspan
column6: who I think has done a terrific job in monetary policy
column7: supports the president's tax cut. I don't. I support it for the middle class
column8: not that part of it that goes to people earning more than $200
column9: 000 a year.  And when I roll it back and we invest in the things that I have talked about to move our economy
column10: we're going to grow sufficiently
column11: it would begin to cut the deficit in half
column12: and we get back to where we were at the end of the 1990s when we balanced the budget and paid down the debt of this country.  Now
column13: we can do that.  Now
column14: if later on after a period of time we find that Social Security is in trouble
column15: we'll pull together the top experts of the country. We'll do exactly what we did in the 1990s. And we'll make whatever adjustment is necessary.  But the first and most important thing is to start creating jobs in America. The jobs the president is creating pay $9
column16: 000 less than the jobs that we're losing. And this is the first president in 72 years to preside over an economy in America that has lost jobs
column17: 1. 6 million jobs.  Eleven other presidents -- six Democrats and five Republicans -- had wars
column18: had recessions
column19: had great difficulties; none of them lost jobs the way this president has.  I have a plan to put America back to work. And if we're fiscally responsible and put America back to work
column20: we're going to fix Social Security.

column1: He forgot to tell you he voted to tax Social Security benefits more than one time. I didn't hear any plan to fix Social Security. I heard more of the same. He talks about middle-class tax cuts. That's exactly where the tax cuts went. Most of the tax cuts went to low- and middle-income Americans. And now the tax code is more fair. Twenty percent of the upper-income people pay about 80 percent of the taxes in America today because of how we structured the tax cuts. People listening out there know the benefits of the tax cuts we passed. If you have a child
column2: you got tax relief. If you're married
column3: you got tax relief. If you pay any tax at all
column4: you got tax relief. All of which was opposed by my opponent.  And the tax relief was important to spur consumption and investment to get us out of this recession.  People need to remember: Six months prior to my arrival
column5: the stock market started to go down. And it was one of the largest declines in our history. And then we had a recession and we got attacked
column6: which cost us 1 million jobs.  But we acted. I led the Congress. We passed tax relief. And now this economy is growing. We added 1. 9 million new jobs over the last 13 months.  Sure
column7: there's more work to do. But the way to make sure our economy grows is not to raise taxes on small-business owners. It's not to increase the scope of the federal government. It's to make sure we have fiscal sanity and keep taxes low.

column1: And this is the first president in 72 years to preside over an economy in America that has lost jobs, 1. 6 million jobs.  Eleven other presidents -- six Democrats and five Republicans -- had wars, had recessions, had great difficulties; none of them lost jobs the way this president has. column2: '13Oct'
column3: 8)	" First
column4: let me make sure that every senior listening today understands that when we're talking about reforming Social Security
column5: that they'll still get their checks. I remember the 2000 campaign
column6: people said if George W. gets elected
column7: your check will be taken away. Well
column8: people got their checks
column9: and they'll continue to get their checks.  There is a problem for our youngsters
column10: a real problem. And if we don't act today
column11: the problem will be valued in the trillions. And so I think we need to think differently. We'll honor our commitment to our seniors. But for our children and our grandchildren
column12: we need to have a different strategy.  And recognizing that
column13: I called together a group of our fellow citizens to study the issue. It was a committee chaired by the late Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York
column14: a Democrat. And they came up with a variety of ideas for people to look at.  I believe that younger workers ought to be allowed to take some of their own money and put it in a personal savings account
column15: because I understand that they need to get better rates of return than the rates of return being given in the current Social Security trust.  And the compounding rate of interest effect will make it more likely that the Social Security system is solvent for our children and our grandchildren. I will work with Republicans and Democrats. It'll be a vital issue in my second term. It is an issue that I am willing to take on
column16: and so I'll bring Republicans and Democrats together.  And we're of course going to have to consider the costs. But I want to warn my fellow citizens: The cost of doing nothing
column17: the cost of saying the current system is OK
column18: far exceeds the costs of trying to make sure we save the system for our children.

column1: You just heard the president say that young people ought to be able to take money out of Social Security and put it in their own accounts. Now
column2: my fellow Americans
column3: that's an invitation to disaster.  The CBO said very clearly that if you were to adopt the president's plan
column4: there would be a $2 trillion hole in Social Security
column5: because today's workers pay in to the system for today's retirees. And the CBO said -- that's the Congressional Budget Office; it's bipartisan -- they said that there would have to be a cut in benefits of 25 percent to 40 percent.  Now
column6: the president has never explained to America
column7: ever
column8: hasn't done it tonight
column9: where does the transitional money
column10: that $2 trillion
column11: come from?  He's already got $3 trillion
column12: according to The Washington Post
column13: of expenses that he's put on the line from his convention and the promises of this campaign
column14: none of which are paid for. Not one of them are paid for.  The fact is that the president is driving the largest deficits in American history. He's broken the pay-as-you-go rules.  I have a record of fighting for fiscal responsibility. In 1985
column15: I was one of the first Democrats -- broke with my party. We balanced the budget in the '90s. We paid down the debt for two years.  And that's what we're going to do. We're going to protect Social Security. I will not privatize it. I will not cut the benefits. And we're going to be fiscally responsible. And we will take care of Social Security.

column2: Bob. This is the same thing we heard -- remember
column3: I appeared on ""Meet the Press"" with Tim Russert in 1990-something. We heard the same thing. We fixed it. In fact
column4: we put together a $5. 6 trillion surplus in the '90s that was for the purpose of saving Social Security. If you take the tax cut that the president of the United States has given -- President Bush gave to Americans in the top 1 percent of America -- just that tax cut that went to the top 1 percent of America would have saved Social Security until the year 2075.  The president decided to give it to the wealthiest Americans in a tax cut. Now
column5: Alan Greenspan
column6: who I think has done a terrific job in monetary policy
column7: supports the president's tax cut. I don't. I support it for the middle class
column8: not that part of it that goes to people earning more than $200
column9: 000 a year.  And when I roll it back and we invest in the things that I have talked about to move our economy
column10: we're going to grow sufficiently
column11: it would begin to cut the deficit in half
column12: and we get back to where we were at the end of the 1990s when we balanced the budget and paid down the debt of this country.  Now
column13: we can do that.  Now
column14: if later on after a period of time we find that Social Security is in trouble
column15: we'll pull together the top experts of the country. We'll do exactly what we did in the 1990s. And we'll make whatever adjustment is necessary.  But the first and most important thing is to start creating jobs in America. The jobs the president is creating pay $9
column16: 000 less than the jobs that we're losing. And this is the first president in 72 years to preside over an economy in America that has lost jobs
column17: 1. 6 million jobs.  Eleven other presidents -- six Democrats and five Republicans -- had wars
column18: had recessions
column19: had great difficulties; none of them lost jobs the way this president has.  I have a plan to put America back to work. And if we're fiscally responsible and put America back to work
column20: we're going to fix Social Security.

column1: He forgot to tell you he voted to tax Social Security benefits more than one time. I didn't hear any plan to fix Social Security. I heard more of the same. He talks about middle-class tax cuts. That's exactly where the tax cuts went. Most of the tax cuts went to low- and middle-income Americans. And now the tax code is more fair. Twenty percent of the upper-income people pay about 80 percent of the taxes in America today because of how we structured the tax cuts. People listening out there know the benefits of the tax cuts we passed. If you have a child
column2: you got tax relief. If you're married
column3: you got tax relief. If you pay any tax at all
column4: you got tax relief. All of which was opposed by my opponent.  And the tax relief was important to spur consumption and investment to get us out of this recession.  People need to remember: Six months prior to my arrival
column5: the stock market started to go down. And it was one of the largest declines in our history. And then we had a recession and we got attacked
column6: which cost us 1 million jobs.  But we acted. I led the Congress. We passed tax relief. And now this economy is growing. We added 1. 9 million new jobs over the last 13 months.  Sure
column7: there's more work to do. But the way to make sure our economy grows is not to raise taxes on small-business owners. It's not to increase the scope of the federal government. It's to make sure we have fiscal sanity and keep taxes low.

And the CBO said -- that's the Congressional Budget Office; it's bipartisan -- they said that there would have to be a cut in benefits of 25 percent to 40 percent. column2: '13Oct'
column3: 8)	" First
column4: let me make sure that every senior listening today understands that when we're talking about reforming Social Security
column5: that they'll still get their checks. I remember the 2000 campaign
column6: people said if George W. gets elected
column7: your check will be taken away. Well
column8: people got their checks
column9: and they'll continue to get their checks.  There is a problem for our youngsters
column10: a real problem. And if we don't act today
column11: the problem will be valued in the trillions. And so I think we need to think differently. We'll honor our commitment to our seniors. But for our children and our grandchildren
column12: we need to have a different strategy.  And recognizing that
column13: I called together a group of our fellow citizens to study the issue. It was a committee chaired by the late Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York
column14: a Democrat. And they came up with a variety of ideas for people to look at.  I believe that younger workers ought to be allowed to take some of their own money and put it in a personal savings account
column15: because I understand that they need to get better rates of return than the rates of return being given in the current Social Security trust.  And the compounding rate of interest effect will make it more likely that the Social Security system is solvent for our children and our grandchildren. I will work with Republicans and Democrats. It'll be a vital issue in my second term. It is an issue that I am willing to take on
column16: and so I'll bring Republicans and Democrats together.  And we're of course going to have to consider the costs. But I want to warn my fellow citizens: The cost of doing nothing
column17: the cost of saying the current system is OK
column18: far exceeds the costs of trying to make sure we save the system for our children.

column1: You just heard the president say that young people ought to be able to take money out of Social Security and put it in their own accounts. Now
column2: my fellow Americans
column3: that's an invitation to disaster.  The CBO said very clearly that if you were to adopt the president's plan
column4: there would be a $2 trillion hole in Social Security
column5: because today's workers pay in to the system for today's retirees. And the CBO said -- that's the Congressional Budget Office; it's bipartisan -- they said that there would have to be a cut in benefits of 25 percent to 40 percent.  Now
column6: the president has never explained to America
column7: ever
column8: hasn't done it tonight
column9: where does the transitional money
column10: that $2 trillion
column11: come from?  He's already got $3 trillion
column12: according to The Washington Post
column13: of expenses that he's put on the line from his convention and the promises of this campaign
column14: none of which are paid for. Not one of them are paid for.  The fact is that the president is driving the largest deficits in American history. He's broken the pay-as-you-go rules.  I have a record of fighting for fiscal responsibility. In 1985
column15: I was one of the first Democrats -- broke with my party. We balanced the budget in the '90s. We paid down the debt for two years.  And that's what we're going to do. We're going to protect Social Security. I will not privatize it. I will not cut the benefits. And we're going to be fiscally responsible. And we will take care of Social Security.

column2: Bob. This is the same thing we heard -- remember
column3: I appeared on ""Meet the Press"" with Tim Russert in 1990-something. We heard the same thing. We fixed it. In fact
column4: we put together a $5. 6 trillion surplus in the '90s that was for the purpose of saving Social Security. If you take the tax cut that the president of the United States has given -- President Bush gave to Americans in the top 1 percent of America -- just that tax cut that went to the top 1 percent of America would have saved Social Security until the year 2075.  The president decided to give it to the wealthiest Americans in a tax cut. Now
column5: Alan Greenspan
column6: who I think has done a terrific job in monetary policy
column7: supports the president's tax cut. I don't. I support it for the middle class
column8: not that part of it that goes to people earning more than $200
column9: 000 a year.  And when I roll it back and we invest in the things that I have talked about to move our economy
column10: we're going to grow sufficiently
column11: it would begin to cut the deficit in half
column12: and we get back to where we were at the end of the 1990s when we balanced the budget and paid down the debt of this country.  Now
column13: we can do that.  Now
column14: if later on after a period of time we find that Social Security is in trouble
column15: we'll pull together the top experts of the country. We'll do exactly what we did in the 1990s. And we'll make whatever adjustment is necessary.  But the first and most important thing is to start creating jobs in America. The jobs the president is creating pay $9
column16: 000 less than the jobs that we're losing. And this is the first president in 72 years to preside over an economy in America that has lost jobs
column17: 1. 6 million jobs.  Eleven other presidents -- six Democrats and five Republicans -- had wars
column18: had recessions
column19: had great difficulties; none of them lost jobs the way this president has.  I have a plan to put America back to work. And if we're fiscally responsible and put America back to work
column20: we're going to fix Social Security.

column1: He forgot to tell you he voted to tax Social Security benefits more than one time. I didn't hear any plan to fix Social Security. I heard more of the same. He talks about middle-class tax cuts. That's exactly where the tax cuts went. Most of the tax cuts went to low- and middle-income Americans. And now the tax code is more fair. Twenty percent of the upper-income people pay about 80 percent of the taxes in America today because of how we structured the tax cuts. People listening out there know the benefits of the tax cuts we passed. If you have a child
column2: you got tax relief. If you're married
column3: you got tax relief. If you pay any tax at all
column4: you got tax relief. All of which was opposed by my opponent.  And the tax relief was important to spur consumption and investment to get us out of this recession.  People need to remember: Six months prior to my arrival
column5: the stock market started to go down. And it was one of the largest declines in our history. And then we had a recession and we got attacked
column6: which cost us 1 million jobs.  But we acted. I led the Congress. We passed tax relief. And now this economy is growing. We added 1. 9 million new jobs over the last 13 months.  Sure
column7: there's more work to do. But the way to make sure our economy grows is not to raise taxes on small-business owners. It's not to increase the scope of the federal government. It's to make sure we have fiscal sanity and keep taxes low.

And the CBO said -- that's the Congressional Budget Office; it's bipartisan -- they said that there would have to be a cut in benefits of 25 percent to 40 percent. column14: none of which are paid for. Not one of them are paid for.  The fact is that the president is driving the largest deficits in American history. He's broken the pay-as-you-go rules.  I have a record of fighting for fiscal responsibility. In 1985
column15: I was one of the first Democrats -- broke with my party. We balanced the budget in the '90s. We paid down the debt for two years.  And that's what we're going to do. We're going to protect Social Security. I will not privatize it. I will not cut the benefits. And we're going to be fiscally responsible. And we will take care of Social Security.

column2: Bob. This is the same thing we heard -- remember
column3: I appeared on ""Meet the Press"" with Tim Russert in 1990-something. We heard the same thing. We fixed it. In fact
column4: we put together a $5. 6 trillion surplus in the '90s that was for the purpose of saving Social Security. If you take the tax cut that the president of the United States has given -- President Bush gave to Americans in the top 1 percent of America -- just that tax cut that went to the top 1 percent of America would have saved Social Security until the year 2075.  The president decided to give it to the wealthiest Americans in a tax cut. Now
column5: Alan Greenspan
column6: who I think has done a terrific job in monetary policy
column7: supports the president's tax cut. I don't. I support it for the middle class
column8: not that part of it that goes to people earning more than $200
column9: 000 a year.  And when I roll it back and we invest in the things that I have talked about to move our economy
column10: we're going to grow sufficiently
column11: it would begin to cut the deficit in half
column12: and we get back to where we were at the end of the 1990s when we balanced the budget and paid down the debt of this country.  Now
column13: we can do that.  Now
column14: if later on after a period of time we find that Social Security is in trouble
column15: we'll pull together the top experts of the country. We'll do exactly what we did in the 1990s. And we'll make whatever adjustment is necessary.  But the first and most important thing is to start creating jobs in America. The jobs the president is creating pay $9
column16: 000 less than the jobs that we're losing. And this is the first president in 72 years to preside over an economy in America that has lost jobs
column17: 1. 6 million jobs.  Eleven other presidents -- six Democrats and five Republicans -- had wars
column18: had recessions
column19: had great difficulties; none of them lost jobs the way this president has.  I have a plan to put America back to work. And if we're fiscally responsible and put America back to work
column20: we're going to fix Social Security.

column1: He forgot to tell you he voted to tax Social Security benefits more than one time. I didn't hear any plan to fix Social Security. I heard more of the same. He talks about middle-class tax cuts. That's exactly where the tax cuts went. Most of the tax cuts went to low- and middle-income Americans. And now the tax code is more fair. Twenty percent of the upper-income people pay about 80 percent of the taxes in America today because of how we structured the tax cuts. People listening out there know the benefits of the tax cuts we passed. If you have a child
column2: you got tax relief. If you're married
column3: you got tax relief. If you pay any tax at all
column4: you got tax relief. All of which was opposed by my opponent.  And the tax relief was important to spur consumption and investment to get us out of this recession.  People need to remember: Six months prior to my arrival
column5: the stock market started to go down. And it was one of the largest declines in our history. And then we had a recession and we got attacked
column6: which cost us 1 million jobs.  But we acted. I led the Congress. We passed tax relief. And now this economy is growing. We added 1. 9 million new jobs over the last 13 months.  Sure
column7: there's more work to do. But the way to make sure our economy grows is not to raise taxes on small-business owners. It's not to increase the scope of the federal government. It's to make sure we have fiscal sanity and keep taxes low.

And the CBO said -- that's the Congressional Budget Office; it's bipartisan -- they said that there would have to be a cut in benefits of 25 percent to 40 percent. column2: '13Oct'
column3: 8)	" First
column4: let me make sure that every senior listening today understands that when we're talking about reforming Social Security
column5: that they'll still get their checks. I remember the 2000 campaign
column6: people said if George W. gets elected
column7: your check will be taken away. Well
column8: people got their checks
column9: and they'll continue to get their checks.  There is a problem for our youngsters
column10: a real problem. And if we don't act today
column11: the problem will be valued in the trillions. And so I think we need to think differently. We'll honor our commitment to our seniors. But for our children and our grandchildren
column12: we need to have a different strategy.  And recognizing that
column13: I called together a group of our fellow citizens to study the issue. It was a committee chaired by the late Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York
column14: a Democrat. And they came up with a variety of ideas for people to look at.  I believe that younger workers ought to be allowed to take some of their own money and put it in a personal savings account
column15: because I understand that they need to get better rates of return than the rates of return being given in the current Social Security trust.  And the compounding rate of interest effect will make it more likely that the Social Security system is solvent for our children and our grandchildren. I will work with Republicans and Democrats. It'll be a vital issue in my second term. It is an issue that I am willing to take on
column16: and so I'll bring Republicans and Democrats together.  And we're of course going to have to consider the costs. But I want to warn my fellow citizens: The cost of doing nothing
column17: the cost of saying the current system is OK
column18: far exceeds the costs of trying to make sure we save the system for our children.

column1: You just heard the president say that young people ought to be able to take money out of Social Security and put it in their own accounts. Now
column2: my fellow Americans
column3: that's an invitation to disaster.  The CBO said very clearly that if you were to adopt the president's plan
column4: there would be a $2 trillion hole in Social Security
column5: because today's workers pay in to the system for today's retirees. And the CBO said -- that's the Congressional Budget Office; it's bipartisan -- they said that there would have to be a cut in benefits of 25 percent to 40 percent.  Now
column6: the president has never explained to America
column7: ever
column8: hasn't done it tonight
column9: where does the transitional money
column10: that $2 trillion
column11: come from?  He's already got $3 trillion
column12: according to The Washington Post
column13: of expenses that he's put on the line from his convention and the promises of this campaign
column14: none of which are paid for. Not one of them are paid for.  The fact is that the president is driving the largest deficits in American history. He's broken the pay-as-you-go rules.  I have a record of fighting for fiscal responsibility. In 1985
column15: I was one of the first Democrats -- broke with my party. We balanced the budget in the '90s. We paid down the debt for two years.  And that's what we're going to do. We're going to protect Social Security. I will not privatize it. I will not cut the benefits. And we're going to be fiscally responsible. And we will take care of Social Security.

column2: Bob. This is the same thing we heard -- remember
column3: I appeared on ""Meet the Press"" with Tim Russert in 1990-something. We heard the same thing. We fixed it. In fact
column4: we put together a $5. 6 trillion surplus in the '90s that was for the purpose of saving Social Security. If you take the tax cut that the president of the United States has given -- President Bush gave to Americans in the top 1 percent of America -- just that tax cut that went to the top 1 percent of America would have saved Social Security until the year 2075.  The president decided to give it to the wealthiest Americans in a tax cut. Now
column5: Alan Greenspan
column6: who I think has done a terrific job in monetary policy
column7: supports the president's tax cut. I don't. I support it for the middle class
column8: not that part of it that goes to people earning more than $200
column9: 000 a year.  And when I roll it back and we invest in the things that I have talked about to move our economy
column10: we're going to grow sufficiently
column11: it would begin to cut the deficit in half
column12: and we get back to where we were at the end of the 1990s when we balanced the budget and paid down the debt of this country.  Now
column13: we can do that.  Now
column14: if later on after a period of time we find that Social Security is in trouble
column15: we'll pull together the top experts of the country. We'll do exactly what we did in the 1990s. And we'll make whatever adjustment is necessary.  But the first and most important thing is to start creating jobs in America. The jobs the president is creating pay $9
column16: 000 less than the jobs that we're losing. And this is the first president in 72 years to preside over an economy in America that has lost jobs
column17: 1. 6 million jobs.  Eleven other presidents -- six Democrats and five Republicans -- had wars
column18: had recessions
column19: had great difficulties; none of them lost jobs the way this president has.  I have a plan to put America back to work. And if we're fiscally responsible and put America back to work
column20: we're going to fix Social Security.

column1: He forgot to tell you he voted to tax Social Security benefits more than one time. I didn't hear any plan to fix Social Security. I heard more of the same. He talks about middle-class tax cuts. That's exactly where the tax cuts went. Most of the tax cuts went to low- and middle-income Americans. And now the tax code is more fair. Twenty percent of the upper-income people pay about 80 percent of the taxes in America today because of how we structured the tax cuts. People listening out there know the benefits of the tax cuts we passed. If you have a child
column2: you got tax relief. If you're married
column3: you got tax relief. If you pay any tax at all
column4: you got tax relief. All of which was opposed by my opponent.  And the tax relief was important to spur consumption and investment to get us out of this recession.  People need to remember: Six months prior to my arrival
column5: the stock market started to go down. And it was one of the largest declines in our history. And then we had a recession and we got attacked
column6: which cost us 1 million jobs.  But we acted. I led the Congress. We passed tax relief. And now this economy is growing. We added 1. 9 million new jobs over the last 13 months.  Sure
column7: there's more work to do. But the way to make sure our economy grows is not to raise taxes on small-business owners. It's not to increase the scope of the federal government. It's to make sure we have fiscal sanity and keep taxes low.

column2: '13Oct'
column3: 8)	" First
column4: let me make sure that every senior listening today understands that when we're talking about reforming Social Security
column5: that they'll still get their checks. I remember the 2000 campaign
column6: people said if George W. gets elected
column7: your check will be taken away. Well
column8: people got their checks
column9: and they'll continue to get their checks.  There is a problem for our youngsters
column10: a real problem. And if we don't act today
column11: the problem will be valued in the trillions. And so I think we need to think differently. We'll honor our commitment to our seniors. But for our children and our grandchildren
column12: we need to have a different strategy.  And recognizing that
column13: I called together a group of our fellow citizens to study the issue. It was a committee chaired by the late Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York
column14: a Democrat. And they came up with a variety of ideas for people to look at.  I believe that younger workers ought to be allowed to take some of their own money and put it in a personal savings account
column15: because I understand that they need to get better rates of return than the rates of return being given in the current Social Security trust.  And the compounding rate of interest effect will make it more likely that the Social Security system is solvent for our children and our grandchildren. I will work with Republicans and Democrats. It'll be a vital issue in my second term. It is an issue that I am willing to take on
column16: and so I'll bring Republicans and Democrats together.  And we're of course going to have to consider the costs. But I want to warn my fellow citizens: The cost of doing nothing
column17: the cost of saying the current system is OK
column18: far exceeds the costs of trying to make sure we save the system for our children.

column1: You just heard the president say that young people ought to be able to take money out of Social Security and put it in their own accounts. Now
column2: my fellow Americans
column3: that's an invitation to disaster.  The CBO said very clearly that if you were to adopt the president's plan
column4: there would be a $2 trillion hole in Social Security
column5: because today's workers pay in to the system for today's retirees. And the CBO said -- that's the Congressional Budget Office; it's bipartisan -- they said that there would have to be a cut in benefits of 25 percent to 40 percent.  Now
column6: the president has never explained to America
column7: ever
column8: hasn't done it tonight
column9: where does the transitional money
column10: that $2 trillion
column11: come from?  He's already got $3 trillion
column12: according to The Washington Post
column13: of expenses that he's put on the line from his convention and the promises of this campaign
column14: none of which are paid for. Not one of them are paid for.  The fact is that the president is driving the largest deficits in American history. He's broken the pay-as-you-go rules.  I have a record of fighting for fiscal responsibility. In 1985
column15: I was one of the first Democrats -- broke with my party. We balanced the budget in the '90s. We paid down the debt for two years.  And that's what we're going to do. We're going to protect Social Security. I will not privatize it. I will not cut the benefits. And we're going to be fiscally responsible. And we will take care of Social Security.

column2: Bob. This is the same thing we heard -- remember
column3: I appeared on ""Meet the Press"" with Tim Russert in 1990-something. We heard the same thing. We fixed it. In fact
column4: we put together a $5. 6 trillion surplus in the '90s that was for the purpose of saving Social Security. If you take the tax cut that the president of the United States has given -- President Bush gave to Americans in the top 1 percent of America -- just that tax cut that went to the top 1 percent of America would have saved Social Security until the year 2075.  The president decided to give it to the wealthiest Americans in a tax cut. Now
column5: Alan Greenspan
column6: who I think has done a terrific job in monetary policy
column7: supports the president's tax cut. I don't. I support it for the middle class
column8: not that part of it that goes to people earning more than $200
column9: 000 a year.  And when I roll it back and we invest in the things that I have talked about to move our economy
column10: we're going to grow sufficiently
column11: it would begin to cut the deficit in half
column12: and we get back to where we were at the end of the 1990s when we balanced the budget and paid down the debt of this country.  Now
column13: we can do that.  Now
column14: if later on after a period of time we find that Social Security is in trouble
column15: we'll pull together the top experts of the country. We'll do exactly what we did in the 1990s. And we'll make whatever adjustment is necessary.  But the first and most important thing is to start creating jobs in America. The jobs the president is creating pay $9
column16: 000 less than the jobs that we're losing. And this is the first president in 72 years to preside over an economy in America that has lost jobs
column17: 1. 6 million jobs.  Eleven other presidents -- six Democrats and five Republicans -- had wars
column18: had recessions
column19: had great difficulties; none of them lost jobs the way this president has.  I have a plan to put America back to work. And if we're fiscally responsible and put America back to work
column20: we're going to fix Social Security.

column1: He forgot to tell you he voted to tax Social Security benefits more than one time. I didn't hear any plan to fix Social Security. I heard more of the same. He talks about middle-class tax cuts. That's exactly where the tax cuts went. Most of the tax cuts went to low- and middle-income Americans. And now the tax code is more fair. Twenty percent of the upper-income people pay about 80 percent of the taxes in America today because of how we structured the tax cuts. People listening out there know the benefits of the tax cuts we passed. If you have a child
column2: you got tax relief. If you're married
column3: you got tax relief. If you pay any tax at all
column4: you got tax relief. All of which was opposed by my opponent.  And the tax relief was important to spur consumption and investment to get us out of this recession.  People need to remember: Six months prior to my arrival
column5: the stock market started to go down. And it was one of the largest declines in our history. And then we had a recession and we got attacked
column6: which cost us 1 million jobs.  But we acted. I led the Congress. We passed tax relief. And now this economy is growing. We added 1. 9 million new jobs over the last 13 months.  Sure
column7: there's more work to do. But the way to make sure our economy grows is not to raise taxes on small-business owners. It's not to increase the scope of the federal government. It's to make sure we have fiscal sanity and keep taxes low.

column1: He forgot to tell you he voted to tax Social Security benefits more than one time. I didn't hear any plan to fix Social Security. column2: '13Oct'
column3: 8)	" First
column4: let me make sure that every senior listening today understands that when we're talking about reforming Social Security
column5: that they'll still get their checks. I remember the 2000 campaign
column6: people said if George W. gets elected
column7: your check will be taken away. Well
column8: people got their checks
column9: and they'll continue to get their checks.  There is a problem for our youngsters
column10: a real problem. And if we don't act today
column11: the problem will be valued in the trillions. And so I think we need to think differently. We'll honor our commitment to our seniors. But for our children and our grandchildren
column12: we need to have a different strategy.  And recognizing that
column13: I called together a group of our fellow citizens to study the issue. It was a committee chaired by the late Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York
column14: a Democrat. And they came up with a variety of ideas for people to look at.  I believe that younger workers ought to be allowed to take some of their own money and put it in a personal savings account
column15: because I understand that they need to get better rates of return than the rates of return being given in the current Social Security trust.  And the compounding rate of interest effect will make it more likely that the Social Security system is solvent for our children and our grandchildren. I will work with Republicans and Democrats. It'll be a vital issue in my second term. It is an issue that I am willing to take on
column16: and so I'll bring Republicans and Democrats together.  And we're of course going to have to consider the costs. But I want to warn my fellow citizens: The cost of doing nothing
column17: the cost of saying the current system is OK
column18: far exceeds the costs of trying to make sure we save the system for our children.

column1: You just heard the president say that young people ought to be able to take money out of Social Security and put it in their own accounts. Now
column2: my fellow Americans
column3: that's an invitation to disaster.  The CBO said very clearly that if you were to adopt the president's plan
column4: there would be a $2 trillion hole in Social Security
column5: because today's workers pay in to the system for today's retirees. And the CBO said -- that's the Congressional Budget Office; it's bipartisan -- they said that there would have to be a cut in benefits of 25 percent to 40 percent.  Now
column6: the president has never explained to America
column7: ever
column8: hasn't done it tonight
column9: where does the transitional money
column10: that $2 trillion
column11: come from?  He's already got $3 trillion
column12: according to The Washington Post
column13: of expenses that he's put on the line from his convention and the promises of this campaign
column14: none of which are paid for. Not one of them are paid for.  The fact is that the president is driving the largest deficits in American history. He's broken the pay-as-you-go rules.  I have a record of fighting for fiscal responsibility. In 1985
column15: I was one of the first Democrats -- broke with my party. We balanced the budget in the '90s. We paid down the debt for two years.  And that's what we're going to do. We're going to protect Social Security. I will not privatize it. I will not cut the benefits. And we're going to be fiscally responsible. And we will take care of Social Security.

column2: Bob. This is the same thing we heard -- remember
column3: I appeared on ""Meet the Press"" with Tim Russert in 1990-something. We heard the same thing. We fixed it. In fact
column4: we put together a $5. 6 trillion surplus in the '90s that was for the purpose of saving Social Security. If you take the tax cut that the president of the United States has given -- President Bush gave to Americans in the top 1 percent of America -- just that tax cut that went to the top 1 percent of America would have saved Social Security until the year 2075.  The president decided to give it to the wealthiest Americans in a tax cut. Now
column5: Alan Greenspan
column6: who I think has done a terrific job in monetary policy
column7: supports the president's tax cut. I don't. I support it for the middle class
column8: not that part of it that goes to people earning more than $200
column9: 000 a year.  And when I roll it back and we invest in the things that I have talked about to move our economy
column10: we're going to grow sufficiently
column11: it would begin to cut the deficit in half
column12: and we get back to where we were at the end of the 1990s when we balanced the budget and paid down the debt of this country.  Now
column13: we can do that.  Now
column14: if later on after a period of time we find that Social Security is in trouble
column15: we'll pull together the top experts of the country. We'll do exactly what we did in the 1990s. And we'll make whatever adjustment is necessary.  But the first and most important thing is to start creating jobs in America. The jobs the president is creating pay $9
column16: 000 less than the jobs that we're losing. And this is the first president in 72 years to preside over an economy in America that has lost jobs
column17: 1. 6 million jobs.  Eleven other presidents -- six Democrats and five Republicans -- had wars
column18: had recessions
column19: had great difficulties; none of them lost jobs the way this president has.  I have a plan to put America back to work. And if we're fiscally responsible and put America back to work
column20: we're going to fix Social Security.

column1: He forgot to tell you he voted to tax Social Security benefits more than one time. I didn't hear any plan to fix Social Security. I heard more of the same. He talks about middle-class tax cuts. That's exactly where the tax cuts went. Most of the tax cuts went to low- and middle-income Americans. And now the tax code is more fair. Twenty percent of the upper-income people pay about 80 percent of the taxes in America today because of how we structured the tax cuts. People listening out there know the benefits of the tax cuts we passed. If you have a child
column2: you got tax relief. If you're married
column3: you got tax relief. If you pay any tax at all
column4: you got tax relief. All of which was opposed by my opponent.  And the tax relief was important to spur consumption and investment to get us out of this recession.  People need to remember: Six months prior to my arrival
column5: the stock market started to go down. And it was one of the largest declines in our history. And then we had a recession and we got attacked
column6: which cost us 1 million jobs.  But we acted. I led the Congress. We passed tax relief. And now this economy is growing. We added 1. 9 million new jobs over the last 13 months.  Sure
column7: there's more work to do. But the way to make sure our economy grows is not to raise taxes on small-business owners. It's not to increase the scope of the federal government. It's to make sure we have fiscal sanity and keep taxes low.

column15: I was one of the first Democrats -- broke with my party. We balanced the budget in the '90s. We paid down the debt for two years.  And that's what we're going to do. We're going to protect Social Security. I will not privatize it. I will not cut the benefits. And we're going to be fiscally responsible. And we will take care of Social Security.

column2: Bob. This is the same thing we heard -- remember
column3: I appeared on ""Meet the Press"" with Tim Russert in 1990-something. We heard the same thing. We fixed it. In fact
column4: we put together a $5. 6 trillion surplus in the '90s that was for the purpose of saving Social Security. If you take the tax cut that the president of the United States has given -- President Bush gave to Americans in the top 1 percent of America -- just that tax cut that went to the top 1 percent of America would have saved Social Security until the year 2075.  The president decided to give it to the wealthiest Americans in a tax cut. Now
column5: Alan Greenspan
column6: who I think has done a terrific job in monetary policy
column7: supports the president's tax cut. I don't. I support it for the middle class
column8: not that part of it that goes to people earning more than $200
column9: 000 a year.  And when I roll it back and we invest in the things that I have talked about to move our economy
column10: we're going to grow sufficiently
column11: it would begin to cut the deficit in half
column12: and we get back to where we were at the end of the 1990s when we balanced the budget and paid down the debt of this country.  Now
column13: we can do that.  Now
column14: if later on after a period of time we find that Social Security is in trouble
column15: we'll pull together the top experts of the country. We'll do exactly what we did in the 1990s. And we'll make whatever adjustment is necessary.  But the first and most important thing is to start creating jobs in America. The jobs the president is creating pay $9
column16: 000 less than the jobs that we're losing. And this is the first president in 72 years to preside over an economy in America that has lost jobs
column17: 1. 6 million jobs.  Eleven other presidents -- six Democrats and five Republicans -- had wars
column18: had recessions
column19: had great difficulties; none of them lost jobs the way this president has.  I have a plan to put America back to work. And if we're fiscally responsible and put America back to work
column20: we're going to fix Social Security.

column1: He forgot to tell you he voted to tax Social Security benefits more than one time. I didn't hear any plan to fix Social Security. I heard more of the same. He talks about middle-class tax cuts. That's exactly where the tax cuts went. Most of the tax cuts went to low- and middle-income Americans. And now the tax code is more fair. Twenty percent of the upper-income people pay about 80 percent of the taxes in America today because of how we structured the tax cuts. People listening out there know the benefits of the tax cuts we passed. If you have a child
column2: you got tax relief. If you're married
column3: you got tax relief. If you pay any tax at all
column4: you got tax relief. All of which was opposed by my opponent.  And the tax relief was important to spur consumption and investment to get us out of this recession.  People need to remember: Six months prior to my arrival
column5: the stock market started to go down. And it was one of the largest declines in our history. And then we had a recession and we got attacked
column6: which cost us 1 million jobs.  But we acted. I led the Congress. We passed tax relief. And now this economy is growing. We added 1. 9 million new jobs over the last 13 months.  Sure
column7: there's more work to do. But the way to make sure our economy grows is not to raise taxes on small-business owners. It's not to increase the scope of the federal government. It's to make sure we have fiscal sanity and keep taxes low.

column2: '13Oct'
column3: 9)	" I see it as a serious problem. I see it as a security issue
column4: I see it as an economic issue
column5: and I see it as a human-rights issue. We're increasing the border security of the United States. We've got 1
column6: 000 more Border Patrol agents on the southern border.  We're using new equipment. We're using unmanned vehicles to spot people coming across.  And we'll continue to do so over the next four years. It's a subject I'm very familiar with. After all
column7: I was a border governor for a while.  Many people are coming to this country for economic reasons. They're coming here to work. If you can make 50 cents in the heart of Mexico
column8: for example
column9: or make $5 here in America
column11: you're going to come here if you're worth your salt
column12: if you want to put food on the table for your families. And that's what's happening.  And so in order to take pressure off the borders
column13: in order to make the borders more secure
column14: I believe there ought to be a temporary worker card that allows a willing worker and a willing employer to mate up
column15: so long as there's not an American willing to do that job
column16: to join up in order to be able to fulfill the employers' needs.  That has the benefit of making sure our employers aren't breaking the law as they try to fill their workforce needs. It makes sure that the people coming across the border are humanely treated
column17: that they're not kept in the shadows of our society
column18: that they're able to go back and forth to see their families. See
column19: the card
column20: it'll have a period of time attached to it.  It also means it takes pressure off the border. If somebody is coming here to work with a card
column21: it means they're not going to have to sneak across the border. It means our border patrol will be more likely to be able to focus on doing their job.  Now
column22: it's very important for our citizens to also know that I don't believe we ought to have amnesty. I don't think we ought to reward illegal behavior. There are plenty of people standing in line to become a citizen. And we ought not to crowd these people ahead of them in line.  If they want to become a citizen
column23: they can stand in line
column24: too.  And here is where my opponent and I differ. In September 2003
column25: he supported amnesty for illegal aliens.

column1: Let me just answer one part of the last question quickly
column2: and then I'll come to immigration. The American middle-class family isn't making it right now
column3: Bob. And what the president said about the tax cuts has been wiped out by the increase in health care
column4: the increase in gasoline
column5: the increase in tuitions
column6: the increase in prescription drugs.  The fact is
column7: the take-home pay of a typical American family as a share of national income is lower than it's been since 1929. And the take-home pay of the richest . 1 percent of Americans is the highest it's been since 1928.  Under President Bush
column8: the middle class has seen their tax burden go up and the wealthiest's tax burden has gone down. Now that's wrong.  Now
column9: with respect to immigration reform
column10: the president broke his promise on immigration reform. He said he would reform it. Four years later he is now promising another plan.  Here's what I'll do: Number one
column11: the borders are more leaking today than they were before 9/11. The fact is
column12: we haven't done what we need to do to toughen up our borders
column13: and I will.  Secondly
column14: we need a guest-worker program
column15: but if it's all we have
column16: it's not going to solve the problem.  The second thing we need is to crack down on illegal hiring. It's against the law in the United States to hire people illegally
column17: and we ought to be enforcing that law properly.  And thirdly
column18: we need an earned-legalization program for people who have been here for a long time
column19: stayed out of trouble
column20: got a job
column22: and their kids are American. We got to start moving them toward full citizenship
column23: out of the shadows. SCHIEFFER: Do you want to respond
column24: Mr. President?

column2: to say that the borders are not as protected as they were prior to September the 11th shows he doesn't know the borders. They're much better protected today than they were when I was the governor of Texas. We have much more manpower and much more equipment there.  He just doesn't understand how the borders work
column3: evidently
column4: to say that. That is an outrageous claim.  And we'll continue to protect our borders. We're continuing to increase manpower and equipment.

column1: Four thousand people a day are coming across the border. The fact is that we now have people from the Middle East
column2: allegedly
column3: coming across the border.  And we're not doing what we ought to do in terms of the technology. We have iris-identification technology. We have thumbprint
column4: fingerprint technology today. We can know who the people are
column5: that they're really the people they say they are when they cross the border.  We could speed it up. There are huge delays.  The fact is our borders are not as secure as they ought to be
column6: and I'll make them secure.

column2: '13Oct'
column3: 9)	" I see it as a serious problem. I see it as a security issue
column4: I see it as an economic issue
column5: and I see it as a human-rights issue. We're increasing the border security of the United States. We've got 1
column6: 000 more Border Patrol agents on the southern border.  We're using new equipment. We're using unmanned vehicles to spot people coming across.  And we'll continue to do so over the next four years. It's a subject I'm very familiar with. After all
column7: I was a border governor for a while.  Many people are coming to this country for economic reasons. They're coming here to work. If you can make 50 cents in the heart of Mexico
column8: for example
column9: or make $5 here in America
column11: you're going to come here if you're worth your salt
column12: if you want to put food on the table for your families. And that's what's happening.  And so in order to take pressure off the borders
column13: in order to make the borders more secure
column14: I believe there ought to be a temporary worker card that allows a willing worker and a willing employer to mate up
column15: so long as there's not an American willing to do that job
column16: to join up in order to be able to fulfill the employers' needs.  That has the benefit of making sure our employers aren't breaking the law as they try to fill their workforce needs. It makes sure that the people coming across the border are humanely treated
column17: that they're not kept in the shadows of our society
column18: that they're able to go back and forth to see their families. See
column19: the card
column20: it'll have a period of time attached to it.  It also means it takes pressure off the border. If somebody is coming here to work with a card
column21: it means they're not going to have to sneak across the border. It means our border patrol will be more likely to be able to focus on doing their job.  Now
column22: it's very important for our citizens to also know that I don't believe we ought to have amnesty. I don't think we ought to reward illegal behavior. There are plenty of people standing in line to become a citizen. And we ought not to crowd these people ahead of them in line.  If they want to become a citizen
column23: they can stand in line
column24: too.  And here is where my opponent and I differ. In September 2003
column25: he supported amnesty for illegal aliens.

column1: Let me just answer one part of the last question quickly
column2: and then I'll come to immigration. The American middle-class family isn't making it right now
column3: Bob. And what the president said about the tax cuts has been wiped out by the increase in health care
column4: the increase in gasoline
column5: the increase in tuitions
column6: the increase in prescription drugs.  The fact is
column7: the take-home pay of a typical American family as a share of national income is lower than it's been since 1929. And the take-home pay of the richest . 1 percent of Americans is the highest it's been since 1928.  Under President Bush
column8: the middle class has seen their tax burden go up and the wealthiest's tax burden has gone down. Now that's wrong.  Now
column9: with respect to immigration reform
column10: the president broke his promise on immigration reform. He said he would reform it. Four years later he is now promising another plan.  Here's what I'll do: Number one
column11: the borders are more leaking today than they were before 9/11. The fact is
column12: we haven't done what we need to do to toughen up our borders
column13: and I will.  Secondly
column14: we need a guest-worker program
column15: but if it's all we have
column16: it's not going to solve the problem.  The second thing we need is to crack down on illegal hiring. It's against the law in the United States to hire people illegally
column17: and we ought to be enforcing that law properly.  And thirdly
column18: we need an earned-legalization program for people who have been here for a long time
column19: stayed out of trouble
column20: got a job
column22: and their kids are American. We got to start moving them toward full citizenship
column23: out of the shadows. SCHIEFFER: Do you want to respond
column24: Mr. President?

column2: to say that the borders are not as protected as they were prior to September the 11th shows he doesn't know the borders. They're much better protected today than they were when I was the governor of Texas. We have much more manpower and much more equipment there.  He just doesn't understand how the borders work
column3: evidently
column4: to say that. That is an outrageous claim.  And we'll continue to protect our borders. We're continuing to increase manpower and equipment.

column1: Four thousand people a day are coming across the border. The fact is that we now have people from the Middle East
column2: allegedly
column3: coming across the border.  And we're not doing what we ought to do in terms of the technology. We have iris-identification technology. We have thumbprint
column4: fingerprint technology today. We can know who the people are
column5: that they're really the people they say they are when they cross the border.  We could speed it up. There are huge delays.  The fact is our borders are not as secure as they ought to be
column6: and I'll make them secure.
